He used to smoke a half-pack of cigarettes daily early in his adulthood but quit smoking around 20 years ago. His dietary history reveals a preference for high-fat and high-cholesterol foods. He also admits to maintaining a sedentary lifestyle with little physical activity  although he used to be more active in his younger years.   Mr. Wilson’s father died of a heart attack at the age of 59 and he reports that a few of his male family members have also had cardiac events in their late fifties. On his last visit 3 months ago  his body mass index was recorded as 28.5 and his blood pressure was 145/85 mm Hg. His LDL cholesterol was 145 mg/dL and HDL cholesterol was 35 mg/dL. His HbA1c was 7.5%.   Given the multiple risk factors — advanced age  male gender  African American ethnicity  family history of coronary artery disease (CAD)  personal history of DM and HTN  history of smoking  a high-fat diet and sedentary lifestyle — Mr. Wilson is at a high risk for CAD  which may be responsible for his symptoms.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old African American male who presents with a chief complaint of increasing bouts of agina over past three months. He describes a left-sided chest pain that he characterizes as a “heavy feeling ” accompanied by shortness of breath and fatigue. The pain is especially severe after moderate exertion such as climbing stairs or after a meal but it also occurred at rest twice in the last week. He reports that his symptoms are relieved with rest in 15-20 minutes.  Mr. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications include Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes. He does not take any medication for the chest discomfort. He is a former smoker  having quit 5-6 years ago after smoking a pack a day for 25 years. His mother and father died at ages 70 and 75 respectively  and both had heart diseases.  Social history reveals that he lives with his wife and is a retired mechanic. He admits to poor diet  occasional alcohol use and his exercise regimen is limited due to consistent lower back pain. On physical examination  he appears in moderate distress. His height and weight are 5'8"" and 190 pounds respectively. His BMI is 28.9 kg/m2 indicating he is overweight. His blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg  heart rate of 82 bpm  and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute.  His diagnostic test including ECG indicated T-wave inversion and 2D Echo revealed mild left ventricular hypertrophy. His laboratory results showed elevated LDL and HbA1c levels confirming poor diabetes control. These findings along with his clinical presentation  risk factors such as hypertension  dyslipidemia  diabetes  a positive family history  and his demographic (African-American male older than 60 years) highly suggest the diagnosis of coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  A 63-year-old African-American male presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic chest pain for the last 3 months  with increased severity over the last few days. The pain is described as a heavy pressure sensation centrally located in the chest  radiating to the left arm  and often occurs during physical activity or bouts of extreme stress but subsides at rest.  He reports a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 25 years  but has quit for 7 years. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension managed with lisinopril for the last 5 years and hyperlipidaemia managed with atorvastatin for 3 years. His father experienced a myocardial infarction at the age of 55.  His BMI is 31  vital signs are BP 140/90 mmHg  HR 78 bpm  RR 18 per minute  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. No evidence of acute distress noted. On auscultation  cardiac sounds S1 and S2 are appreciable and rhythm regular with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  He currently works as a middle school teacher and lives with his wife. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. He has a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity. His diet history reveals frequent consumption of high-fat foods.  These presenting symptoms  demographic attributes  and lifestyle habits are suggestive of possible stable coronary artery disease with high-risk factors. Further diagnostic workup including EKG and echocardiogram is recommended to rule out other differential diagnoses. The patient is at high risk for a major cardiovascular event due to his age  race  chronic hypertension  hyperlipidaemia  history of smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of premature coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Juan Garcia  a 67-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic complaining of persistent substernal chest pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw  often experienced during exertion but resolves with rest. The pain is described as a crushing sensation and has been occurring intermittently over the past three months. He has associated symptoms of dyspnea  easy fatiguability  and episodes of diaphoresis.  Mr. Garcia lives with his wife in the city and is a retired construction worker. He has a 30-year history of smoking but claims to have quit ten years ago. His diet is high in red meats and processed foods  with minimal consumption of fruits and vegetables. He lacks consistent physical activity. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  His past medical history includes uncontrolled type 2 diabetes diagnosed eight years ago and hypertension diagnosed ten years ago. His medication regimen includes metformin 500 mg twice daily  lisinopril 20 mg daily  and aspirin 81 mg daily.   His last check-up was six months ago  where elevated LDL cholesterol levels were noted  and no other significant findings were reported. He has not sought intervention for his chest pain until today. He denies any other associated symptoms such as syncope  palpitations  or lower extremity swelling.   This presentation is typical of worsening stable angina  a manifestation of coronary artery disease. His advanced age  male sex  Hispanic ethnicity  family history  history of smoking  unhealthy diet  lack of physical activity  poorly managed diabetes and hypertension  and elevated LDL cholesterol place Mr. Garcia at high risk for coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Oleva is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired construction worker  presenting to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent chest pain. The pain is described as a crushing sensation  centrally located  and often radiates to his left arm. It has been occurring intermittently for the past 6 months  typically with exertion such as when climbing stairs or carrying heavy items  and relieved by rest within 10-15 minutes. The intensity varies  usually 5/10  but once reached 8/10  which forced him to seek care in the ER. He also reports associated symptoms such as feeling short of breath  sweating  and occasional nausea during these episodes. The chest pain is not provoked by eating  coughing  or changes in body position. He denies palpitations  dizziness  or fainting.  His past medical history includes type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia for which he takes metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin respectively. He smoked one pack of cigarettes a day for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He reports a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity and a habit of eating fast food. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father suffering a myocardial infarction at age 52 and his older brother undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting at age 60.  On physical examination  he appears slightly overweight with a BMI of 29. The cardiovascular examination shows a regular rhythm with an S4 gallop. There was no audible murmur  rubs  or clicks. Blood pressure is mildly elevated at 142/85 mmHg.   His current presenting signs  symptoms  and history suggest a probable diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD). Further assessment with diagnostic testing  such as an ECG or stress test  will be required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of disease.

Patient Presentation:  John Smith  a 65-year-old African American male  presented to the clinic today complaining of intermittent chest pain. The pain is described as a squeezing pressure sensation in the middle of his chest that generally lasts less than a few minutes. He reports that the chest discomfort is often triggered by physical activity or emotional stress but will usually dissipate at rest. Occasional dyspnea and indigestion like symptoms have been noticed concurrent with chest pain.  John has a medical history significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension  conditions ubiquitous in literature as comorbidities of coronary artery disease. He was a heavy smoker throughout his adult life but he quit five years ago upon his diabetes diagnosis. His father died of a heart attack in his early 70s as did his two older brothers in their early 60s.  His current medications include Metformin 1000mg for his diabetes  Lisinopril 20mg for hypertension  and low-dose aspirin 81mg as a chest pain prophylaxis. Despite medication compliance  John reports his symptoms have been steadily worsening over the past several months. Occasionally  he has also experienced discomfort in his neck  shoulder  and arm which are new developments and bring him in for consultation today.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Brown Age: 64 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer Race: Caucasian Marital Status: Married  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Brown has presented in the clinic today complaining of recurrent episodes of chest pain  particularly during physical exertion or under stress  which is relieved by rest. He describes the pain as a squeezing  pressure-like discomfort radiating to his left arm and jaw. He has also reported experiencing shortness of breath and occasional bouts of nausea.  Past Medical History: Mr. Brown is a former smoker and quit smoking 10 years ago. He has been diagnosed with hypertension and high cholesterol for which he has been on medication for the past 12 years. He is overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 29. His father had a heart attack at 65 and his elder brother underwent angioplasty at the age of 60.  Medications: He is on Amlodipine 5 mg for hypertension and Atorvastatin 20 mg for high cholesterol  Family History: His father died of a heart attack; his mother died of complications associated with diabetes. His elder brother underwent an angioplasty few years back.   Social History: He lives with his wife and reports occasional alcohol consumption. Mr Brown retired 4 years ago and leads a largely sedentary lifestyle.   Physical Examination: At rest  Mr. Brown appears comfortable. He is alert  oriented and in no respiratory distress. His blood pressure reading is 139/85 mmHg and his heart rate is 78 beats per minute. His ECG showed nonspecific ST-T wave changes.   Plan:  Given his high-risk profile  Mr. Brown has been recommended for further evaluation  including echocardiogram and stress test  to establish a formal diagnosis of coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Stewart  a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a body mass index of 30 Kg/m^2  presents to the cardiology clinic with a 4-month history of chest discomfort and dyspnea on exertion. The discomfort  which he describes as a 'pressure' or 'heaviness' in his chest  tends to occur when he is walking or exercising; also  he notes that it subsides when he rests.   Mr. Stewart has a 20-year history of smoking a pipe but quit 5 years ago. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both of which have been managed with metformin and lisinopril  respectively  for the past 10 years. His blood pressure has been consistently within the normal range on recent readings  and his last HbA1c 3 months ago was 6.8%. His family history is significant  with his father having experienced a myocardial infarction at the age of 57.  Regarding his lifestyle  Mr. Stewart is generally sedentary and consumes a diet rich in fats and carbohydrates. He drinks alcohol minimally and does not use recreational drugs. His cholesterol levels have been high in the past; however  he does not take any statin medication. He admits to occasional non-compliance with his prescribed medications due to forgetfulness.  On examination  he appears well  but slightly overweight  with a pulse rate of 75 bpm  regular  and blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination shows no signs of heart failure. His lung examination is unremarkable. His ECG shows some T wave inversion in leads V1 to V4. The rest of his physical exam is within normal limits.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 64-year-old Hispanic male presenting with steady  dull chest pain radiating down his left arm. The pain is described as a heavy squeezing sensation in the chest  and it often occurs after meals or physical exertion.   Mr. Rodriguez has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  which have been managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin for the past 10 years. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago after a 20-year pack-a-day habit. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease with both his father and paternal grandfather dying of myocardial infarctions in their 60s. He acknowledges a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in saturated fats and processed foods.  Recently  Mr. Rodriguez has also experienced increased shortness of breath with minimal exertion and episodes of lightheadedness. He denies any nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis during these episodes. His current medications include Lisinopril 10 mg daily  Atorvastatin 20 mg daily  and Aspirin 81 mg daily. He shows adherence to medications and regularly attends his medical appointments.  His vital signs today include: Blood pressure 140/85  Pulse 78  Respirations 18  Saturation 95%  BMI 30 indicating obesity. On examination  his cardiovascular system shows normal S1 and S2 with no additional heart sounds or murmurs. He has mild pitting edema in the ankles.  Given Mr. Rodriguez's age  gender  background  and history  there is a strong suspicion of stable angina and coronary artery disease. A workup including ECG  lab tests (including lipid profile and cardiac biomarkers)  and stress testing is being considered to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

Patient Presentation: A 64 year-old African American man  Mr. A.B  presents to the clinic complaining of on-and-off substernal chest pressure that typically lasts 10-15 minutes. The pain radiates towards his left shoulder and is associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. Activities like climbing stairs or shoveling snow initiate the symptom which disappears with rest. He had not had any before two months ago. He also reports a history of chronic lower back pain for which he occasionally takes ibuprofen but avoids due to history of peptic ulcer disease.  Past Medical History: Mr. A.B. is a former smoker  having smoked 1 pack per day for 30 years and quit 8 years ago. He has a diagnosis of type II diabetes which is managed with metformin and has hypertension controlled with lisinopril. A peptic ulcer was diagnosed 5 years ago and is treated with omeprazole. He has a BMI of 28  indicating overweight. His father died at 70 due to a heart attack.  Demographics:  Mr. A.B. is a retired civil engineer  he is married  lives with his wife and they have two children. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use. His diet is mostly meat-based with low fruit and vegetable intake. He does not engage in regular physical activity. His wife is his major support system and accompanies him for most appointments.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with ongoing chest discomfort that he describes as ""heavy"" and ""dull "" and occasionally radiates to his left arm. He says the discomfort has persisted for the last two weeks and has been worsening in intensity. In recent days  the discomfort has been occasionally provoked by mild to moderate physical activity but sometimes occurs even at rest. He also reports experiencing dyspnea on exertion.   Mr. Doe is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history  but he quit 10 years ago. His other risk factors for coronary artery disease include a history of hypertension  which is controlled with lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia  controlled with atorvastatin. He has a strong familial history of coronary artery disease; his father had a heart attack at the age of 62  and his brother had an angina diagnosis in his 50s. Mr. Doe is married  retired  and lives with his wife.   His diet does contain a significant amount of red meat  and he admits he could likely benefit from an increase in his physical activity. Alcohol consumption is minimal to moderate  with no history of drug abuse. Mr. Doe also mentions he had been under some additional stress due to personal reasons over the past few months.   On examination  his blood pressure is mildly elevated at 138/88 mmHg  heart rate 80 bpm  and BMI calculated at 27  indicating overweight. Auscultation of the heart reveals no murmurs or gallops. Pulses are equal on both sides  and his respiration sounds are normal. His cholesterol panel from last year showed increased LDL levels at 140 mg/dL and a total cholesterol at 220 mg/dL.   Mr. Doe’s current symptoms  along with his past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking  stress  lifestyle factors  family history and age  make coronary artery disease a significant concern.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 65-year-old Hispanic male who presents with a complaint of intermittent chest pain  sometimes radiating to his left arm  over the past two months. He describes the pain as pressing in nature  often exacerbated by physical exertion and relieved with rest. Additionally  he mentions occasional episodes of breathlessness on exertion alongside the chest pain. He denies any symptoms of palpitations  syncope or swelling of legs.   He has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and is on Metformin. His father passed away from a heart attack in his 70s which raises suspicion about a possible genetic predisposition. Apart from this  Mr. Rodriguez is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history and he occasionally consumes alcohol.  On examination  his blood pressure is slightly elevated at 140/85 mmHg  pulse rate is regular at 80 beats per minute  and BMI is 28 kg/m2 which falls into the overweight category.  Based on his age  sex  ethnicity  symptom description  past medical and family history  he fits much of the risk factor profile for Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Further diagnostic tests should be scheduled to confirm the diagnosis  including an Electrocardiogram (ECG)  stress test and possibly a coronary angiography.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Williams Age: 62 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Mechanic  Presenting Complaint:   Mr. Williams reports experiencing episodes of chest pain  mostly occurring during periods of activity but recently it has started to happen during periods of rest. The pain often radiates to his left arm and is occasionally associated with shortness of breath and sweating.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Williams has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years  which is being managed with medication. He has been a smoker for the past 35 years with a history of 20 pack/years. He also has a family history of heart disease  with his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 65.  Diet and Exercise:  Mr. Williams admits to having a high-fat diet with an inactive lifestyle and very limited physical exercise.  Review of Symptoms:   The patient also reported a recent onset of fatigue  occasional dizziness  palpitations  and episodes of nausea. He denies any history of syncope  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.  Social History:  He has been retired for two years now and lives with his wife. His alcohol consumption is moderate  and he has been a chronic smoker. He admits to being under stress after retirement due to financial constraints.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he is overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 29. He has high blood pressure  high resting heart rate  and his electrocardiogram (ECG) shows signs of ischemic heart disease. His cholesterol levels are elevated  he has a FIFO murmur and evidence of poor peripheral circulation is present.  Based on the above history  symptoms  and demographic factors  a preliminary diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) is suspected. Further investigations like coronary angiography  echocardiography  or a stress test may be suggested to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the disease.

Patient Information: Mrs. Elizabeth Morales  a 65-year-old Latina woman.  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Morales presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of intermittent chest pressure which she describes as ""a heavy feeling""  typically occurring when she is climbing stairs or doing household chores and usually subsiding with rest. She has also noticed she's been more breathless when walking her dog or climbing stairs  compared to a year ago.  Medical History: Mrs. Morales has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes for the past 10 years  which is reasonably managed by oral hypoglycemics - Metformin 500mg BID. She also has hypertension  under control with Lisinopril 10mg daily. There's no previous history of a similar chest condition  stroke  or peripheral arterial disease.   Social History: Mrs. Morales is a retired school teacher  living with her husband and is originally from Mexico. She denies tobacco use but admits to occasional alcohol use (only socially on weekends).   Family History: She has a significant family history  namely her mother who died of myocardial infarction at age 70  and her older brother has had a coronary stent placed at age 60.   Review of systems is otherwise negative  particularly she denies symptoms of orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or palpitations.  Based on her presenting symptoms  past medical history  and significant risk factors including her age  sex  diabetes  hypertension  and family history  Mrs. Morales was suspected to have coronary artery disease (CAD) and was sent for further cardiologic evaluation. Her symptoms of exertional chest discomfort point towards stable angina  a common presentation of CAD.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Edward James  a 56-year-old African-American male  presented to the clinic commenting of gradually progressing chest discomfort predominantly on exertion  which he has been experiencing for the past two months. The discomfort typically radiates to his left arm and is occasionally associated with shortness of breath and sweating. Pain usually lasts for about 10 minutes and is relieved by rest.  Previously  Mr. James had been relatively healthy  with a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years  mild hypertension controlled with low dose Lisinopril  and dyslipidemia for which he was prescribed Atorvastatin five years back. There is no history of diabetes mellitus or other cardiovascular diseases. His father had survived a heart attack at the age of 60. In terms of exercise  Mr. James is sedentary and works as a driver for a courier company. His diet is high in saturated fats and he admits to drinking 3-4 beers daily.  On examination  his blood pressure was found to be 140/90 mmHg and his BMI calculated to 32 kg/m2. The remainder of his physical examination is unremarkable.  Mr. James' symptoms  along with his risk factors including his ethnicity  age  sex  chronic smoking habit  unmanaged hypertension  dyslipidemia  family history  and lifestyle choices  make coronary artery disease the leading differential diagnosis. More diagnostic studies will be required to confirm the cause and the severity of the disease  including an ECG  exercise stress test and possibly cardiac imaging or catheterization.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Smith is a 58-year-old Caucasian male who presents with intermittent substernal chest pain radiating down the left arm  occurring primarily during physical exertion and relieved with rest over the past two weeks. He reports occasional shortness of breath  palpitations  and diaphoresis. There's no associated nausea  vomiting  or fainting.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril 20 mg daily  and hyperlipidemia  controlled with 20 mg Atorvastatin daily. He is a former smoker but quit 15 years ago after a smoking history of two packs a day for 20 years. He admits to having a ""mostly sedentary"" lifestyle and an inconsistent diet rife with fatty foods.   He has a family history significant for heart disease; his father suffered a heart attack at 60 years. He consumes alcohol socially but denies illicit drug use. He works in finance  married with two children  and describes himself as being under ""moderate stress.""   On physical exam  the patient appears mildly uncomfortable but not acutely distressed. His BMI is calculated at 28  indicating he is overweight. Vital signs are within normal range except for an elevated blood pressure of 140/90mmHg. Cardiovascular examination reveals a regular rhythm with no audible murmurs  rubs  gallops. Pulmonary examination shows clear breath sounds bilaterally. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Considering his age  sex  significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  strong family history of heart disease  lifestyle  and classic symptoms  the diagnosis of coronary artery disease is highly likely. Further evaluation with an EKG and cardiac stress test is planned.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. J. Smith  a 62-year-old African American male  presents to the office with reports of intermittent chest discomfort of 3 months duration. He describes the discomfort as a ""pressure-like"" sensation  usually precipitated by physical exertion or emotional distress and typically relieved by rest  lasting approximately for 10-15 minutes. He also reports experiencing shortness of breath on exertion and occasional bouts of lightheadedness.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled through medication for the last 15 years. He has a 20-year history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily  though he quit smoking 5 years ago. He has a family history of heart disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.   Mr. Smith's occupational history reveals that he is a retired teacher and currently he leads an increasingly sedentary lifestyle. His diet is high in red meat and fried food. His current medications include Metformin 500mg twice daily  Rosuvastatin 10mg once a day  and Lisinopril 10mg once a day.   On examination  Mr. Smith appears uncomfortable and his vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 78 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and body mass index of 31 kg/m^2. His cardiovascular examination reveals a regular rhythm  without any murmurs  rubs  or gallops.   This history and presentation is strongly suggestive of stable coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American male who presents to the clinic with a three-week history of chest discomfort and shortness of breath. The chest discomfort is located in the middle of his chest  described as a pressure-like sensation  and tends to radiate towards his left arm. These symptoms are often provoked by mild-to-moderate exertion (e.g.  walking or climbing stairs) and are typically relieved by rest.  The clinical history reveals Mr. Johnson is a retired construction worker. He has a 20-year history of hypertension for which he has been inconsistently treated due to occasional lapses in insurance coverage. He admits to non-compliance with his prescribed blood pressure medications. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years but quit approximately two months ago. He has a modest alcohol intake of upto one glass of wine a day.  He has a family history significant for heart disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at 62 years of age  and his older brother has undergone percutaneous coronary intervention. He has a past medical history of high cholesterol diagnosed 5 years prior  however  he has never been on lipid-lowering therapy.  His diet predominantly consists of high-fat and high-sodium foods. He is obese with a BMI of 32 kg/m2 and does not engage in any regular exercise.  The patient sounds to be in significant distress due to his symptoms. Considering his history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  strong family history  physical inactivity  high-sodium diet  obesity  and past smoking history  the suspicion for coronary artery disease is heightened.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 62-year-old African American male  presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of recurrent chest pain  radiating to his left shoulder  enduring for the past two months. The pain is typically exacerbated by physical activity and mild exertion  with relief occurring upon rest. Mr. Smith further describes the feeling as a heavy pressure  rated 7/10 on the pain scale  accompanied by episodes of shortness of breath and occasional episodes of sweating and light-headedness.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been a type-2 diabetic for ten years  controlled with metformin and regular diet. He was diagnosed with hypertension five years ago  controlled with amlodipine. His lipid panel from a routine check-up six months ago showed hypercholesterolemia. He does not have a personal history of heart disease but his mother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 67 and paternal grandfather died of a heart disease in his early 70's.   Social History:  Mr. Smith is a retired construction worker  currently living with his wife in an urban setting. He has been a smoker for the past 45 years  averaging a pack per day  and reports minimal alcohol consumption  typically a few beers over the weekend. He follows a diet high in saturated fats  low in fruits and vegetables  and admits to leading a sedentary lifestyle  including lack of regular exercise. He reports adherence to his medications and has no known drug allergies.   Family History:  As stated above  Mr. Smith has a strong family history of heart disease. His mother had a myocardial infarction and his paternal grandfather had heart disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 58-year-old Hispanic male presenting to the clinic with chief complaints of recent episodes of chest pain  typically occurring with exertion and abating with rest. He reports that these episodes have been gradually increasing in frequency and intensity over the past 3 months. The pain is described as feeling like a heavy pressure in the center of his chest  sometimes radiating to his left arm and jaw.   He additionally reports associated symptoms of fatigue  shortness of breath after exertion  and the occasional feeling of indigestion. Mr. Rodriguez also noticed increasing discomfort in his chest during his usual morning walks. He has no history of nausea  vomiting  or sweating associated with the chest pains  nor history of loss of consciousness or palpitations.  Mr. Rodriguez's past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypertension. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and his mother had a stroke at the age of 70. Mr. Rodirguez has been smoking a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 30 years  consumes alcohol socially (one drink per day) and admits to a diet high in saturated fats and salt.  There is no known drug allergies. Medications include metformin for diabetes  and amlodipine for hypertension. Mr. Rodriguez is currently working as a construction worker and lives with his wife and two adult children.  Considering his risk factors including his genetics  ethnicity  age  male gender  smoking history  diet  and uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension  he is at high risk for coronary artery disease. Further assessment  including functional testing or coronary angiography  needs to be considered to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Joseph Sanchez  a 64-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic with a 4-day history of central chest pain radiating to his left arm  shortness of breath  and increased fatigue. At first  he associated these symptoms with his known diagnosis of Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD). However  they persisted and amplified during physical efforts. He also experiences episodes of night sweats  nausea  and loss of appetite in the past days.  Mr. Sanchez has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His list of medications includes Metformin 1000mg BID  Atorvastatin 40mg nightly  Amlodipine 10mg daily  baby Aspirin 81mg daily  and as needed antacids for GERD.   His family history includes a father who died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and a brother who suffered from a stroke in his 60's. Mr. Sanchez is a retired construction worker  reports a 30-year history of smoking (currently 1 pack of cigarettes per day)  consumes alcohol socially  and has a known BMI of 32 indicating obesity. He reports being noncompliant with his diet  medication  and lacks physical activity due to his demanding work schedule prior to retirement.  This patient presentation is consistent with a potential diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) due to his symptoms  demographic (older  male  Hispanic)  past medical history of risk factors (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes)  lifestyle elements (smoking  sedentary behavior  obesity)  and family history. Careful evaluation and tests are needed to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the disease.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Jim Ross  a 64-year-old African-American male  presents to his primary care physician's office with a recent history of intermittent exertional chest pain that radiates to his left arm. He describes the pain as a feeling of pressure and tightness  exacerbated by physical activity and stress  but typically relieved with rest. He reports that it lasts for less than 10 minutes at a time  and has occurred over the last month. He also mentioned he has been experiencing bouts of shortness of breath and fatigue on exertion.  Relevant past medical history reveals he has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he is on medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively). He has a 25-year history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day  although he recently reduced to half pack per day over the last year. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and has a family history of ischemic heart disease  with his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 59.  His dietary habits include high intake of fatty foods like fast food and red meat  while his alcohol consumption is modest at 1-2 drinks a month. He acknowledges the limited time spent on exercise  pinpointing his busy schedule as a barrier to regular physical activity. He also notes occasional episodes of anxiety that increase his stress levels.   Upon examination  blood pressure reading is 140/85  heart rate is 92 beats/minute  and body mass index (BMI) is lodged at 28. The lipid profile reveals elevated LDL levels and his latest HbA1c is found to be marginally high at 6.3 highlighting a potential risk for developing diabetes.  With his clinical presentation of symptoms  past medical history  and lifestyle  this patient is highly suspicious for coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents in the outpatient clinic with a 2-week history of exertional chest pain. The pain is described as a pressure-like sensation  radiating to his left arm  and associated with shortness of breath and profuse sweating. It often subsides with rest within 10-15 minutes. Recently  he noticed the chest pain occurring at rest as well. The patient admits to having similar episodes of chest pain in the past  however  dismissed them as indigestion.  He is a 40 pack-year smoker  with a diet high in saturated fats and low in fruits and vegetables. His father died of a heart attack at 70 years and his older brother diagnosed with a coronary artery disease at 63 years.   Mr. Doe has a 15-year history of chronic hypertension controlled by medication. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago  poorly controlled  as indicated by his recent HbA1c level of 8.5%. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 5 years ago  but has not been consistent with his statin treatment.   A resting ECG shows nonspecific ST-T changes and T-wave inversions. Physical examination is unremarkable otherwise. His body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m2  indicating obesity. He has been sedentary most of his adult life and admits to chronic stress related to his work as a businessman.   Given his symptoms and risk factors  including his age  sex  positive family history  smoking  sedentary lifestyle  stress  diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  and poor dietary habits  the patient is suspected to have coronary artery disease (CAD).

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting with a two-month history of progressive exertional chest pain. He describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation in the center of his chest which radiates to his left arm. The chest pain typically lasts for 15-20 minutes and is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. The pain develops after walking about two blocks or ascending a flight of stairs and is relieved by rest. He has also experienced this pain during stressful events  like an argument.  Mr. Johnson reports a history of hypertension diagnosed 12 years ago  type 2 diabetes diagnosed 9 years ago and he quit smoking cigarettes 10 years ago after a 30 pack-year history. His medications consist of Metformin 1000 mg twice daily  Lisinopril 20 mg once daily  and Atenolol 50 mg once daily. He lives alone and retired 8 years ago as an engineer. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 50  and his mother has hypertension and diabetes.  On physical examination  Mr. Johnson has a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg and a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. His body mass index is 31  and his waist circumference is 41 inches indicating obesity. His lipid panel reveals an LDL of 150 mg/dL  HDL of 35 mg/dL  and triglycerides of 175 mg/dL.  These demographic details  the given past medical history  long term smoking history and family history of coronary artery disease  as well as current obesity  make Mr. Johnson susceptible to atherosclerotic coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old African-American male  presenting with a chief complaint of chest discomfort of two-hour duration. He describes his pain as a retrosternal 'pressure' radiating down his left arm. The discomfort is 7/10 in intensity and is brought on by exertion. He reports associated symptoms including shortness of breath  excessive sweating  and episodes of lightheadedness. He denies any personal history of chest pain.  Patient History:  Mr. Johnson is a retired postal worker and lives with his wife. He has a medical history of hypertension for about 15 years  controlled with medication (Lisinopril)  and type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years  managed with Metformin. He has maintained a poor diet and sedentary lifestyle since retirement. Apart from his routine medications  he does not take any over-the-counter medications  herbal supplements  or indulge in recreational drug use.   Family History:  He has a strong family history of coronary artery disease  with his father having a heart attack at age 65 and his older brother having undergone a coronary artery bypass graft surgery at age 60.  Social History:  Mr. Johnson has a 40-pack year history of smoking  having started in his early 20s. He consumes alcohol sparingly  limited to social occasions.  Demographic Details:  His vitals reveal a blood pressure of 160/90 mm Hg  a pulse rate of 88 beats per minute  a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air  and a body mass index of 32 (an indicator of obesity).    Previous Consultations/Procedures:  He has not undergone any hospitalizations or surgeries in the past. He is not known to have any allergies.    Review of Systems:  Gen: He has recently noted fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. CVS: Positive for recurrent episodes of chest discomfort.  Considering his age  sex  race  lifestyle patterns  strong family history of CAD  and clinical presentation  a diagnosis of coronary artery disease seems likely. Further diagnostic evaluation  including an ECG and cardiac enzymes  are advised.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Thompson  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with a complaint of retrosternal chest pain that radiates down his arm  particularly with exertion  along with episodes of shortness of breath and a feeling of tightness in his chest. He mentions that the pain usually subsides upon rest or with the use of nitroglycerin  which was recommended by a friend.   Mr. Thompson has a past medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (for the last 15 years) and Hypertension (for the last 10 years). He admits to being a former smoker  having quit 5 years back after a span of 35 years of smoking. He maintains a rather sedentary lifestyle and his diet includes regular intake of fast food. He doesn't have any known drug allergies.   Family history reveals his father had myocardial infarction at the age of 60  and his mother has chronic hypertension and diabetes. His lipid profile conducted few months back showed elevated total cholesterol and LDL levels.   Patient takes Metformin for his diabetes and hydrochlorothiazide for his hypertension. He admits to irregularities in taking his prescribed medication due to forgetfulness.   On further questioning  Mr. Thompson admits he has been stressed recently due to job-related factors  and reports decreased sleep and low mood  but denies any suicidal ideations.   An electrocardiogram (ECG) and further diagnostic investigations are planned to evaluate the suggestive symptoms of his ongoing chest pain. He has been counselled about the importance of medication compliance  lifestyle changes  and regular follow-ups.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 64-year-old Caucasian male from Michigan  presenting with a six-month history of chest pain that is progressively becoming more frequent and intense. The pain  described as a heavy or squeezing sensation  occurs mainly with exertion and is relieved by rest. Recently  he has been experiencing these discomforts during less strenuous activities as well. He reports shortness of breath and episodes of lightheadedness accompanying the chest pain.  Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for mild hypertension  treated with Lisinopril 10mg daily for the past 10 years. He is a 40-pack-year smoker but quit smoking five years ago. He also traces a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) in his family  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. He follows a high-fat diet and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to his job as a truck driver.  On examination  his blood pressure on presentation is 142/85 mmHg  pulse 78 beats per minute  and BMI measured at 30  indicating obesity. Auscultation of his heart reveals normal S1 and S2 with no added sounds. His cholesterol levels were last checked 3 years ago  with a total cholesterol of 230 mg/dl  LDL 160 mg/dl  and HDL 35 mg/dl. His fasting blood glucose level is 98 mg/dl.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Joseph Turner is a 60-year-old African-American male presenting to the outpatient clinic with a complaint of intermittent chest pain that worsens during physical exertion and is often relieved by rest. The pain is described as a squeezing  pressure-like sensation that occasionally radiates to the patient's left arm. He also reports episodes of breathlessness and at times he feels heart palpitations  especially during stressful times.   Mr. Turner is a retired school teacher who lives with his wife. Both are non-smokers; however  he admits to having a sedentary lifestyle and diet high in fatty foods  which he is finding difficult to change after retiring. He reports drinking alcohol occasionally in moderate quantities. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 63  which the patient is aware increases his personal risk.   As for his past medical history  Mr. Turner has a 10-year history of controlled type-2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He takes Metformin 500mg BID and Lisinopril 10mg daily for his conditions and follows a treatment plan established by his primary physician.   He is concerned about the chest discomfort and fears it might be related to heart disease considering his poor lifestyle habits  family history  and existing comorbidities. He denies any recent weight loss  fever  or cough  and reports regular bowel and bladder habits.  This history of chest pain and breathlessness on exertion in a patient with risk factors including age  gender  race  sedentary lifestyle  diet  diabetes  hypertension  and family history  is suggestive of possible stable angina secondary to coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Tom Smith is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of experiencing episodes of central chest pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw  particularly noticed during physical activity like mowing the lawn or climbing stairs. He mentions that the chest discomfort is typically relieved after resting for some time or while taking sublingual nitroglycerin  which has been prescribed by a previous general practitioner.   Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history. He was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and type 2 diabetes mellitus about 5 years ago. Both conditions are regularly monitored and under control through management with medication  diet  and monthly routine check-ups.   He has a long-standing history of hyperlipidemia and is taking statin medication for the same. Despite quitting smoking 8 years back  he had been a pack-a-day smoker for 25 years. The patient admits he leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle and his diet includes high intake of red meat and fatty foods. His father expired from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. He seems concerned about his recurrent angina symptoms and states that these symptoms are affecting his ability to carry out routine activities.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Rutherford  a 64-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of increasing chest discomfort on exertion. He describes the pain as a constant pressure radiating to his left arm and sometimes associated with shortness of breath  particularly when he is trying to do strenuous activities such as mowing the lawn. The pain improves with rest. He denies any episodes of chest pain at rest. He rated the pain as 7 on a 10-point scale.  He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which is poorly controlled with Metformin. He also reports a 40-pack year smoking history  but quit 10 years ago. He is currently taking Lisinopril for his hypertension. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 65.  On physical exam  his blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg  heart rate is 72 beats per minute  and BMI of 30 kg/m2. The cardiovascular exam demonstrated normal heart sounds without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. No carotid bruits were noted. Pulses were 2+ and equal in all extremities. Residual examination findings were within normal limits.  His ECG revealed T-wave inversions in the inferior leads. Given his risk factors  clinical history  and ECG changes  he was diagnosed with stable coronary artery disease. He was advised lifestyle modifications  including a low salt  low cholesterol diet and regular aerobic exercise. He was also started on aspirin  a beta-blocker  and a statin to manage his risk factors. It was suggested he should follow up in the cardiology clinic for further evaluation  including possible coronary angiography.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Jimenez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent chest pain that he describes as “pressure” in his chest occurring most commonly during periods of exertion or emotional stress  but readily relieved with rest. He states that these episodes last from 2 to 10 minutes. To alleviate the discomfort  beyond rest  he also takes Nitroglycerin which normally helps.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with Lisinopril  type 2 diabetes controlled with Metformin  and hyperlipidemia managed by Atorvastatin. He quit smoking 3 years ago  after maintaining the habit for about 30 years. He admits to occasional alcohol consumption and denies any illicit drug use. His family history is remarkable for coronary artery disease (his father had a heart attack at the age of 56).  Lives alone and maintains a sedentary lifestyle. He worked as an accountant before retirement. He is adherent to his medication regimen  but admits difficulty following the dietary recommendations given.  On physical exam  Mr. Jimenez is 5’8”  weighs 210 lbs  and has a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg. His BMI is 32  which categorize him in obesity. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.   Given the suggestive clinical picture  further diagnostic procedures were recommended to confirm the suspicion of coronary artery disease. He was referred to cardiology for a stress test and possible cardiac catheterization.

Patient Presentation:  John Smith  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic today with complaints of exertional chest discomfort lasting for the past two months. He describes the sensation as a ""squeezing "" and it typically subsides with rest. Lately  he has found that this discomfort is occurring with less exertional activity than when it first started. He also reports feeling increasingly short of breath and experiencing fatigue with minimal exertion. He denies palpitations  dizziness  or syncope.  Mr. Smith is a pack-a-day smoker for the past 40 years and admits to a diet high in red meat and processed foods. He consumes moderate alcohol and has a sedentary lifestyle. His BMI is 29 and he has a history of hypertension managed with Lisinopril 10 mg daily  diagnosed five years back. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Upon physical examination  the patient appears diaphoretic. His blood pressure reads 150/95 mmHg  pulse 90/min  oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Auscultation of the heart reveals no rubs  gallops  or murmurs. Pulmonary examination is clear to auscultation bilaterally.   Given his symptoms  long-standing smoking history  family history of heart disease  and hypertension  there is concern for a presentation consistent with stable angina from possible coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 62-year-old African American male who came to the clinic reporting escalating chest discomfort over the past three weeks. He described the pain as dull  heavy  and occurring intermittently  located on the left side of his chest  which sometimes radiates to the left arm and accompanied by shortness of breath and episodes of fatigue.  Mr. Smith is a retired postal worker  a smoker with a 40-pack-year history  and has been consuming alcohol moderately for the past 30 years. His dietary history reveals high saturated fat intake and low physical activity  which has led to his current body mass index (BMI) of 31  categorized as obese.  His past medical history is significant for Type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed five years ago  currently controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. Mr. Smith also suffers from hypertension under treatment with antihypertensive medication for the last eight years. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 59 and his mother has been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease and hypertension.  He is currently on Metformin 500 mg twice daily for diabetes and Lisinopril 10 mg once daily for hypertension. His blood pressure reading today is 148/95 mmHg  heart rate is 78 bpm  and BMI is 31 kg/m2. His last recorded HbA1c  done three months ago  was 7.1%.  The complaints  history  and presenting symptoms are indicative of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) in Mr. Smith. Due to his multiple risk factors including age  sex  race  smoking  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  diabetes  hypertension  and a family history of premature heart disease  he is at an increased risk of CAD.   Early diagnosis and management are advised to prevent severe cardiac complications. The planned approach includes a full cardiac workup - EKG  stress test  and echocardiography  and other investigations if necessary.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male from an urban area who presents with recurrent chest discomfort  interpreted as angina  lasting for about 10 minutes at a time. Episodes frequently occur during exertion but have recently started appearing during rest as well. He describes the discomfort as a pressure-like feeling  located centrally in his chest  sometimes radiating to his left arm.  He is a former smoker  having smoked one pack a day for 30 years but claims to have quit 10 years ago. He has type 2 diabetes  managed through diet and metformin  and a family history of heart disease. His father had a myocardial infarction in his sixties. He has a BMI of 32  placing him in the obese category.  He is currently retired but used to work in construction. He lives with his wife in a third-floor apartment and reports some difficulty climbing the stairs due to his current symptoms. He also reports shortness of breath upon exertion  and symptoms of fatigue  and occasional lightheadedness. His current medications include metformin for his type 2 diabetes and atorvastatin for hypercholesterolemia. He denies any drug use or alcohol overuse.  His BP on admission is 140/90 mmHg  a pulse of 85 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breath/min  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. He maintains a low level of physical activity and admits to a diet high in sodium and fat. He does not keep up with his annual check-ups citing a general distrust in physicians. His discomfort is somewhat relieved by nitroglycerin which was prescribed to him when he first started experiencing chest discomfort about a year ago. He's been using this medication more frequently in recent weeks. He came to the hospital fearing that his condition is worsening.

Chief Complaint: Chest pain and shortness of breath  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a body mass index (BMI) of 30  representing obesity. He is professionally retired and is currently residing in Northern Texas.   Medical History: The patient reveals a long-standing history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both diagnosed 20 years ago  currently managed with Metformin and Losartan respectively. He experienced a transient ischemic attack (TIA) about 1 year ago. The patient's father died at the age of 58 due to myocardial infarction.   Lifestyle Details: He reports smoking about a pack of cigarettes daily for around 40 years and patches of quit attempts in-between. His diet is high in saturated fats and has led a sedentary lifestyle since retirement. He consumes alcohol moderately  with rare binge drinking episodes during the holiday seasons.   Current Symptoms: He reports intermittent episodes of chest pain  which he describes as ""a constant  heavy sensation"" in the middle of his chest. He also reports experiencing shortness of breath  especially during minor physical activity  like walking down his driveway to collect mail. He also complains of fatigue and occasional episodes of lightheadedness.   Based on his risk factors (including age  sex  obesity  smoking history  diabetes  hypertension  family history of heart disease)  symptoms  and lifestyle habits  a preliminary diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) can be considered. Further diagnostic tests  including EKG  stress tests  and possible coronary angiography  would be useful to confirm his diagnosis and assess the extent of his disease.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Name: John Doe   Age: 66 years   Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Factory Worker  Mr. John Doe is a 66-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years with a 20 pack-year history. He admits to a relatively sedentary lifestyle with irregular exercise. Despite efforts to control his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  he reports poor compliance to his medication regime including Losartan and Atorvastatin.   His father died of myocardial infarction at 70 years old. Mr. Doe has no history of substance abuse  surgical procedures  or sexually transmitted infections.   Over the past two days  he has been experiencing intermittent chest pains  often occurring during physical exertion or emotional upset. He describes the pain as a ‘pressure’ or ‘tightness’ in his chest that sometimes radiates towards his left arm and neck. The pain typically lasts 5-10 minutes and is relieved by rest or Nitroglycerin.   He denies symptoms of shortness of breath  palpitations  dizziness  or loss of consciousness. However  he reports feeling fatigue more than usual lately. In the absence of notable fever  weight loss  or night sweats  he also reports difficulty sleeping and occasional indigestion.   On physical examination  his vital signs are: BP = 150/85 mmHg; HR = 80 bpm; RR = 16 breaths per minute; temperature = 36.9 C; and SpO2 = 95% on room air.   Based on the symptoms  familial history  age  and lifestyle habits of the patient  a presentation of coronary artery disease is suspected. Immediate management  investigation  and potential lifestyle modifications are necessary to confirm diagnosis and prevent cardiovascular events.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John is a 62-year-old African-American male presenting with a progressive 6-month history of typical anginal chest pain. Pain is classically central  pressing in nature  and occasionally radiates down the left arm; each episode lasts for minutes and most often occurs upon exertion  such as climbing a flight of stairs  but seems to be easily relieved with rest or nitroglycerin tablets.   Over the past week  Mr. John has noticed an increase in frequency of these episodes  occasionally even occurring at rest. He also reports associated shortness of breath  occasional dizziness  and transient episodes of profuse sweating accompanying pain. He denies any episodes of syncope  palpitations  or cough. He hasn't noticed any swelling in his legs  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.   Mr. John has a past medical history significant for well-controlled hypertension for the last 10 years  and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 8 years  maintained on oral hypoglycemic agents. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years  with an approximate 20 pack/year history. His diet primarily consists of fatty foods  and he has an inactive lifestyle with minimal exercise.   There's a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases: his father suffered an MI at the age of 58 and his 65-year-old brother has stable angina.   On physical examination  he is normotensive and has a body mass index (BMI) of 28. The cardiovascular system examination reveals a normal S1 and S2 with no evident murmurs or added sounds. There's no peripheral edema  and pulses are palpable bilaterally.  Given the patient’s age  sex  race  symptoms  lifestyle  and medical and familial history  he is at a high risk for coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. K. Anderson is a 65-year-old African-American male  presenting to the outpatient clinic with the chief complaint of progressive chest discomfort on exertion over the past three months. He has recently also noticed accompanying symptoms of diaphoresis  shortness of breath  and occasional lightheadedness. He reports that these symptoms resolve at rest.   He has a previous history of type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago  hypertension for 10 years  and was a smoker for 30 years until he quit 5 years ago. His medications include Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. His father had a history of myocardial infarction at age 50.  On evaluation  his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  pulse 88 beats per minute  BMI 32. His physical examination is unremarkable  His presentation  symptoms  and risk factors suggest a working diagnosis of coronary artery disease. Further diagnostics including EKG and stress testing has been scheduled to confirm this.   Note: This patient represents an appropriate demographic as per the literature on coronary artery disease (CAD). CAD is more prevalent among men  ages 45 or older  and women  ages 55 or older. African-American ethnicity  history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and family history of early heart disease are acknowledged risk factors.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Rodriguez  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of recurrent  exertional chest pain radiating to his left arm. He also reports shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional episodes of lightheadedness. He notes that his symptoms are often precipitated by physical activity and are relieved by rest or nitroglycerin tablets prescribed by a previous physician.   The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both managed with medication for the past 10 years. He was a smoker for 30 years (30 pack-years) but quit cigarette smoking three years ago upon the advice of his physician. He reports being non-compliant with his exercises and dietary plans and admits to a diet high in fats and sugars.   His paternal grandfather had a fatal myocardial infarction at 67 years of age  and his mother has severe cardiovascular disease  suggestive of a family history of coronary artery disease.   Currently  he is taking lisinopril (10mg daily) for hypertension and metformin (1gm twice daily) for diabetes. He does not report any known drug allergies. His BMI is around 29  indicating that he is overweight. He is retired and lives with his wife; he drinks alcohol socially and does not use illicit drugs.   The clinical presentation  patient's age  race  sex  as well as his lifestyle and past medical history contribute to a high index of suspicion for coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is a 63-year-old white male who presents to the clinic with recurrent chest pain over the last few weeks  typically worsened by exercise and relieved by rest. The pain is described as heavy and centrally located  often radiating to his left arm. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath and episodes of lightheadedness. No history of syncope  sweating or nausea reported.   Patient's medical history includes hypertension managed with Lisinopril  type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin  and hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin. The patient's father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. Patient admits to being a former smoker  quitting 5 years ago after a 20-year pack history. He consumes alcohol in moderation  averaging two drinks per week  and does not use any recreational drugs.  Height is 5'10''  Weight: 200lbs  with a BMI of 28.7  indicating an overweight status.  Resting blood pressure is found to be 135/85 mm/Hg  which is higher than the ideal range. From his symptoms and medical history  a potential diagnosis of coronary artery disease should be considered and further investigations such as electrocardiogram (ECG) and angiogram should be ordered. His lifestyle factors  genetic predisposition  and comorbid conditions make him a high-risk candidate for such condition.

Patient Information: Mr. Ahmed is a 60-year-old African American male  married with two children. He was born and raised in Southern California  and he is employed as a bus driver. He has been a smoker for the past 30 years and regularly consumes alcohol. He reports no known drug allergies.  Chief Complaint: He presents with complaints of ongoing chest discomfort and shortness of breath primarily occurring during physical exertion for the last 3 months. The pain is quite sharp in nature and usually lasts for five to fifteen minutes before subsiding. The pain typically radiates to his left arm.  Past Medical History: Mr. Ahmed was diagnosed with high blood pressure five years ago and Type 2 diabetes three years ago. He has been relatively complacent about following the doctor's dietary recommendations and taking his prescribed medications consistently. He also has a significant family history of heart disease  with his father having suffered from a heart attack at the age of 62. He reports no previous surgeries.  Physical Exam: On examination  Mr. Ahmed is slightly obese with a BMI of 31. His blood pressure is elevated at 160/95 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs  gallops  or rubs. Breath sounds are noted to be normal bilaterally  but the patient appears slightly short of breath even at rest.  Review of Systems: He reports fatigue  generalized body aches  and frequent headaches. He denies fevers  weight loss  night sweats. His diabetic control has been poor  with recent HbA1c measured at 9.2%. His lipids have also been high with LDL of 150 mg/dl.  Given his age  race  male sex  smoking and drinking history  family history of heart disease  personal history of hypertension and poorly controlled diabetes  sedentary lifestyle and symptoms  Mr. Ahmed is at a high risk for coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Alvarez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presents today with frequent episodes of chest pain over the last three months that appears to be worsening daily. The chest pain is constricting in nature  left-sided  radiating to the left arm  lasting for 15-25 minutes  and usually occurs with exertion such as climbing a flight of stairs.  He rates the pain as 7 out of 10 on the severity scale. The pain is relieved by resting or taking nitroglycerin tablets. He also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  unintentional weight loss  and dizziness.   Mr. Alvarez has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus managed by metformin  and hypertension controlled with amlodipine. He is a smoker with a 30 pack-year smoking history and a moderate drinker who consumes alcohol occasionally. His father died of a heart attack at age 60. He has poor dietary habits and admits to a sedentary lifestyle.  He is retired and lives with his wife in an urban area. He used to work as a construction worker and has minimal health literacy. He has no known drug allergy. He is up-to-date with his immunization.  His vitals on examination are stable: Blood pressure 145/90 mmHg  heart rate 86 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  temperature 98.6 F  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air.   On physical examination  he appeared in moderate distress. Cardiac examination reveals normal S1  S2 with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. There are no signs of heart failure. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.  Based on the symptoms  past medical history  and risk factors  my initial impression is Stable Angina due to coronary artery disease. He requires further diagnostic evaluation and management for this potential diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas Martin  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of discomfort on his left chest  which he describes as ""pressure"" lasting for a few minutes  especially after exerting himself or upon stress. He reports additional symptoms like shortness of breath  extreme fatigue  and lightheadedness that have been progressive over the last three months.  The patient is retired and used to work in a high-stress corporate job. He has a history of smoking 1 pack a day for 30 years but quit ten years ago. His diet is high in saturated fats and he admits to a sedentary lifestyle with minimal exercise.   His medical history is significant for hypertension and dyslipidemia over the last five years. He is on a regimen of antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril) and statin therapy (Atorvastatin). Past surgical history is largely unremarkable. His family history is notable with both his father and paternal uncle suffering from myocardial infarctions in their early sixties.  Mr. Martin is a widower  lives alone  and has two adult children. He has consumed alcohol socially in the past but abstains now. He denies any illicit drug use. His immunizations  including for Influenza and Pneumococcal  are up-to-date.  Physical examination reveals a overweight male (BMI: 28) with blood pressure 145/85 mmHg and a pulse of 78 bpm. Cardiovascular examination reveals normal heart sounds with no murmurs  rubs or gallops. A mild decrease in breath sounds is observed in both lung bases. Chest exam shows no tenderness or deformities. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A lipid panel is ordered as a follow up.  His symptoms  associated risk factors and family history point towards the possibility of coronary artery disease. EKG  stress test  and further cardiac evaluation is planned.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of recurrent and increasingly severe chest pain over the past few months. The pain is often precipitated by physical activity  such as walking up a flight of stairs  and it typically subsides with rest. The patient describes the pain as a heaviness in his chest  often radiating to his left arm.   The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension  diagnosed ten years ago  which is being managed on lisinopril 20mg daily. The patient also has a 35-year history of smoking  although he quit two weeks ago; and a family history of early coronary artery disease (father had a myocardial infarction at age 59). The patient does not have a history of diabetes or dyslipidemia.  The patient is a retired high school teacher living with his wife. He admits to being sedentary for the past five years since his retirement. Also  he admits to adhering to a diet high in saturated fats  cholesterol  and sodium. He denies any alcohol or illicit substance use.  The patient is currently on no other medication except lisinopril and reports no known allergies. His immunization records are up-to-date  with no records of recent illness or infection. There's no recent travel or contact with a sick person noted.   On examination  his blood pressure is on the higher end of normal at 138/90 mm Hg  heart rate is 78 beats per minute  and his body mass index is 29.2 kg/m2  denoting overweight.  A possible diagnosis of coronary artery disease has been considered given his age  gender  clinical presentation  extensive smoking history  family history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension  and lifestyle. Patient has been referred for further investigations including an ECG  echocardiogram  and stress test.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male retired college professor  who presents to the clinic today with complaints of episodic chest discomfort over the past two weeks. The discomfort is described as a pressure-like sensation  located centrally  which often radiates to the left arm.  The pain typically arises after exerting himself  such as by walking uphill or carrying groceries  and will subside after a few minutes of rest. He has also noticed associated shortness of breath and fatigue during these episodes. He denies experiencing diaphoresis  nausea  vomiting  palpitations during these episodes of chest discomfort.   He has never experienced symptoms like this before. He does not note any relation to meals  does not wake him up from sleep  and is not reproducible with movement or palpation.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with amlodipine 5mg and atorvastatin 20mg daily respectively. His hypertension is well-controlled. His recent lipid profile was elevated with an LDL of 170 mg/dL.  Mr. Smith has never smoked and consumes alcohol occasionally  a glass or two of wine during social gatherings. His diet includes high sodium and high fatty food mostly. He reports jogging lightly 2-3 times per week. His father died at 70 due to myocardial infarction and his mother at 85 due to congestive heart failure. He is married and resides with his wife and dog.       This clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic stable angina secondary to coronary artery disease  given the reproducible symptoms with exertion  his age  sex  and associated risk factors like hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Tom Smith  a 62-year old African American male  presents to your office with a two week history of intermittent chest pain that radiates to his left arm. The pain seems to get worse with physical activity and dissipates with rest. He is a retired accountant  currently living with his wife  and has a history of smoking cigarettes for the past 40 years. He quit two years ago.   He admits to having dyspnea on exertion and occasional episodes of diaphoresis with his chest pain that lasts up to 5-10 minutes at a time before fading away. His appetite and sleep are normal  but he reports occasional nausea during his chest pain episodes. He denies any palpitations  syncope  edema  or recent weight changes.   In his past medical history  he has been treated for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  which are under control with amlodipine and metformin  respectively. He has a family history of early cardiovascular disease as his father had suffered from a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  His physical examination revealed evidence of slight obesity with a BMI of 30 kg/m². His blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg and the cardiovascular examination was consistent with a regular heart rhythm  and there were no audible murmurs or gallops. His chest was clear  and no lower limb edema was noted. His ECG revealed T wave inversions in the inferior and anterolateral leads.   Given that Mr. Smith is a older male patient with multiple major risk factors for coronary artery disease  including smoking history  hypertension  diabetes  family history  and high BMI  his symptoms suggest that he may have coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 56-year-old Hispanic male presenting to the clinic today complaining of a 2-month history of exertional chest pain. The pain is described as dull  located in the left side of his chest  and radiates to his left arm. It improves with rest and has become progressively worse over the past week. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath  sweating  and fatigue.   He has a past medical history of hypertension diagnosed 6 years ago and Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago  for both of which he takes home medications. He also has a significant family history of heart disease  with his father having passed away from a heart attack at age 60. The patient is a former smoker with a 20 pack-year history but quit 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use. He works as a construction worker and admits to having a sedentary lifestyle when not at work.  He had his last lipid panel 1 year ago with his primary physician  and at that time  his total cholesterol was 230 mg/dL  triglycerides were 180 mg/dL  and he had a low-density lipoprotein cholesterol level of 160 mg/dL. His body mass index (BMI) is 28 kg/m2. Blood pressure during today’s visit was 140/90 mmHg  with a resting heart rate of 75 beats per minute. Chronic management of his diabetes and hypertension has been inconsistent due to his lack of health-seeking behavior unless symptomatic.  These findings suggest a high risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) given his clinical presentation  risk factors including his diabetes  hypertension  high cholesterol  obesity  family history; moreover  he is in a key demographic as CAD incidence is highest in men over 45 – particularly those of Hispanic ethnicity.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Prescott  a 65-year-old African American male  comes in complaining of intermittent chest discomfort and shortness of breath predominantly on exertion for the past three months. His symptoms have become more frequent and severe over the last two weeks  also he reported an episode of rest angina a week earlier.  He has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both managed with medications. He is otherwise normally active with reasonable exercise tolerance. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He currently works as a truck driver and admits to a diet heavy in fast food. There's a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father experiencing a myocardial infarction in his 60s.   On examination  he is overweight with a BMI of 30  and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Cardiovascular examination reveals no abnormalities; the lungs are clear  and the rest of the physical exam is unremarkable. EKG in the office showed nonspecific changes but no acute ischemic signs. Given the symptoms and risk factors  the clinical suspicion for coronary artery disease is high.

Patient Information: Mr. J.S. is a 67-year-old African American male retired engineer complaining of recurrent chest pain usually triggered by exertion and relieved by rest.  Chief Complaint: Chest Pain   History of Present Illness: The patient reports that he has been experiencing chest pain radiating to the left arm over the past six months. The pain is typically reported as a heavy sensation on his chest lasting for 10-15 minutes  improving with rest or two nitroglycerin tabs. Recently  the frequency and intensity of episodes have increased and are occurring with less exertion than before.  Medical History: Long-standing history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He is a former smoker  with a pack history of 25 years but quit tobacco use 10 years ago. His father died of a heart attack in his early sixties. Regular medication includes Metformin  ACE inhibitor  and Nitroglycerin as needed for angina attacks.  Review of Systems: Besides chest pain  J.S. has also noticed limited exercise tolerance and shortness of breath on exertion. No reports of palpitations  indigestion  dizziness or fainting. He has noticed some swelling in the legs by the end of the day.  Physical Examination: Although vital signs are reported stable  a cardiovascular examination reveals a Grade II systolic murmur best heard at the apex  bilateral lower extremity pitting edema up to the ankles  and the absence of carotid bruits.  Habits and Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle. Reports occasional alcohol use.  Family History: Father died of a myocardial infarction in his 60s  mother had a stroke in her 70s. He has one sister who is alive and well.
