Allergies: None  This presentation fits a typical patient with coronary artery disease given his age  sex  ethnicity and risk factors - hypertension  diabetes mellitus  family history  and past history of smoking.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Richard Thompson  a 64-year-old African-American male presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of recurrent chest pain  especially during physical exertion that usually resolves with rest. He reports the pain to be pressure-like  being located in the center of the chest  and occasionally radiating to his left arm. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath  fatigue and occasional lightheadedness.   He has a past medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  for which he takes Metformin and Lisinopril respectively. His father had a history of a heart attack in his early 60s. He is a 20-year pack smoker but quit about 18 months ago. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in fats and processed foods. He drinks alcohol occasionally.  He is currently retired  previously working in construction. He is married with three adult children and lives with his wife. They are of lower-middle-class socioeconomic status  with limited access to health services in their rural community.   On examination  his blood pressure is found to be 145/95 mmHg and BMI is 31 kg/m2. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed T-wave inversions in the anterior leads consistent with possible ischemia. The patient has been scheduled for further cardiovascular examination  including an exercise stress test and possible coronary angiography to assess for suspected coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Mohammad Ali  a 65-year-old Asian man  presents to the clinic today reporting symptoms of ongoing chest pain  shortness of breath  and fatigue. The chest pain seems to get worse with exertion and decreases with rest. He also reports episodes of nausea and excessive sweating during these episodes of chest discomfort. Mr. Ali has a past medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He is a former smoker and quit smoking about 10 years ago after a 40-pack year history. His BMI is 29  falling into the category of overweight.   Family history reveals that his father passed away in his early 70s due to a heart attack and his mother had a stroke in her late 60s. He does not engage in regular physical activity and follows a diet high in saturated fats and low in fruits and vegetables.   Mr. Ali is currently on Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. He was previously employed as a bus driver but is currently retired. His life at home is moderately stressful due to financial struggles and caregiving responsibilities for his wife who has Parkinson's disease.   In summary  this is a 65-year-old Asian male with significant risk factors for coronary artery disease including advanced age  male sex  hypertension  diabetes mellitus  a history of smoking  and strong family history. His lifestyle of poor diet and lack of exercise exacerbate the potential for cardiac problems. His symptoms of chest pain  particularly on exertion  along with shortness of breath and other associated symptoms  raise concerns about possible coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Albert Wilson  a 67-year-old African-American male  presents to the clinic with complaints of chest discomfort and shortness of breath upon exertion  which has been gradually increasing over the past few months. The chest discomfort is typically relieved by rest. He also reports episodes of lightheadedness  but no fainting spells or palpitations.   His past medical history is significant for poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago  hypertension which is currently managed with Lisinopril  and dyslipidemia for which he takes Atorvastatin. He quit smoking two years ago after a 40-year history of 1 pack a day smoking but continues to consume alcohol occasionally.   He lives with his wife  is retired from his job as a warehouse manager  has a diet that is high in animal fats and sodium  and has a sedentary lifestyle. His family history reveals that his older brother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55.  Based on this presentation  a history of risk factors  demographics  and symptoms  Mr. Wilson is likely suffering from Coronary Artery Disease.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Rodriguez  a 62-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the office complaining of chest discomfort and shortness of breath especially while walking or climbing stairs. He describes the discomfort as a sensation of pressure radiating to his jaw  which abates upon resting. He also states that he feels fatigued more easily than before. The patient has a 30-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension which are managed with Metformin  Lisinopril  and Hydrochlorothiazide. He does not follow any diet or exercise regimen and has been a smoker for 20 years  with a 20-pack year smoking history. He drinks alcohol socially.  Recent checks indicate a body mass index (BMI) of 30.1  indicating obesity. There have not been any major surgeries in the past. He has a family history of heart disease with his father having died from myocardial infarction at the age of 60. Despite no prior formal diagnosis of heart disease  his presenting symptoms and the existing chronic comorbid conditions  coupled with his lifestyle  suggest a possible diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD). He reported no allergies.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old African-American male presents at the clinic with recent episodes of chest discomfort over the past three weeks. The patient describes these episodes as a pressure-like sensation in the chest which worsens with exertion and generally subsides with rest. He also admits to experiencing shortness of breath  fatigue  and light-headedness following mild physical activities. His symptoms appear to be progressively worsening.  The patient is an accountant by profession and has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he takes Metformin daily. He reports a sedentary lifestyle with occasional alcohol intake and is an ex-smoker  having quit smoking 15 years ago after a 20-year history of tobacco use.   There is a family history of cardiovascular disease  as his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. The patient admits to neglecting regular medical check-ups and has been non-compliant with a previously recommended diabetic diet and exercise routine.   He is presently overweight (BMI 29) and his vital signs on arrival were blood pressure at 155/95 mmHg  pulse at 88 bpm  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute.   The noted presentation essentially fits within the typical demographic representation of coronary artery disease  predominantly affecting men over 60 years with a significant link to African-American ethnicity  diabetes  hypertension  and smoking history.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Sutton is a 65-year-old Caucasian male residing in an urban area of Ohio. He presents to the physician’s office complaining of a recurrent central chest pain radiating down his left arm for the last three months. The pain is exertional and relieved by rest. However  during the past week  the pain has increased in frequency and intensity.  Mr. Sutton is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago but had a pack/day smoking history for 30 years. He is retired and used to work as an attorney. He has a sedentary lifestyle and a diet rich in saturated fats. His father suffered a heart attack in his 60s.   His past medical history includes obesity  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are treated with metformin and a daily antihypertensive medication.  On examination  his BMI is calculated to be 32 indicative of obesity. His blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg. Furthermore  his lipid profile reveals elevated cholesterol levels. ECG is suggestive of possible ischemic changes.   Given the presentation and personal and familial history  there is a high suspicion of stable angina due to coronary artery disease. Mr. Sutton will be referred for further cardiac testing.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Brown  a 62 years old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of chest pain and shortness of breath  particularly upon exertion  for the past three months. The chest pain describes as crushing type and radiates to his left arm. Patient reports occasional episodes of nausea and cold sweats along with it.  Demographics:   Mr. Brown currently lives in the Midwest United States  specifically in Milwaukee  Wisconsin. He is a retiree  previously employed as an industrial supervisor. He is married with two grown children. He is a smoker and has a 20-pack year history of smoking. He admits to rarely exercising and adheres to a diet high in red meat and processed food.  Past Medical History:   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  diagnosed five years ago and is currently on medication (Amlodipine for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia). He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having had a myocardial infarction at age 55. He also reports being moderately obese with a Body Mass Index (BMI) 30 kg/m2.  Given the patient's age  sex  smoking history  lack of physical activity  unhealthy diet  and family history  he corresponds well to the demographic of a typical patient with coronary artery disease as represented in prevalent clinical study data.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Selvam  a 65-year-old Asian-Indian man  presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent chest pain for the past two months. The patient describes the chest pain as a heavy  squeezing sensation located in the mid-sternal area that radiates to his left arm and lasts about 10 to 15 minutes. The pain was initially induced by heavy physical activity but is now also occurring at rest. Given these symptoms  the patient is experiencing a decreased interest in performing his daily activities  such as gardening  citing shortness of breath and fatigue.  The patient is a retired engineer  married with two adult children  and lives with his wife. He has lived in the United States since he was 30 years-old. He has a 15-pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He admits he doesn’t exercise much and follows a typical Indian diet that is rich in fats and carbohydrates.  His medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Both conditions were diagnosed eight years ago and are managed with medications: Losartan 50 mg/day for hypertension and metformin 1000 mg twice a day for diabetes. Despite compliance with medications  blood sugar levels and blood pressure have been persistently elevated in recent clinic visits.  Family history is significant for heart disease. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 52 and his elder sister was recently diagnosed with angina.  Article sources have stated that South Asians  particularly Asian Indians  have a higher prevalence of coronary artery diseases. Other risk factors like age  gender  smoking history  sedentary lifestyle  poor dietary habits  hypertension  diabetes  and family history present in Mr. Selvam further increase his risk for coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 67-year-old African American male who presents to the clinic with progressive  exertional chest discomfort over the last several months. He describes the pain as a pressure sensation  located in the central chest  which radiates to the left arm. The pain typically lasts for 10-15 minutes and improves with rest. He also reports associated shortness of breath.   Smith reports a past medical history significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus  for which he currently takes lisinopril and metformin respectively. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history but has quit 5 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and has a diet high in high-fat  high-sodium foods.  His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 55 and his mother was diagnosed with stroke at the age of 68. His elder brother  aged 70  is also diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Smith leads a sedentary lifestyle with minimal daily exercise. He is currently retired and states that he has been feeling a significant amount of stress due to financial concerns which is also leading to occasional insomnia.   He also reports a history of erectile dysfunction for the past couple years.   In summary  Smith is an elderly  African-American male presenting with typical angina  and multiple risk factors for Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) including older age  male gender  hypertension  diabetes  smoking history  familial history of early CAD  unhealthy diet  psychosocial stressors  erectile dysfunction  and physical inactivity.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Joe Davis  a 60-year-old African American male patient  presented himself in the clinic today. He is retired and lives with his wife and two adult children with no history of substance abuse. He complains of recurrent chest pain for the past few months  which he describes as a heaviness or pressure in his chest. Mr. Davis mentions the episodes are often triggered by physical exertion and are often relieved by rest. Recently  he has also noticed shortness of breath during these episodes  accompanied by fatigue and occasional dizziness. It's worth noting he also reports having intermittent episodes of heartburn but antacids seem to provide little relief.  His past medical history shows a diagnosis of hypertension which has been poorly controlled over the past few years  and Type 2 diabetes that was diagnosed 5 years ago. He also has a history of hypercholesterolemia and was prescribed statin therapy but has been inconsistent in taking the medication over the last year. Additionally  he reports a 20 pack year history of smoking  though his last cigarette was approximately a year ago. There's also a relevant family history of Coronary Artery Disease with his father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65.  His current medications include Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for cholesterol. No known drug allergies are reported. On general physical exam  he appears slightly overweight with a BMI of 28 and blood pressure reading high at 150/90 mmHg. He denies any illicit drug use and alcohol consumption. The patient conveys concern about his symptoms and is keen to know what could be wrong.  Based on the patient’s presentation and his risk factors including his age  race  medical history of untreated hypertension and high cholesterol  poorly controlled diabetes  previous smoking habits  overweight status  family history  and the fact that his symptoms are relieved by the rest  a differential diagnosis directed towards coronary artery disease (CAD) (Angina Pectoris) might be reasonable.

Patient Profile: Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Demographics: He is a retired engineer  lives in a suburban area in Seattle  Washington with his wife. They have two adult children who don't live with them. He is a non-smoker but admits to having a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in red meat  processed foods and salt. Mr. Smith holds a private insurance coverage.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith presents to the clinic with complaints of chest pain  especially after exerting himself or after a heavy meal. He describes his pain as a feeling of uncomfortable pressure  fullness  and squeezing in the center of his chest  lasting for more than a few minutes. He also mentions occasional shortness of breath and fatigue after minimal physical effort.  Past Medical History: His medical records reveal a diagnosis of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he was prescribed antihypertensive drugs and statins two years ago. However  he admits that his compliance with these medications has been poor over the last few months. His father suffered from a heart attack in his early sixties and both his elder brother and sister have a history of heart disease. He has never been diagnosed with diabetes  but his BMI indicates obesity.  Social History: Mr. Smith was a heavy smoker in his 30s but successfully quit 20 years ago. He admits to having 2-3 alcoholic beverages per night. He reports being sedentary for most of the day and does not participate in any regular physical activity. He experiences moderate levels of stress.  Given this demographic information  the multiple risk factors for the development of coronary artery disease (CAD) - including his age  male sex  family history of early heart disease  hypertension  high cholesterol levels  lack of exercise  poor diet  and stress – and his clinical presentation  a thorough cardiac evaluation is warranted for Mr. Smith. The physician should also emphasize the importance of medication adherence  lifestyle modifications  and regular health check-ups to slow the progression of his condition and prevent serious cardiac episodes such as a heart attack.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 65-year-old Hispanic male who presents today with complaints of recurrent chest pain that seems to radiate to his left arm and neck. He describes the pain as “crushing"" and reports that it often appears when he is physically active and can last for over 10 minutes. Episodes typically resolve with rest. Recently  he has also noticed that shortness of breath accompanies the chest pain. He denies symptoms of nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis.   His past medical history is significant with hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which have been managed with medications for the past 10 years. He has also been a smoker for the last 40 years with multiple failed quit attempts. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. He is retired and lives with his wife who is concerned about his recent health. He follows a typical Western diet  admitting to regularly consuming highly processed and fast food. He has not engaged in regular physical activity for many years due to his lifestyle and job constraints. He has no known drug allergies.   His blood pressure at today's visit was 150/90  and his Body Mass Index (BMI) is calculated to be 32  indicating obesity. An electrocardiogram (EKG) was ordered and shows possible ischemic changes.   Based upon his age  sex  ethnicity  history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  familial history of heart disease  obesity  lack of physical exercise  unhealthy diet  and current symptoms  the preliminary diagnosis is Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). An immediate referral to a cardiologist for further investigations using stress testing and angiography scan is planned.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 62-year-old African American male in town on a business trip. He presented to the emergency department complaining of on-and-off central chest heaviness and shortness of breath for the last 11 hours  which was atypical from his usual exertional dyspnea. He describes the chest pain as a ""crushing"" sensation that occasionally radiates to his left arm. The discomfort is exacerbated with activity and alleviated with rest. Associated symptoms included diaphoresis and nausea. The patient denied any symptoms of palpitations  dizziness  or fainting.  Mr. Smith has a past medical history of hypertension for 20 years and type 2 diabetes diagnosed 12 years ago. His medications include metformin  amlodipine  and atorvastatin. The patient also admitted to a 35 pack-year history of smoking but quit about 3 years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol  with an average of one drink per day. He has a family history of heart disease  with his father dying from myocardial infarction at the age of 68.  Upon physical exam  his blood pressure was 145/90 mmHg and pulse rate of 105 beats per minute. His body mass index is 28.9 kg/m^2  suggesting overweight. He appeared anxious; there were no signs of heart failure.  These findings heightened suspicion for angina or an acute coronary syndrome. Immediate diagnostics  including an EKG and cardiac enzyme tests  were ordered  along with medication to relieve his symptoms.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Joseph Martinez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic today with a chief complaint of progressive exertional chest pain for the past few months. The pain is described as a sensation of pressure and tightness in the chest  radiating to his left arm. It is often associated with shortness of breath  and is brought on by activity and relieved by rest. He also reports a recent onset of fatigue  especially during physical activity  and occasional dizziness.   Mr. Martinez has a past medical history significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  all of which have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history  although he quit smoking five years ago. His father had suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 55 and passed away due to subsequent complications.   He does not exercise regularly and his diet is high in saturated fats and cholesterol. For his medications  Mr. Martinez takes Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for his high cholesterol. He is adherent to his medications but struggles with lifestyle modifications. He denies any alcohol or recreational drug use.  On examination  Mr. Martinez is overweight with a BMI of 31  and his blood pressure today is 145/90. His heart sounds are normal with no murmurs  but the rhythm is slightly irregular. His arteries are palpably thickened and stiff.   Based on the patient's symptomatology  strong family history  and risk factors (hypertension  dyslipidemia  type 2 diabetes  former smoker  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and age)  he is highly suspected for coronary artery disease and will be referred accordingly for appropriate investigations.

Patient Presentation   A 64-year-old African American male presents to the clinic complaining of recurrent chest discomfort over the past several weeks. The pain  described as a heavy pressure sensation in the middle of his chest  often arises during exercise or times of emotional stress and is relieved within minutes by rest. Occasionally  the chest discomfort is accompanied by discomfort in his left arm and mild shortness of breath. The pain has not occurred at rest  nor did it wake the patient from sleep.  No associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting  palpitations  or fainting are reported. The patient admits to smoking approximately 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years  states his diet is high in carbohydrates and fats and admits to having a sedentary lifestyle with minimal exercise due to his job as a truck driver.   Family history reveals his father died of a heart attack at the age of 55. The patient has been treated for high blood pressure for the past 10 years and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 5 years ago.   Overall  the patient presentation and past medical history points to classical angina symptoms associated with coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thompson is a 58-year-old African American male  an accountant  who presents in the clinic with a six-month history of intermittent chest pain. The pain is typically located in the left anterior chest and radiates to the left arm and neck. He describes it as a heavy  squeezing sensation that lasts around 15 minutes. It typically occurs when he is walking or under stress  but it subsides when he rests or takes nitroglycerine.   In the past month  he has noticed the episodes of chest pain have become more frequent and severe  triggering with less exertion. Over the past week  he began to experience this pain at rest at night. Each episode of pain is accompanied by shortness of breath and a cold sweat. He has no history of lightheadedness or loss of consciousness.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he is taking hydrochlorothiazide prescribed by his primary healthcare provider. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He claims to engage in minimal physical activity due to his job's demands. His diet is rich in saturated fats and cholesterol.  His father suffered a heart attack at the age of 62. His body mass index (BMI) is 29 kg/m2.  This presentation is consistent with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) with unstable angina.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old African American male presents to the clinic complaining of chest pain for the last three days. The pain is described as pressure-like  radiating to the left arm and jaw  worsens with exertion and is relieved with rest. The patient also reported episodes of shortness of breath  especially during physical activities. He denies any sensation of palpitations  syncope  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.  Demographics:   The patient lives in an urban environment with his wife. He is a retired construction worker with a history of smoking  approximately one pack per day for 40 years  but quit 5 years ago. He admits to consuming alcohol occasionally.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Both conditions are under control with medical therapy (Metoprolol for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes). He is not on any statins.   Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in his father  who passed away at the age of 62. His mother has a history of hypertension. The patient's BMI is 30 kg/m2 and he reports that his diet is generally high in fat and low in fiber. He also states that he doesn't engage in regular physical activity.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Baker  a 63-year-old African American male with a BMI of 30.5  presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of chest discomfort and shortness of breath  especially on exertion for the past 2 months. The chest discomfort is in the mid-sternal area and described as a pressure-like feeling  which occasionally radiates to the left arm. The symptoms are triggered with moderate to heavy physical activity and relieved by rest. He also states that he has had episodes of dizziness but no syncope.   He has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus that is controlled with metformin. He also reports hypertension  for which he takes lisinopril. He is a former smoker  having stopped 20 years ago after a 15-pack year history. His father passed away after suffering a heart attack at the age of 56 and his older brother had a bypass surgery at 60 years of age.   He works as a school bus driver and admits he does not exercise regularly as per the recommended guidelines. His diet mostly comprises high carbohydrate meals and he acknowledges his struggles with weight management. He stays with his wife and two adult children  who are supportive and very concerned about his health. Mr. Baker admits he is worried his conditions may cost him his job which he needs to manage his home payments and family expenses.  On examination  his vital signs show a BP of 145/95 mmHg  a pulse rate of 85 bpm  and his physical examination is notable for mild overweight  but no acute distress. The cardiovascular exam reveals regular rate and rhythm  with no murmurs. His lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. His pulses are equal and symmetrical in all limbs. However  his ankle-brachial index is on the lower side  indicating possible peripheral artery disease.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John White is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the cardiology outpatient clinic with recurrent episodes of retrosternal chest pain that radiates to his left arm. The pain typically occurs with exertion such as climbing stairs or carrying groceries  and it is usually relieved by rest or taking sublingual nitroglycerin. He reports a significant weight gain over the past year  and he has an increased shortness of breath with mild exertion. He's experienced these symptoms intermittently over the last two months but he reports a recent increase in frequency - from once or twice a week to almost daily.  Mr. White's past medical history is significant for hypertension  which was diagnosed 10 years ago and has been managed with amlodipine  and hypercholesterolemia that has been managed with atorvastatin for the past decade. He also suffers from Type-II diabetes diagnosed five years ago  managed with oral metformin. Mr. White admits he has a 30-pack year smoking history  but he quit smoking about 10 years ago.  Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  where his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58 years. With regards to social history  Mr. White is a retired engineer  lives with his wife  consumes moderate alcohol on weekends and he has a diet fairly rich in saturated fats.  On physical examination  he is overweight with a BMI of 31 kg/m². His vital signs are as follows: BP 145/90 mmHg  heart rate 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs  rubs or gallops.  Based on his presenting symptoms  demographic details  past medical history  and significant risk factors (age  gender  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  diabetes  obesity  positive family history  smoking history and poor diet)  the preliminary diagnosis is Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Further diagnostic tests such as an EKG  stress test or coronary angiography may be necessary.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Carter is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the clinic today with complaints of progressive exertional chest pain that tends to radiate to his left arm  associated with shortness of breath for the last three months. He describes his chest pain as a heavy sensation and tends to experience it more frequently during physical activity and emotional stress  but it typically resolves with rest. The pain is not accompanied by palpitations  dizziness  or fainting. He denies having any swelling in his feet  weight gain  or abdominal pain.   Mr. Carter has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His blood pressure readings have generally been within 130-150/85-95 mmHg during regular visits. His HbA1c  checked six months ago  was 7.2%. His father had a history of an acute myocardial infarction at the age of 57.   He has been living with his wife after his retirement from the armed forces. He admits he has been smoking about one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 35 years. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies the use of any illicit drugs. His diet mainly consists of high-fat foods  and he admits irregular exercise.   He is currently on metformin for his diabetes  lisinopril for his hypertension  and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He has no known drug allergies. His immunizations are up-to-date.  On systems review  Mr. Carter denies any changes in his vision  hearing  bowel habits  urinary changes or loss of consciousness. He has a negative review of systems for headaches  changes in speech  difficulty swallowing  and falls. He denies any recent illnesses or fever.  On examination  his blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg with BMI of 29. His cardiopulmonary examination reveals no murmur  gallop or rubs. His chest is clear to auscultation bilaterally. Peripheral pulses are symmetrical in all four extremities; no pitting edema is noted. Rest of his examination is within normal limits.  The above history and examination are suggestive of stable angina; however  further diagnostic tests are needed to confirm the diagnosis and extent of coronary artery disease.

Subject: Mr. Carlos Rodriguez Age: 52 Gender: Male Race: Hispanic Occupation: Factory Worker Location: El Paso  Texas  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Rodriguez has come in presenting with an increasing amount of chest discomfort over the past few weeks. The discomfort mainly occurs during exertion and subsides with rest. He also complains of occasional episodes of breathlessness  particularly during his morning walk.  Medical History:  - Hypertension for 5 years  currently taking Lisinopril. - High cholesterol  currently prescribed Atorvastatin for the past 4 years. - Diabetes mellitus type 2 for the past 7 years  managed with Metformin. - Smoker for the past 20 years  approximately one pack daily.  Family History: Both father and elder brother had heart attacks in their 60s.  Social History: Mr. Rodriguez is a married father of two children. He drinks alcohol occasionally  having about 2-3 drinks per week. His diet typically includes high salt and fat content. He has a sedentary lifestyle due to the nature of his job and lack of regular exercise apart from brief morning walks. He admits non-adherence to his medications at times due to work schedule.  Reviewed Systems: Patient denies palpitations  syncope  or nocturnal dyspnoea. He mentions feeling fatigued more often lately. There's been a decline in his exercise tolerance compared to few months ago.  Vital Signs: BP 145/90 mmHg  Pulse rate 88bpm  Respiration rate 18 breaths per minute  BMI 30 (Obese).   Summary: Mr. Rodriguez is a 52-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  presenting with angina symptoms  indicative of possible coronary artery disease. His lifestyle and non-adherence to medications increase his risk for the advance of the disease. His family history of heart disease also puts him at further risk.

Patient Presentation:  John Doe is a 68-year-old African American male  presenting to the clinic with complaints of intermittent chest pain upon exertion over the last two months. The pain is described as a squeezing sensation accompanied by shortness of breath  discomfort in his left arm  and occasional sweating.   Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which was diagnosed 10 years ago and is currently well-controlled with Lisinopril. He has a 35-year history of smoking  packs a day  however he quit 5 years ago. His father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at age 65 and mother had a history of type 2 diabetes.  Mr. Doe also reports a significant reduction in his customary activities  including climbing stairs and walking due to the fear of chest pain. These symptoms are suggestive of chronic stable angina.  He was noncompliant with a prescribed low-salt  low-fat diet for his hypertension  and he has not initiated any regular exercise plan. Mr. Doe's BMI is 30. He admits to occasional alcohol consumption but denies recreational drug use.  The patient’s history of smoking  African American ethnicity  age  male sex  family history of heart disease  sedentary lifestyle  and noncompliance with anti-hypertensive diet place him at high-risk category for Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). The patient is currently not on any anti-platelet medication. A lipid panel  stress test and possible cardiac catheterization should be considered for further evaluation and risk stratification. A more aggressive management of his hypertension and life-style changes will be crucial for this patient.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Smith  a 68-year-old African-American male  presents to the clinic with intermittent chest pains for the past two weeks. The pain in his chest is usually triggered by physical activity and emotional stress and is alleviated by rest. Occasionally  he reports shortness of breath with minimal exertion. He admits to smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 45 years. His diet includes fast food frequently. He is unemployed and lives with his wife in low socioeconomic conditions.  Past medical history reveals that Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus approximately 10 years ago for which he takes Metformin and Lisinopril  but admits to sometimes forgetting his medication. Despite being advised to initiate lifestyle modifications  he states that changing his diet and managing stress properly has proven quite challenging  partly because of his living conditions. He also reveals a family history of heart disease; his father died of a heart attack at the age of 60.  On examination  his blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg and BMI is 32 kg/m^2  both of which are above the normal range. From these facts  it is to be suspected that Mr. Smith may potentially be presenting with symptoms of coronary artery disease. He will be advised to undergo immediate further diagnostic testing like EKG  and potentially angiogram to confirm the diagnosis and determine further treatment options.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American woman presenting with a six-month history of intermittent chest pain. The pain often radiates to her left arm  and is exacerbated by exertion but relieved by rest. Recently  the frequency of pain seems to have increased  occasionally awakening her from sleep. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  fatigue  mild dizziness  and occasional bouts of feeling faint.  She has a past medical history of hypertension controlled with medication for the past 15 years  type-2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin for 10 years  and hyperlipidemia managed with statins. Connection to her current symptoms has not been definitively established.   Mrs. Johnson admits to being a former smoker  having quit five years ago  but she acknowledges a strong family history of heart disease. Her father and brother both died from myocardial infarction in their 60s. Furthermore  she states that she leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle  with difficulty incorporating exercise due to knee arthritis.  The patient lives alone  she's retired  previously working as a middle school teacher. She admits she often skips meals and relies on quick take-out or pre-prepared meals due to mobility and time constraints. Mrs. Johnson has not experienced weight loss  fever  cough  or changes to bowel habits. She consumes alcohol moderately  a glass of wine three to four times in a week.  In conclusion  Mrs. Johnson fits the typical demographic profile and clinical picture of a patient with coronary artery disease as per current literature. Her risk factors include advanced age  African American ethnicity  female sex  genetics  hypertension  diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  previous smoking history  sedentary lifestyle  and poor diet. Her symptoms of exertional pain relieved by rest are suggestive of chronic stable angina  likely due to the underlying progression of coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian female presenting with complaints of chest discomfort and intermittent shortness of breath for the past few weeks. She has been experiencing these symptoms predominantly when walking uphill or climbing stairs  but they tend to resolve with rest. She has also noticed increased fatigue and occasional lightheadedness during these episodes.   Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she is on Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. Both conditions are well controlled. She has a 40 pack year smoking history  but had given up smoking about 10 years ago. There is a family history of heart disease. Both her father and older brother had heart attacks in their early 60s.   She lives alone  maintains her house independently  and her adult children check in on her regularly. She has never consumed excessive alcohol and does not engage in illicit drug use. She admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in red meat and saturated fats. She has seen a local cardiac rehab service which runs twice a week but struggled to attend because of transport issues.  Over the counter medications include low-dose aspirin  which she started on her own about a month ago when the chest discomfort presented more frequently. No know drug allergies exist and her immunizations are up to date.  She had regular contact with her primary care provider up until the COVID-19 pandemic but has not attended regular appointments since in-person appointments were reduced. She has not had any regular cardiac screening and has never been diagnosed with cardiovascular disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Gomez is a 64-year-old Hispanic male  presenting with a two-month history of intermittent chest pain. The pain is often localized in the central chest area  feels like pressure or tightness  and commonly radiates to his left arm. The pain is precipitated mainly with physical activities and relieved by rest.  Mr. Gomez has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which has been intermittently controlled for the past 10 years. He also has Hypertension  managed with lisinopril  for the past 15 years. He was diagnosed with Hyperlipidemia seven years ago  for which he takes atorvastatin. He reports a 30 pack-year history of smoking  but quit five years ago.   Mr. Gomez’s paternal grandfather suffered a fatal myocardial infarction at 68  and his father had a history of angina. His family history also reveals a prevalence of Type II Diabetes on his mother's side. He consumes alcohol occasionally  two to three bottle beers on weekends.  Given his history and presentation  there is a high suspicion for Coronary Artery Disease.

Patient Presentation  Patient Name: John Smith Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  John Smith presents to the clinic complaining of a feeling of pressure and heaviness in his chest  particularly during exercise or when physically active. The symptoms often last for a few minutes and are relieved by rest. He also mentioned shortness of breath and occasional episodes of feeling lightheaded. He has no complaints of pain  but is worried about the chest discomfort and breathlessness.  Mr. Smith’s past medical history includes management for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years. He is a 45 pack-year smoker but quit smoking 5 years ago. His father had a myocardial infarction in his late 50s. Mr. Smith does not engage in regular physical activity; his job involves long hours of sitting. His diet is predominantly high in sodium and saturated fats. He doesn't have any known allergies.  On examination  Mr. Smith is obese with a BMI of 32. His blood pressure measures 145/95mmHg. His heart rate and rhythm are regular  but there is a soft systolic ejection murmur.  Given these findings  Mr. Smith falls into the high-risk category for coronary artery disease due to his age  gender  past history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and strong family history.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old African American man who presents to the clinic with a complaint of progressive exertional chest pain for the past three months. The chest pain is centrally located  described as a heavy pressure  occurring primarily with physical activity and relieved by rest. Over the last week  he has noticed the pain occurring more frequently and with less exertion. He reports having episodes of diaphoresis and shortness of breath accompanying the chest pain.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been on medication for these conditions including amlodipine 5mg daily and atorvastatin 40mg daily  but his adherence to medication and regular follow-ups have been sporadic due to lack of health insurance. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He does not engage in regular physical activity due to being retired and living a sedentary lifestyle. His family history is notable for his father who had a myocardial infarction in his early 60s.   Mr. Johnson lives alone and admits he doesn't have a healthy diet  often resorting to fast food. He does not drink alcohol but has a history of heavy alcohol consumption in the past. Upon physical examination  his blood pressure is found to be 150/90 mm Hg  pulse 78 bpm  respirations 16 per minute  and BMI 30 indicating obesity. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable. He is alert and oriented  and in moderate distress due to pain.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of worsening  exertional substernal chest discomfort over the past 2 months. The pain is described as pressure-like  radiating to his left arm  mostly occurs with physical activity  and is relieved by rest. He also reports associated symptoms such as shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional dizziness.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a known history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus which have been managed by Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively  over the past 5 years. He quit smoking about 10 years ago after a 30 packs/year habit and reports occasional alcohol consumption. He has a history of dyslipidemia and his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. His BMI is calculated at 29  indicating overweight.  On regular follow-ups  he has been documented with relatively poor glycemic control (HbA1c ranging from 7.5 – 8.0) for diabetes and occasional blood pressure spikes above the target range. His most recent lipid profile  6 months ago  showed total cholesterol of 220mg/dL  HDL 35mg/dL  LDL 160mg/dL  and triglycerides 180mg/dL.     The patient has been non-compliant with recommended dietary restrictions and seems to be leading a sedentary lifestyle. He admits no regular exercise habits and his diet frequently contains processed  high-fat content food. He denies illegal drug use and no noted allergy was reported to any medications.    Given the nature of his symptoms along with underlying comorbidities  poor lifestyle measures  and a positive family history  a provisional diagnosis of Chronic Stable Angina (coronary artery disease) is being highly suspected.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 62-year-old African American male who presents with a three-week history of intermittent  central chest discomfort radiating down his left arm  often associated with exertion and relieved with rest. These episodes occur approximately three times a week and last approximately 10 minutes each time. He also reports shortness of breath  especially during physical activities and has mentioned numerous instances of sudden  unexpected fatigue. He denies any recent history of cough  fever  weight changes  or night sweats.  The patient has a 20-year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which is currently being managed with Metformin  and a 5-year history of Hypertension controlled by Lisinopril. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 5 years ago. He has never had a myocardial infarction or stroke  and there is no known family history of premature cardiovascular disease. He has been non-compliant with his daily exercise routine and follows a diet high in saturated fats.  On physical examination  the patient has a BMI of 29.5  blood pressure of 150/90mmHg  heart rate of 78 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  The patient's demographics and presentation strongly suggest stable angina due to coronary artery disease  and hence  warrants further investigations and management. His age  gender  race  and cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes mellitus  history of smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and unhealthy diet all contribute to his high risk of coronary artery disease. The characteristic nature of his chest discomfort strongly points towards angina pectoris secondary to coronary ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Thompson is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with a two-week history of chest pain. He is a retired factory worker who lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He has been experiencing a discomforting pressure in his chest  particularly when exercising  described as a heavy feeling that is sometimes accompanied by a shortness of breath. He states that the pain is relievable by rest.   Mr. Thompson has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both of which have been managed with medication for the past ten years. He is a former smoker  having quit approximately 15 years ago  but he did smoke a pack a day for approximately 20 years. He admits to having a sedentary lifestyle and a diet that is high in fats and cholesterol.   He had a myocardial infarction ten years ago  at the age of 53  and has been on aspirin and a statin since then. There is a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father having undergone coronary artery bypass surgery at the age of 60.   On examination  his blood pressure is elevated at 145/95mmHg and his BMI is 29 kg/m2  indicative of overweight. His lungs are clear to auscultation  and heart sounds are normal with no murmurs or gallops. He is in no apparent distress at rest.  Laboratory investigations reveal elevated LDL cholesterol and HbA1c. EKG shows ST-segment depression indicative of myocardial ischemia. Given these findings  he is referred to Cardiology for further evaluation for suspected Coronary Artery Disease.

Patient Presentation:  Gender: Male    Age: 65   Race: Caucasian   Occupation: Retired Construction Worker    Chief Complaint:   Patient complains of a chronic chest pain that worsens upon exertion and improves with rest past 2 months.  History of Present Illness:   The patient reports intermittent chest discomfort described as a pressing sensation behind the sternum  often radiating to the left arm and sometimes accompanied by shortness of breath and diaphoresis. He says that it mostly occurs while walking his dog or during an emotional event but always improves with rest. He denies any symptoms when he is at rest. The patient also reports feelings of unusual fatigue and has noticed a decrease in his exercise capacity.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes 12 years ago  for which he takes metformin and lisinopril daily. He quit smoking 10 years ago but had a 30-year pack history prior. He also has a known history of hypercholesterolemia diagnosed 8 years ago  for which he had been prescribed statins. Patient occasionally takes nitroglycerin for angina as prescribed by the cardiologist.  Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at 70 and his elder brother  68  underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 2 years ago due to severe coronary artery disease.  Social History: The patient is a widower who lives alone. He is a retired construction worker. He admits to alcohol consumption of 1-2 drinks per day. He has stopped smoking and does not use illicit drugs.  Review of Systems: Positive for chest pain  shortness of breath  and fatigue. Negative for fever  cough  weight loss  palpitations  dizziness  and syncope.  On examination:    Vital signs: BP 140/85mmHg  HR: 85 bpm  RR: 18/min  Temp: 98°F   Physical examination is largely unremarkable except for an obese abdominal stature  and bilateral ankle edema.  In conclusion  given the patient's age  sex  symptoms  and past medical and family history  the diagnosis of coronary artery disease is suspected. Further investigation is required for confirmation and potential intervention.

Patient Presentation:  A 63-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of recurring episodes of chest pain  typically following physical exertion or emotional stress. He describes it as a crushing pain in the middle of his chest that sometimes spreads to his left arm and jaw. It occasionally coincides with shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea  and generally resolves with rest.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes. The patient has a 30 packs/year history of smoking though he quit five years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. Family history is notable for his father who passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 68.  The patient currently takes medications including metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He admits that he does have a sedentary lifestyle and does not adhere to a diabetes-friendly diet. He is otherwise independent in all activities of daily living and is retired. The patient lives with his wife in a suburban community and his only stress at the moment is related to his recent financial loss.  On initial assessment  his blood pressure is elevated at 150/95 mmHg  heart rate is 80 beats per minute  respirations are 18 per minute  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Upon auscultation  his heart sounds appear to be normal and lung fields are clear bilaterally.  Given his age  gender  race  symptoms  and risk factors  a suspicion of coronary artery disease is warranted. A thorough cardiovascular evaluation including 12-lead electrocardiogram and possibly further tests such as coronary angiography are scheduled to confirm the diagnosis and severity of his condition  as well as to guide appropriate management.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old African American male who presents with a chief complaint of persistent  crushing chest pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw. Accompanying symptoms include episodes of shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and fatigue  particularly after moderate physical activity. His symptoms have been progressing over the past several months.  He has a significant history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both managed on medication for the past 15 years. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 5 years ago  for which he takes a statin. He also has a 20-year history of smoking  which he quit about 1 year ago.   He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father and elder brother both suffered myocardial infarctions in their early sixties. He is retired and has a history of poor adherence to a healthy diet and poor exercise habits. He is 5'8” tall  weighs 248 lbs  and has a body mass index of 37.7  putting him in the category of obesity.  The patient denies any allergies to medication. He is currently on the following management: Metformin for his type 2 diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for his hyperlipidemia.  Given the patient's history  symptoms  and risk factors  there is a high suspicion for coronary artery disease. Further investigation  including an electrocardiogram  stress test  and potential angiography  is warranted.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 56-year-old African American male who presents to the clinic complaining of recurring chest discomfort that worsens with activity over the last two months. He describes his chest pain as a dull pressure in the central chest region  which sometimes radiates to his left arm. He has also noticed experiencing shortness of breath and feeling unusually tired when climbing stairs.  This patient is a manager at a local retail chain  working long hours with irregular meal patterns. He states he used to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily for about 20 years but quit ten years ago. He consumes alcohol socially and has a family history of heart disease; his father died of a heart attack at age 60.  Mr. Johnson's past medical history reveals he has been living with type 2 diabetes and hypertension for over seven years  for which he is on Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively. He also has hyperlipidemia  controlled with a statin (Atorvastatin). Despite this  he struggles with weight reduction and has a body mass index (BMI) of 32  classifying him as obese.  His vitals today are stable except for a slightly elevated blood pressure of 142/88 mmHg. Further assessment and diagnostic tests have been scheduled to evaluate the severity of his probable coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic retired engineer  presents to the clinic with complaints of sporadic chest discomfort  irregular heartbeats  and shortness of breath-especially during physical exertion over the past two months. The patient also reports feeling increasingly fatigued  occasional dizziness  and cold sweats. His discomfort tends to lessen with rest and intensify with physical exertion or emotional stress.  His medical history includes a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes about eight years ago and hypertension for the past five years. He was a smoker but quit 10 years ago. He has a body mass index of 29  indicating that he is overweight. His father died at 55 from a myocardial infarction  and his mother had a stroke at 75  indicating a significant family history of heart disease. His regular medications include Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. He admits to a low physical activity level due to his recent retirement and confesses that he has been indulging in unhealthy food more frequently.  On examination  his blood pressure is elevated at 145/90mmHg  his heart rate is irregular  and his respiration rate is slightly increased. Sounds heard through a stethoscope reveal mild crepitations at lung bases suggesting fluid overload. On inspection  another significant finding includes mild peripheral edema. No significant findings in the abdominal and neurologic examination.   The findings accurately represent the common demographics and characteristics of individuals with coronary artery disease as indicated in literature: older age  male  heritogeneity  diabetes  hypertension  overweight  and a history of smoking.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 64-year-old African American male who comes to the clinic complaining of recurrent chest pain  discomfort in his upper body  shortness of breath  fatigue  and lightheadedness over the last three weeks. He describes the pain as ""heavy"" or ""pressing"" and sometimes radiating to his left arm. These symptoms seem to worsen with physical activity but improve with rest.   He works as an accountant and lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He is a smoker with a 20 pack-year history and admits to having a diet high in red meat and processed foods. He has a BMI of 29  which is considered overweight. He states that he only engages in minimal physical activity and mostly leads a sedentary lifestyle.  Mr. Johnson's past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which were diagnosed about 10 years ago. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 65 and his older brother was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease. These family histories further increase his own risk for coronary artery disease. He is under medication for his chronic illnesses  taking Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. However  he admits to inconsistently taking his medications.  The combination of his chest pain symptoms  male gender  age group  citizenry  African-American ethnicity  smoking history  poor diet  low physical activity  parental history of heart attack  hypertension  diabetes  overweight  and inconsistent adherence to medication  makes Mr. Johnson a high-risk individual for coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  John  a 67-year-old Hispanic male  weighs 220 lbs with a height of 6ft  presenting with chest discomfort and shortness of breath on exertion for the past few weeks. John lives in Los Angeles  California and is a retired mechanic. He admits to a 30 pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. His diet is high in saturated fats  and his lifestyle is mostly sedentary.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both diagnosed 7 years ago and managed by medications. He also has a familial history of cardiac disease. His father died of a heart attack at 72  and his older brother had a stent placed for coronary artery disease at the age of 63.   John's current medication regimen includes lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 40mg daily for hyperlipidemia. He does not have any known drug allergies.   On further questioning  he describes the chest discomfort as a squeezing sensation  lasting for 10-15 minutes and usually relieved by rest. The shortness of breath is typically concurrent with the chest discomfort. He had no known episodes of syncope  but he reports occasional episodes of dizziness particularly on exerting.  The persistent chest discomfort and shortness of breath on exertion  along with his established risk factors  strongly suggest underlying coronary artery disease. The patient needs immediate further evaluations including an EKG and stress testing to assess the severity of the suspected coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Antonio Vega  a 62-year-old Hispanic male  presented to the clinic today with chief complaints of intermittent chest pain radiating to the left arm  especially during physical activities  as well as shortness of breath  and fatigue for the past 2 weeks. He describes the pain as ""tightening"" that improves with rest. He also reports episodes of lightheadedness but no reports of syncope. There is no history of nausea  vomiting or diaphoresis associated with the pain.  Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin  dyslipidemia managed with a statin  and hypertension controlled with amlodipine and lisinopril. He is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history but quit 10 years ago. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in processed foods.   He has a family history significant for coronary artery disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. He lives with his wife and is retired  they have two adult children. He admits to occasional alcohol consumption but denies any illicit drug use.   On physical examination  his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  pulse 75 bpm  and BMI 30.5 Kg/m2  indicating obesity. Cardiovascular examination reveals distant heart sounds  but no murmur or gallop.   This presentation raises suspicion for stable angina secondary to coronary artery disease  and the patient's age  male gender  ethnicity  unhealthy lifestyle  and genetic predisposition further increase his risk profile for the same. This warrants further investigative studies including EKG and potentially other cardiac stress testing methods.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Starks  a 73-year-old African-American female  presents to the clinic complaining of increasing episodes of chest pain and discomfort over the past few months. These episodes typically occur while she is physically active and they subside after rest. Additionally  she reports feeling a shortness of breath after climbing stairs or carrying groceries. She has a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been under fairly good control with medication.  Mrs. Starks leads a sedentary lifestyle  has a BMI of 31 (indicating obesity)  and a 15-year smoking history  although she quit two years ago. Her father had an early-onset coronary artery disease (CAD)  he passed away from a heart attack at the age of 56. She admits that her diet is mainly high in fats and carbohydrates.   On clinical examination  her blood pressure reads 135/85 mmHg and her heart rate is 85 bpm. Cardiovascular examination reveals no specific abnormalities  but given her symptoms and risk profile  there is a strong clinical suspicion of underlying CAD.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old African American male presents himself at the clinic complaining of frequent chest discomfort that he describes as a crushing sensation  occurring predominantly with exertion or stress and relieved with rest or nitroglycerin use. He reports this symptom onset within the last 6 months  progressively getting worse. The patient states the discomfort sometimes radiates to his left arm and complains of associated shortness of breath.   He has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which were diagnosed ten years ago but have not been well controlled despite medication. He had ceased his regular walking routine due to the chest discomfort.   Mr. Doe has been a smoker for the past 40 years  with a 20 pack-year history and drinks alcohol occasionally. The patient reports that his father had died from a so-called ""heart attack"" at the age of 70.   He has been using antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril) along with a hypoglycemic agent (Metformin). He has not had any surgeries in the past  and his immunizations are up to date. He has an allergy to NSAIDs which causes him skin rash.   The patient's BMI is 28  indicative of overweight. On physical examination  his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  heart rate is regular at 80 bpm  and respiratory rate is 18 breaths per min. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs  rubs or gallops but there are decreased breath sounds at the lung bases with crackles  suggestive of possible heart failure.   Given the constellation of exertional chest pain  shortness of breath  uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  smoking history  and family history of heart disease  the working diagnosis for Mr. Doe is coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Brown is a 59-year-old African American man who presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of intermittent chest heaviness  which has been increasingly frequent over the past week. The pain typically occurs with exertion  lasts about 10 minutes  and is relieved by rest. He describes the pain as a vague discomfort  not sharp or stabbing  and it seems to radiate to his left arm. Occasionally  he also experiences shortness of breath and lightheadedness along with the chest discomfort  particularly during his evening walks.  Mr. Brown is a retired insurance salesperson. He is a current smoker with a 40-pack-year history and admits to drinking alcohol socially. His diet is high in fats and processed foods. He does not engage in regular physical exercise.  His medical history is significant with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication. He has a family history of heart disease  as his father had a heart attack at the age of 62.   Mr. Brown reports poor medication adherence due to forgetfulness since his insurance doesn't cover the full cost of his medications  which he also cites as a significant point of stress. No allergies are reported.  Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 155/92 mmHg and irregular heart rate of 85 bpm. BMI is 32  indicating obesity. Mild peripheral edema is noted in his ankles bilaterally.  Based on the risk factors  presenting symptoms  and family history  a preliminary diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) is considered.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Mendoza is a 57-year-old Hispanic male presenting with a chief complaint of chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 2 weeks. The pain is characterized as a pressure sensation in the middle of his chest that radiates to the left arm. It gets worse with exertion and eases somewhat with rest. The patient also notes occasional palpitations and diaphoresis  mostly associated with the chest pain.  Mr. Mendoza has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  all diagnosed 7 years ago. He is non-compliant with prescribed medications due to lack of health insurance. He is a former smoker  with a 20-pack year history; he quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies illicit drug use. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. He reports a sedentary lifestyle attributable to his job as a long-distance truck driver and a diet that leans heavily on fast food and high carbohydrate  high-fat foods.  The patient denies having a fever  cough  gastrointestinal symptoms  lower limb swelling or recent engaging in strenuous physical activities. He is not currently experiencing symptoms of a stroke  such as sudden numbness or weakness on one side of the body  sudden confusion  difficulty speaking or understanding speech  sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes  or sudden trouble walking  dizziness  or loss of balance.  Physical Examination:  On physical exam  Mr. Mendoza is overweight (body mass index of 30)  and his blood pressure is observed to be elevated at 155/95 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation reveals distant heart sounds but no murmur  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary examination is clear  and no lower extremity edema is noted. Other physical findings are within normal limits. His EKG showed a possible left ventricular hypertrophy and nonspecific T wave changes. He was pulled in for further tests to confirm the suspicion of CAD.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of chest pain for the past month. The patient describes it as a heavy feeling in the center of his chest  which often appears after physical exercise or heavy meals and disappears after rest. The pain has a duration of about 10-15 minutes and is sometimes accompanied by shortness of breath and sweatiness. He reports a recent increase in intensity and frequency of the episodes. He denies any episodes of syncope  palpitations  or lower limb edema.  He has a 20-year history of type-2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which are managed with metformin  lisinopril  and hydrochlorothiazide. He is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago  after a 30-year-history of one pack per day. He admits to having an unhealthy diet  high in cholesterol and saturated fat. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. He has a family history of premature heart disease  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. He is retired and lives with his wife. He is adherent to his medications but does not engage in any regular physical activity.  Physical Examination: On examination  he is alert and oriented. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  pulse-rhythm is regular at 78 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute  and BMI is 30 kg/m2. Raised yellowish patches (xanthomas) can be seen over both his elbows. His cardiac examination reveals normal S1 and S2 heart sounds with no additional heart sounds or murmurs. His lungs are clear to auscultation and his peripheral pulses are intact.  This patient's demographic details  along with his symptoms and clinical history  are suggestive of coronary artery disease. A cardiovascular assessment shall be helpful in determining the extent of his condition and identifying suitable treatment options.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the clinic with worsening chest pressure and shortness of breath for two weeks. He describes the chest pain as a tight  squeezing discomfort  located in the middle of his chest  which often radiates to his left arm. The symptoms usually begin with exertion or under stress and improve with rest.   Mr. Smith has been experiencing episodes of these symptoms for several months  which have been progressively getting worse. Over the last couple of days  he has also noticed some difficulty in catching his breath following light physical activities  such as walking around the house or climbing stairs.   He has a past medical history significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension for which he takes daily medication  including hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. He has been a type 2 diabetic for the last 10 years and is currently being managed with metformin. He also has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit ten years ago.   He consumes alcohol socially but denies any illicit drug usage. His father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and his older brother has been diagnosed with coronary artery disease.   On physical examination  the patient appears comfortable at rest. His vital signs are as follows: blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  pulse of 80 beats per minute  respirations at a rate of 16 breaths per minute  and a body temperature of 98.6° F (37° C). His body mass index is 30. An EKG is ordered due to his presentation of symptoms and medical history.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Study – Coronary Artery Disease Subtitle: An Overview of Heart Health in Demographic Context  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who is a non-smoker  living in a metropolitan area. - He is slightly overweight with a BMI of 27  works as a shift consultant  and has a history of low physical activity. - The literature suggests the incidence of coronary artery disease (CAD) is comparatively high in this demographic due to lifestyle factors and genetic predisposition.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  - The patient has a history of hypertension  controlled by medication. - He has no previous diagnosis of diabetes but shows signs of insulin resistance  suggesting a pre-diabetic state. - The patient was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia two years ago. - His father passed away from a heart attack at age 65  indicating a strong family history of heart disease.  Slide 5: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) - CAD  also known as ischemic heart disease  is most commonly due to a buildup of plaques in the arteries supplying blood and oxygen to the heart. - Risk factors include old age  male sex  smoking  physical inactivity  poor diet  obesity  hypertension  diabetes  and family history.  Slide 6: Symptom Presentation - The patient visited the emergency department complaining of recurrent chest pain and shortness of breath  particularly when performing physical activities. - He reported that the pain often spreads to his shoulders  arms  and neck.  - Further cardiac examination suggested symptoms of angina pectoris.  Slide 7: Diagnosis & Treatment - Cardiac diagnostic tests  including electrocardiogram and coronary angiography  confirmed CAD. - The patient was prescribed antiplatelet therapy  beta-blockers  statins  and lifestyle-modifying measures. - The patient is also advised to have regular follow-ups to monitor his condition.  Slide 8: Connecting Demographics with CAD  - The lifestyle of a metropolitan  desk-bound employee coupled with age and genetic predisposition significantly contributed to his CAD.  - As per literature  men  especially Caucasian men  over the age of 60  have a higher risk for CAD. - This case reinforces the need to focus on preventive strategies  early diagnosis  and management for at-risk demographics.  Slide 9: Conclusion - CAD is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide.  - Our understanding of the inherent link between CAD and specific demographics can help guide proactive healthcare measures.  End of Presentation.

Title: A Case Presentation on Coronary Artery Disease in the Elderly  Slide 1: Introduction - Age: 70-year-old - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupations: Retired factory worker  Slide 2: Past Medical History - Hypertension for the past ten years  currently managed with medication. - Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes five years ago and is currently under control with diet modification and medications. - Family history of heart disease  his father passed away from a heart attack. - Former smoker  quit smoking 15 years ago. - Low physical activity  sedentary lifestyle.  - Previous history of overweight  current BMI now in a normal range due to recent weight loss.  Slide 3: Presenting Concern  - The patient presents with consistent angina  which has been progressively becoming severe over the past year. Recently  he has been experiencing shortness of breath  dizziness  and excessive sweating on minor exertion.  Slide 4: Diagnosis  - A comprehensive examination including Electrocardiogram (EKG)  Stress Test and ultimately Coronary Angiography confirmed the diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). - There is significant obstruction in two out of three major coronary arteries.   Slide 5: Management and Prognosis  - Encouragement of healthy lifestyle changes  such as diet and exercise - Medication for managing symptoms and slowing disease progression i.e.  beta-blockers  calcium channel blockers  nitroglycerin. - Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) or Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) could be considered for severe cases. - Regular follow-up for monitoring disease progression and medication side-effects.  Slide 6: Conclusion  - Early diagnosis and treatment of coronary artery disease are crucial to prevent harmful complications like heart attacks.  - Regular follow-ups for a patient like this are critical due to the combination of CAD  hypertension  and diabetes  making the case severe. - Positive prognosis with lifestyle changes and ongoing treatment.   Please note while this presentation is based on a typical case of CAD  the disease can present differently based on various factors such as genetic predisposition  general health condition  lifestyle etc. Always look at the individual case.

Title: Case Presentation of a Patient with Coronary Artery Disease   Slide 1: Introduction This presentation describes a case of a 60-year-old African American male diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD). Recent literature shows that African American males are disproportionately affected by CAD  often due to lifestyle factors and unique genetic susceptibilities.   Slide 2: Demographics Our patient is a 60-year-old retired construction supervisor living in Washington  D.C. He is a widower with two adult children. He is a non-smoker but admits to a history of poor dietary habits and infrequent exercise.  Slide 3: Past Medical History The patient's medical history includes grade 2 hypertension and dyslipidemia  well-managed with medication. Notably  the patient's mother died early from CAD. Unfortunately  this family history further elevates his risk for CAD.   Slide 4: Presentation Mr. Smith presented to the doctor with frequent chest pain and shortness of breath  particularly when engaging in physical activities. He also experienced episodes of indigestion that he initially associated with dietary issues.  Slide 5: Diagnosis CAD was suspected based on his symptoms and risk factors. ECG showed T-wave inversion  and subsequent angiography confirmed significant occlusions in his coronary arteries. He was then formally diagnosed with CAD.  Slide 6: Management and Prognosis The patient was prescribed a regimen of aspirin  statins  angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  and beta-blockers. He underwent angioplasty and had a stent placed in the obstructed artery. Lifestyle modifications  including a heart-healthy diet  exercise  and cardiac rehabilitation  were also encouraged. With compliance  the prognosis for this patient is cautiously optimistic. However  it reinforces the importance of screening and prevention strategies in at-risk populations.    Slide 7: Conclusion This case highlights the importance of considering CAD in patients with known risk factors  even if their symptoms may seem unremarkable. Regular follow-ups and aggressive management of modifiable risk factors in such high-risk patients are essential in preventing any cardiovascular event.
