He claims compliance with his antihypertensive  statin  and antidiabetic medications  but continues to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily. He admits intermittent chest pain over the last several months  similar to his current symptoms  but that usually resolved on its own. He has no known allergies. His last physical examination was a year ago  where his blood pressure was 145/90  cholesterol was 210 mg/dL  and HbA1c was 8.2%. The patient has not undergone any baseline cardiac diagnostic tests in the past. His BMI was recorded to be 27.5 kg/m2  indicating overweight status. Current vital signs are stable  with a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse 64 beats per minute  respirations 18 breaths per minute  and temperature 98.4 degrees Fahrenheit. Examination reveals an overweight man in mild distress. His cardiovascular examination reveals normal heart sounds and no murmurs. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old Caucasian male presents with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath  particularly with exertion over the past six months. The pain is typically located in the mid-chest area  pressurized  radiates to the left shoulder  and often associated with nausea and diaphoresis. His past medical history is significant for type two diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and tobacco use (~20 pack-years). The patient's family history is notable for his father dying of a heart attack at the age of 60. He is currently on metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. His BMI is 30.1 kg/m2. On examination  the patient's BP is 140/90 mmHg  heart rate is 78 bpm  and other vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiovascular examination reveals normal S1  S2 with no murmurs. His chest appears clear on auscultation  and there is no peripheral edema noted.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male retired banker  presenting with a one-month history of progressive chest pain  described as pressure-like  often occurring during periods of stress or elevated physical activity. The pain is typically relieved by rest. Occasionally  he also experiences shortness of breath and diaphoresis during these episodes. The patient has a 20-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which have been managed with medication. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease (CAD); his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. The patient has been a 10-cigarette/day smoker for about 30 years but quit about 10 years ago. His BMI is 29  and he follows a relatively sedentary lifestyle with a moderate diet.

Patient Profile: 65-year-old African American male.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus. He also has a 20-year history of cigarette smoking  which he quit five years ago. No prior history of any cardiovascular diseases. Regular medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and a statin.  Symptoms at Presentation: The patient presented with a recent onset of increasing chest discomfort  particularly noted during physical exertion. The pain is described as pressure-like in the center of the chest  radiating to his left arm. The discomfort usually subsides upon resting. He also reports experiencing intermittent shortness of breath and occasional episodes of dizziness in the past month. No nausea  vomiting or sweating is reported. He denies any recent changes in weight  diet  or physical activity level.  This medical problem representation indicates angina pectoris possibly due to coronary artery disease  given the patient's age  race  sex  relevant medical history and the classic description of symptoms. It needs prompt medical evaluation including but not limited to an electrocardiogram and stress test.

Patient Profile:  Mr. James  a 63-year-old Caucasian male  truck driver  married with 2 kids  residing in the city.  Presenting Issue:  Mr. James reports experiencing recurrent episodes of substernal chest pain and shortness of breath  especially during physical exertion or emotional stress  over the last two months. Sometimes  these episodes are accompanied by cold sweats  palpitations  and nausea. He does not have any pain radiating to the arms or throat. Previously  these symptoms would resolve on resting  but in the past week  they have become prolonged and more frequent.  Medical History:  The patient has a known history of high cholesterol levels  diagnosed two years ago. He is on a low dose of Atorvastatin which he takes inconsistently. He also has hypertension  diagnosed five years ago  and is inconsistent in managing his blood pressure levels with medication. He has no known allergies. He has a 30 pack-year history of smoking  consuming one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years. He admits a diet high in saturated fats with minimal regular exercise. There is family history of early heart disease; his father and paternal uncle both had myocardial infarctions in their sixties.   Physical Examination on Presentation:  On presentation  Mr. James appears mildly distressed with some profuse sweating. Vitals reveal blood pressure of 160/96  heart rate 102 beats per minute  respirations 22 per minute  and saturation 96% on room air. Auscultation of the heart reveals normal heart sounds without any additional sounds. Pain is not reproduced on palpation of the chest. Lab results are pending.   These findings suggest that Mr. James may be experiencing angina due to significant coronary artery disease  which should be further evaluated.

Patient Information: Robert Thompson  a 67-year-old African American male  Chief Complaint: Presenting with left-sided chest pain lasting approximately 10-15 minutes  occurring after exertion and relieved by rest. The pain has been present intermittently for the past three months but has been intensifying and persisting for longer durations over the past week.  History of Present Illness: Patient has been previously diagnosed with Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  managed with medications (Metformin  Lisinopril  and Amlodipine). He reports medication adherence but has inconsistent follow-ups with his primary care physician. He also has a 30-pack-year smoking history and a Western diet with minimal physical activity.  Past Medical History: Hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and Dyslipidemia  Family history: Father died of myocardial infarction at 65  and mother suffers from Type 2 diabetes.   Social History: Mr. Thompson is retired  lives with his wife  and has a 30-pack-year smoking history. He reports social alcohol use.   Review of systems: Reports increased fatigue and tiredness. No complaint of palpitations  shortness of breath or syncope.   Physical examination: Blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  a heart rate of 80 beats per minute  obesity with a BMI of 31. Cardiovascular examination reveals soft S1 and S2 with no murmurs or rubs.   Pertinent laboratory findings: Slightly raised troponin levels  HbA1c of 7.9%  and elevated LDL cholesterol.  Assessment: Given his risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  smoking  family history of cardiovascular diseases  age  and ethnicity)  symptoms suggestive of angina pectoris  and pertinent lab findings  he is suspected of having Coronary Artery Disease. Referral to cardiology for further evaluation including ECG  stress tests  and potentially angiography is warranted.  Plan: Cardiology referral for further evaluation and management. Consider lifestyle modification counseling including smoking cessation advice  diet  exercise instructions  and consistent follow-ups. Optimization of blood pressure  blood sugar  and cholesterol may be necessary. Antiplatelet therapy and symptom-relieving medications may also be considered depending on the recommendations upon cardiology consultation.

Patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presenting with moderate to severe chest pain with breathlessness that started while he was mowing his lawn  and relieved partially by rest. The pain radiates to his left arm and is accompanied by a sense of heaviness and pressure  consistent with angina pectoris. In addition  there have been recent episodes of exertional fatigue and dizziness. He has a history of smoking tobacco for 30 years  but quit 10 years ago. Patient acknowledges a family history of early-onset coronary artery disease. His medications include enalapril  metoprolol  atorvastatin  and metformin. On examination  his BP is 145/90 mmHg  pulse 78 bpm  and BMI 29 (indicating overweight status). Patient’s EKG shows ST-segment depressions and T-wave inversions indicative of ischemia. Chest radiography reveals no signs of congestion. Taking all these into account  the etiology of his complaints seems to be coronary artery disease  specifically chronic stable angina.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent chest pain  frequent episodes of breathlessness especially on exertion  and occasional dizzy spells for the past two months. He reports the chest pressure is localized to the center and often radiates towards the left arm. He also mentions experiencing sweating and nausea with these episodes.   Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension 10 years ago. He has been irregular with his treatment and monitoring.   Family History: His father passed away from a heart attack at 70. His younger brother had a stent placement at 60 for coronary artery disease (CAD).   Social History: The patient reveals a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years  but quit 2 years ago. His diet is rich in fats and carbohydrates and he does not engage regularly in physical activities.  Review of Symptoms: Unremarkable apart from cardiovascular and endocrine review.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  his blood pressure is recorded as 150/90 mm of Hg and body mass index is 32 kg/square meter  indicative of obesity. Cardiac examination reveals normal heart sounds with no murmurs or gallops.  Given the frequent episodes of exertional angina  coupled with diabetes  hypertension  family history  past smoking  obesity  and physical inactivity  the patient's presentation is highly suggestive of worsening coronary artery disease.

Patient Profile: A 67-year-old African American male presents with a heavy feeling in his chest  and shortness of breath particularly with exertion.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a 15-year history of Type-2 diabetes and a history of hypertension for the past 10 years  for which he has been on oral medications. He is also a former smoker with a 20 pack-year smoking history. There is a family history of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) and heart attack- his father had CAD and suffered a heart attack at the age of 62.  Symptoms on Presentation: This patient presents with chest discomfort  which he describes as a heavy and tight feeling that occasionally radiates to his left arm. The chest discomfort is triggered by exertive activities and generally resolves with rest. He has also noticed that he is getting short of breath more easily and quickly while climbing stairs or walking short distances. He denies any incident of cold sweats  nausea  or lightheadedness. On physical examination  his blood pressure is elevated to 145/95 mmHg and his BMI is 32 (height: 175 cm  weight: 93 kilograms)  indicative of obesity.   This history and presentation most commonly align with stable angina due to coronary artery disease  likely exacerbated by his uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and history of smoking. His age  gender  race and family history also place him at an increased risk for coronary artery disease.

A 65-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes presents with chest discomfort. The patient describes a central chest pressure that radiates to his left arm  lasting approximately 10 minutes and associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and light-headedness. Symptoms are typically triggered by physical exertion and relieved by rest. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years  drinks alcohol occasionally  and is non-compliant with his medications. He has a strong family history of coronary artery disease with his father having a heart attack at the age of 56. He is retired and lives alone. He denies any illicit drug use. Currently  he takes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. On examination  his blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg  pulse 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  and BMI 30. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs  rubs or gallops. Respiratory  abdominal  and neurological exams are unremarkable.

Patient Description: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Problem: The patient presents complaining of recurrent episodes of chest pain  particularly during physical activities. He also reports fatigue  and occasional lightheadedness.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a documented history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol for which he has been on medication for the past 10 years. He had been a smoker for 30 years but quit approximately 5 years ago. There is a family history of heart disease with his father having suffered from a heart attack in his early 70s.  Physical Examination and Symptoms: Clinical examination revels the patient is overweight (BMI 28) with a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. He appears pale and slightly dyspneic on exertion. An electrocardiogram shows evidence of previous myocardial infarction.   Preliminary Diagnosis: These presentation and history are suggestive of coronary artery disease with possible angina pectoris.

Patient is a 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He complains of persistent  intermittent chest pain for the last two weeks  predominantly on exertion  and reports one episode of overnight chest pain that woke him from sleep. Accompanying symptoms include fatigue  shortness of breath  and diaphoresis. He denies nausea  vomiting  orthopnea  or palpitations. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year history  and admits to a sedentary lifestyle. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive and diabetes medications due to financial constraints.

Patient is a 67 year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and a 45-year history of tobacco use. He presents complaints of a chronic  dull chest pain that intensifies during exercise but relieves at rest  often described as a sensation of pressure or tightness. The patient also reports episodes of shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional dizziness  more frequently in recent weeks. He has been struggling to climb stairs due to the discomfort and dyspnea. Family history reveals that his father passed away from heart disease at an early age. He also hadn't been maintaining his diet and exercise regimen due to the recent loss of his wife. He has been on anti-hypertensive and statins but admits to lack of medication adherence recently. Patient refrains from alcohol but has a 2-pack per day smoking history which includes his current tobacco use. His BMI is 32 indicating obesity. His blood pressure is regularly monitored and is generally high (150/95 mmHg on average). The aforementioned chronic symptoms  combined with the provided medical history  make it highly probable that his current clinical presentation is a consequence of atherosclerotic coronary artery disease.

Patient: A 64-year old  African-American male  with a BMI of 29.8  residing in an urban environment.   Medical History: Our patient has a relevant medical history of uncontrolled hypertension for about a decade  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. There is also a documented family history of early-onset coronary artery disease among his male relatives (father and elder brother). His regular medications include hydrochlorothiazide  metformin  and atorvastatin. However  the patient does not adhere strictly to his prescribed regimen  and exhibits inconsistent medication compliance. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago after a 30-year pack history. He also admits to alcohol consumption of occasional beer over the weekends and maintains a diet high in saturated fats  with little exercise.   Problem: For the past month  the patient has been experiencing intermittent chest discomfort  typically on exertion like climbing stairs  which is relieved by rest. Lasting around 15 minutes each episode  the heaviness is localized in the center of the chest. For the last 2 days  the chest discomfort started to appear more frequently and intensively than before. He also complained about shortness of breath during mild physical exertion and increased fatigue. The symptoms have led to the discontinuation of his daily activities. No other associated symptoms such as dizziness  loss of consciousness  sweating  or palpations.   This clinical situation raises the suspicion of worsening coronary artery disease with potential unstable angina based on the nature and progression of his symptoms.

Patient is a 62-year-old white male with a past medical history of hypertension and tobacco use who presents with chest discomfort and shortness of breath. He describes the pain as a constant heavy ache in the middle of his chest  radiating to his left arm  which began approximately two hours ago. The patient rates the pain at 7/10 and withdrew from recreational activities due to discomfort. Associated symptoms include diaphoresis and nausea. He was previously prescribed medication for his hypertension but non-compliant with it. He also has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father having a myocardial infarction at age 60. His lifestyle lacks regular exercise and includes a rich  high-fat diet.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: A long-time smoker (40 pack years)  with a history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type2 diabetes. Family history reveals that his father had a heart attack at age 70.  Presenting Complaints: Complaining of progressive exertional chest pain over the last 3 months  which he describes as a ""tightness"" in the center of his chest that is usually brought on by walking and relieved by rest. The patient also admits to shortness of breath and has noticed an unexplained weight loss.  Review of Systems: Notable for generalized fatigue  decreased exercise tolerance  palpitations  occasional episodes of extreme sweats  and disturbed sleep.  Physical Examination: Overweight (BMI: 29)  BP: 152/90 mmHg; regular heart rate at 84 bpm but mild ejection systolic murmur noted. No peripheral edema or jugular venous distention. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  In light of his age  gender  symptoms  and risk factors (long-standing smoker  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and family history of heart disease)  Mr. Johnson's presentation is suggestive of stable coronary artery disease (CAD). Referral to cardiology for further evaluation  including functional testing or angiography  is warranted to confirm the diagnosis  assess the severity of his disease  and guide appropriate management.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old African American male presents to the clinic with increasing episodes of chest pain during physical activity. The pain is centrally located  experienced as a heavy pressure  radiating to his left arm  and is relieved by rest. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath that occur concurrent with the pain. He denies nausea  vomiting  or palpitations. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year history  but quit 10 years ago. He has a known medical history of hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. Results from an exercise stress test performed 1 year ago showed no evidence of ischemia.  Relevant social history includes a diet high in fats  and poor compliance with his prescribed medications  which include atorvastatin 40mg daily and Lisinopril 20mg daily. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg and a body mass index (BMI) of 30.5 kg/m2. No murmurs  rubs  or gallops can be appreciated on auscultation. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.  In conclusion  this is a patient with a significant cardiovascular risk profile and typical angina symptoms  suggestive of stable coronary artery disease  requiring further diagnostic evaluation and management.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired factory worker  with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II Diabetes Mellitus  and a 30-pack-year smoking history (quit 5 years ago) who presents with a six-hour period of intermittent  retrosternal chest pain that radiates to the left arm. He's experiencing severe discomfort  he describes it as ""a heavy pressure""  sometimes accompanied by episodes of shortness of breath and excessive sweating  especially during periods of exertion or stress. The pain sometimes subsides when he is resting. The patient has noted these episodes have been increasing in frequency and duration over the past three months. He denies any nausea  vomiting or syncope. He has a family history of coronary artery disease in his father  who had his first heart attack at the age of 60. His physical examination is within normal limits with a BMI of 29. His blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg and pulse rate is 85 beats per minute.  This clinical scenario suggests the patient is suffering from coronary artery disease (CAD)  likely angina pectoris  given his risk factors which include older age  male gender  personal history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes mellitus  and a family history of CAD  along with his characteristic chest pain associated with exertion and relieved with rest. His symptoms need prompt intervention to prevent a possible myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old male presenting with new-onset chest discomfort.  Medical Problem Representation: A 65-year-old Caucasian male with past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presents with symptoms of retrosternal chest discomfort which he describes as a ""pressure-like"" feeling radiating to his left arm and jaw. Discomfort is typically aggravated by physical activities and relieved with rest or nitroglycerin. He also reports associated shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  and fatigue. He has a 20-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day  coupled with a sedentary lifestyle and a family history of coronary artery disease with his father experiencing his first myocardial infarction at 55 years of age. An EKG indicated ST-depressions and negative T-waves in leads V4-V6. His recent blood work shows elevated blood pressure  raised levels of low-density lipoprotein  and poor glycemic control. Concordantly  all of these details suggest the diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease.

Patient is a 68-year-old African American male with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  presenting with symptoms of acute chest pain  particularly upon exertion  shortness of breath and fatigue. He is a retired manufacturing employee and has a 50 pack-year smoking history. His father suffered a heart attack at 72. He also experiences occasional discomfort in his arms  neck  and back. Patient follows a sedentary lifestyle with irregular exercise. His BMI is 32.3 indicating obesity. His latest blood lipid profile shows elevated LDL cholesterol and blood glucose levels are also poorly controlled despite medication and diet control efforts. He is adherent to his prescribed antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. His blood pressure taken in the clinic today is 150/90 mmHg  indicating poorly controlled hypertension. His complaints have been worsening over the past few weeks. He denies any previous occurrence of similar pain. No other significant health problems were reported. The findings raise the suspicion for coronary artery disease exacerbated by uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes.

Patient Presentation: A 62-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent chest discomfort over the past three months. The pain is described as a heavy sensation localized to the middle of his chest  sometimes radiating to his left arm and is aggravated by physical exertion and emotional stress. Patient reports episodes often lasting approximately 10-15 minutes  typically subsiding with rest.   Demographics: The patient is a retired teacher  married with two children  non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He has a significant family history of cardiovascular disease; his father had an MI at age 64  and a brother had a stroke at age 55. The patient lives an urban lifestyle with moderate physical activity.  Medical History: In view of his age  sex  family history  and presenting symptoms  he has an increased risk for coronary artery disease (CAD). His medical history is significant for Type-2 Diabetes and hypertension  which are known risk factors for CAD. He has been on Metformin and Lisinopril for the past ten years. No known medication allergies.   Symptoms on Presentation: On further questioning  he admits to experiencing some shortness of breath  particularly during moderate physical activity such as walking up stairs. Patient also mentioned occasional episodes of dizziness. He has not experienced any palpitations  syncope  or lower extremity swelling. On physical examination  there is no lateral displacement of the cardiac apical impulse  and heart rate and rhythms are normal. Laboratory investigations show a slightly elevated cholesterol level.

Problem Representation:  A 64-year-old African American male presents with a complaint of intermittent chest discomfort over the past week. The pain is described as a pressure sensation in the center of the chest  radiating to the left arm. It is typically brought on by exertion and relieved by rest  lasting about 10 minutes each time. The patient also reports episodes of shortness of breath that accompany this discomfort.  The patient has a significant medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia  all of which have been under uncontrolled status despite being on medication. He smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 30 years but quit 2 years ago. His mother died of myocardial infraction at 70 years old.  On physical examination  the patient has a BMI of 30  blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and regular pulse of 90 beats per minute. On cardiac auscultation  there is no murmur  S1 and S2 sounds noted. There's no jugular venous distention and lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.  These aforementioned features suggest patient's history is possibly consistent with coronary artery disease (CAD).

Patient is a 68-year-old African-American male  who presents with a several-month history of exertional chest discomfort  shortness of breath  increasing episodes of fatigue  and intermittent dizziness. Patient has a relevant medical past including a long-standing history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  obesity (BMI of 32)  and a 30-year pack history of smoking but ceased 2 years ago. Family history is significant for his father who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. Patient is currently taking metformin and losartan  but admits non-compliance due to lack of understanding of the medications' importance. On presentation  the physical examination reveals elevated blood pressure and a body mass index suggestive of obesity. EKG changes suggestive of ischemia. No other immediate abnormal findings. The patient's symptoms  lifestyle and previous medical history contribute to his high-risk status for coronary artery disease.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Johnson  a 63-year-old Caucasian man  presents with typical angina-like symptoms. He is from middle-class socioeconomic status  living an urban lifestyle  and is retired. He has a significant past medical history including hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia  all of which are currently being medically managed.   Current Presentation: He describes a central chest discomfort that radiates to his left arm and is associated with excessive sweating. These symptoms occur mainly during activities such as gardening or brisk walking and relieve with rest. Over the past week  these episodes have been growing more intense and frequent. The patient also reports mild dyspnea on exertion.   He is a former smoker  having quit about 15 years ago  attributing to roughly 25-pack year history. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle  consuming a carb-heavy diet and a moderate alcohol intake. There is no relevant family medical history except for a younger brother who had an myocardial infraction in his early fifties.   The combination of Mr. Johnson’s demographics  previous medical history  and symptoms strongly suggest he is dealing with worsening coronary artery disease. The increase in severity and frequency in his angina symptoms suggest he may be at a stable but high risk  nearing unstable angina levels.

Patient Profile:   Mr. Brown is a 58-year-old African-American male  presenting with chronic coronary artery disease (CAD).   Medical History:  He has a significant medical history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. His mother was diagnosed with CAD at the age of 64. For the past 15 years  Mr. Brown has been a heavy smoker with an average habit of 20 cigarettes per day. He admits to a lack of regular exercise as his job requires long hours at a desk and confesses to a diet rich in processed foods.   Presenting Symptoms:  Recently  Mr. Brown has started to experience recurrent bouts of chest discomfort  particularly during periods of emotional distress or physical exertion. These episodes are typically relieved with rest. He describes the pain as a tightness located in the center of his chest  sometimes radiating to his left arm. He further reports episodes of shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional feeling of lightheadedness. He denies any associated symptoms such as palpitations  coughing up blood  or loss of consciousness.  This clinical scenario is consistent with a chronic stable angina  likely secondary to worsening CAD. In light of his presenting symptoms  medical history  and demographic  further assessment and medical management should be urgently considered.

Patient Representation:  John Doe is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  sedentary lifestyle and a 20-pack year smoking history reporting with a 3-week history of intermittent  exertional chest pain. The pain is described as squeezing in nature  located in the middle of the chest  and is associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. The symptoms were initially occurring while he was doing yard work but has recently started to notice it while he walks from the living room to the kitchen. He denies any orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He does admit to progressive fatigue and has decreased his activity to avoid symptom onset. He has a family history significant for his mother and older brother having myocardial infarctions in their early 60s. His current medications are Lisinopril and Simvastatin. He is adherent to his medications  but his blood pressure and cholesterol levels have not been consistently controlled. Mr. Doe has a BMI consistent with obesity and he consumes alcohol moderately. He has undergone no surgeries in the past. On examination  the patient appears fatigued  however is not in acute distress. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination unremarkable except for a grade 3 systolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart. His electrocardiogram reveals no acute ischemic changes.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired  with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He has been a smoker for the past 45 years with a 30 pack-year history. There is a strong family history of heart disease  with his father passing away from a heart attack at an early age. He presents today with new-onset chest pain that he describes as a heavy feeling in the center of his chest  radiating to his left arm. The pain started while he was mowing his lawn and seemed to get better with rest. He also reports associated symptoms of nausea  shortness of breath  and diaphoresis although denies any related lightheadedness or fainting. The patient's blood pressure is elevated at 160/95 mmHg and his BMI is in the obese range. His blood sugar levels have been inconsistently controlled and an HbA1c taken 3 months ago was 8.6%. He previously had a normal stress test around 2 years ago but has not had any more recent cardiac workup. The presentation and history suggest the possibility of coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  former smoker  with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and obesity. He presents to the outpatient clinic with a 2-week history of episodic chest discomfort that radiates to his left shoulder and typically occurs with walking for more than two blocks but resolves with rest. The patient also reports associated symptoms of dyspnea on exertion  mild diaphoresis  and occasional lightheadedness. These symptoms limit his ability to engage in physical activities  leading to a marked decrease in his quality of life. The patient has a 10-year history of dyslipidemia and hypertension  both of which have been managed with diet  exercise  and medication. He was a smoker for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He has a family history of premature coronary artery disease; his father suffered a myocardial infarction at age 55. He denies any history of illicit drug use  alcohol abuse  palpitations  syncopal episodes  or lower extremity edema. His BMI is 30 (height: 180 cm; weight: 97 kg). Blood pressure: 142/92 mmHg; pulse: 82 bpm; blood glucose: 206 mg/dl; total cholesterol: 262 mg/dl; LDL: 162 mg/dl; HDL: 32 mg/dl; triglycerides: 270 mg/dl.

Patient: 64-year-old African American male  Medical History: Hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  smoking (~20 pack years)  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with chest discomfort occurring predominantly during physical exertion or emotional stress. He describes the pain as a central  squeezing pain radiating to his left arm accompanied by shortness of breath. Pain severity is approximately a 7 out of 10  lasting 10–20 minutes  and resolves with rest. He has been noticing this pattern for the past two weeks.  Signs on Presentation: On physical examination  blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse is 75 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 16 per minute  and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Examination of the precordium reveals no heaves or lifts. Heart sounds S1 and S2 are normal with no murmurs or rubs. There is no peripheral edema noted. The rest of the physical exam is unremarkable.  Pertinent Labs/Imaging: Fasting lipid panel reveals cholesterol 220 mg/dL  LDL 140 mg/dl  HDL 35 mg/dl  and triglycerides 200mg/dl. Random blood sugar is 175mg/dl. EKG shows T wave inversions in leads V1-V3.   Brief Assessment: This patient with a strong cardiovascular disease risk profile (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and tobacco use) presents with chest pain that is exertional and relieved with rest  raising suspicion of stable angina secondary to coronary artery disease. Urgent diagnostic intervention (like stress testing or coronary angiography) and lifestyle modifications are required for confirmation and management of suspected disease.

Patient Profile: Age: 70 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Presenting Issue:  John Doe presents to the clinic with a recent history of chest discomfort  especially under physical exertion. He also reports shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasionally  nausea.   Relevant Medical History: He has a known history of Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a 30-year history of smoking  but quit 5 years ago. His father passed away from a heart attack at 75  suggesting a family history of cardiac disease.   Problem Representation: 70 years old male patient with risk factors including a history of Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  past smoking  and family history of heart disease  now presents with classic symptoms of coronary artery disease such as chest discomfort (especially with physical exertion)  shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional nausea.

A 65-year-old African American male patient with a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the ER with complaints of moderate to severe chest pain radiating to his left shoulder and shortness of breath. He reports the pain feels like ""heavy pressure."" The patient also states he has a prior tobacco use history of 20 years but quit 10 years ago. He has episodes of similar  but less severe  discomfort for the past one week. He does not comply with his prescribed antihypertensive and hyperlipidemia medications and maintains an unhealthy high-fat diet. His family history reveals that his father had a heart attack at the age of 58. The patient does not report any drug or alcohol abuse. His BMI is 30.2 kg/m2 indicating obesity. His blood pressure upon admission was 155/95 mmHg  heart rate of 98 beats/min  respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation was 96% in room air.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a history of smoking  presenting with a 2 hour history of midsternal chest pain  radiating to the left arm  associated with diaphoresis and dyspnea. He rates the pain at 8 out of 10 on pain scale  stating the onset was at rest and did not alleviate with nitroglycerin. He reports that this is the first occurrence of this type of chest pain. He has a family history of CAD with his father having an MI in his late 60s. He is retired and is married with 2 children. He admits to being non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication  metformin for his diabetes  and has a 30-pack year history of smoking  though he quit 5 years ago. Prior lipid panel showed high LDL cholesterol. On physical examination he is anxious  diaphoretic with stable vitals except for an elevated blood pressure of 160/94 mmHg. Cardiac examination revealed normal heart sounds  no murmurs or rubs. Lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdominal and neurological examinations were within normal limits. No peripheral edema was noted. The rest of the examination was unremarkable. His EKG showed ST segment elevation in the anterior leads  suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Problem Representation:  A 62-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes presents with dull  steady chest pain radiating to his left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath  fatigue  and mild diaphoresis. Pains started intermittently a couple of weeks ago and have increased in frequency. The patient reports the pain seems more intense upon exertion  primarily during his evening walks around the neighborhood.   He also reports a 20-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily but quit 5 years ago. His last annual medical checkup was about 1 year ago  where his blood test results showed hyperlipidemia. He adheres to his anti-hypertensive  anti-diabetic  and statin medications. There is a family history of early coronary artery disease in his father  who died of a heart attack at the age of 58. Although he claims adherence to his medication regimen  he confesses his diet could be better.   On examination  vital signs are stable; however  cardiovascular examination reveals decreased breath sounds in both lung bases  palpable heave on the left sternal edge  and a grade 2/6 systolic murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space. The rest of the examination is noncontributory.    His EKG onsite shows T wave inversion. His symptoms  supported by his significant cardiac risk factors - African American ethnicity  male gender  uncontrolled diabetes  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  family history of early coronary artery disease  and finally previous smoking habit  all contribute to a high likelihood of coronary artery disease. Immediate attention and management of his condition are required.  This case is compatible with epidemiological data - Coronary artery disease usually presents in men over the age of 60 and is more common in those of African American ethnicity. The presence of comorbid risk factors  such as Type 2 Diabetes and hypertension  are consistent with actualities in many patients with this disease. Also  family history and previous smoking are significant risk factors for coronary artery disease. The presenting symptoms of chest pain  especially on exertion  shortness of breath  and fatigue  along with the patient's medical history and demographic factors align well with what is generally present in patients with coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of high blood pressure  type 2 diabetes  and dyslipidemia  who presents with a three-week history of intermittent chest pain radiating to his left arm. The chest pain is primarily exertional  lasting for about 10-15 minutes and relieved by rest. Previously the pain used to occur after walking for about 6 blocks  however  lately  it starts after walking for about half a block or going up a flight of stairs. He reports similar pain while shoveling snow last week. He has also noted increased fatigue and shortness of breath with minimal effort. He denies syncope  dizziness or palpitations. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history  but quit 10 years ago. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 52.   Physical examination reveals an overweight male in no acute distress. Vital signs are T: 98.2 °F  HR: 72 bpm  BP: 147/92 mm Hg  RR: 16/min  and SpO2: 96% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rate and rhythm  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lungs are clear bilaterally  and no lower extremity edema is noted. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. His last HbA1c was 8.4% and the most recent LDL level was 142 mg/dL while being on atorvastatin 20mg daily.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He presents with complaints of intermittent chest discomfort at rest occurring over the past three weeks. The discomfort is described as a squeezing feeling at the center of his chest that occasionally radiates to the left arm. He mentions having episodes of shortness of breath after minimal activity such as walking up the stairs. He has been adherent with his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. He is a former smoker  with a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and has no known drug allergies. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. There is no current fever  cough  or any urinary symptoms. The patient is currently retired  living with a wife and does not report any recent travels or illnesses in close contacts. The patient appears alert  awake  and well oriented during the consultation.   Vital signs are as follows: temperature of 37.5°C  pulse rate of 80 beats per minute  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals an overweight individual with a body mass index (BMI) of 28. He has normal heart sounds with no murmurs or additional sounds.   The patient's symptoms seem consistent with angina pectoris  suggestive of underlying coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 63-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus presenting with complaints of chest pain for the past several hours. The pain is described as a pressure-like sensation that radiates down the left arm  associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. Patient noted similar  but less severe  symptoms over the past few weeks during his daily activities  particularly while mowing the lawn. He is a 45-pack-year smoker  is overweight with a BMI of 29  and leads a sedentary lifestyle. He admits to suboptimal compliance with his prescribed medications and has a family history of heart problems. On physical exam  the patient appears uncomfortable  vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg  heart rate of 92 beats/min  and his electrocardiogram taken immediately showed ST-segment depression indicative of myocardial ischemia. This presentation is concerning for acute coronary syndrome secondary to underlying coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  is a retired accountant who presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of intermittent chest pain. The pain is described as a heavy  squeezing discomfort that radiates to his left arm and occasionally to the jaw. It usually occurs during physical activity or stress and resolves with rest. Mr. Doe has been experiencing episodes lasting for about 10 to 15 minutes.   Patient's Past Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. All conditions are controlled with medication- Lisinopril for hypertension  Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia and Metformin for Diabetes Mellitus. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history  though he quit smoking 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally. His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg  heart rate is regular at 72 bpm  and BMI is 28 kg/m2. He is afebrile  with an oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Cardiovascular exam reveals no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. His chest discomfort occurs during the treadmill exercise stress test.  Based on the patient's clinical history  clinical presentation  and physical examination  there is a high suspicion of coronary artery disease. This is clearly an unstable pattern and likely indicates progressive coronary disease. Further diagnostic testing will be necessary  which may include a coronary angiogram for definitive diagnosis.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco smoking 1 pack/day for 30 years  who presents to the cardiology clinic with a 2-week history of recurrent exertional chest pain  which he describes as a central chest pressure occurring mainly during physical exertion and lasts about 5-10 minutes  subsiding with rest. The pain radiates to his left arm and is occasionally associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis and nausea. He also reports having decreased exercise tolerance  as he begins to experience these symptoms even with less demanding activities. He denies any episodes of syncope or symptoms at rest. He has no history of diabetes or previous cardiovascular events. His father had his first myocardial infarction at 60. The patient's medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Physical examination shows a mildly obese man  blood pressure of 140/85 mm Hg  pulse of 75 bpm  and a noticeable delay in the femoral pulse as compared to the radial pulse. Cardiovascular examination reveals normal heart sounds with no additional sounds or murmurs. His EKG shows minor ST-T wave changes in the chest leads. The patient's clinical picture suggests stable angina due to coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 65-year-old African American male with a history of obesity (BMI 35)  type II diabetes mellitus  and hypertension  presenting with ongoing  central  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm accompanied by shortness of breath and diaphoresis. The patient reports occasional episodes of similar chest pain during strenuous activities over the past 2 months  relieved by rest  but this episode persisted and was more intense. The patient has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications  and has a 20-pack-year history of smoking. He denies any familial history of coronary artery disease  but his elder brother had a stroke in his early 70s. Review of symptoms is negative for orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and lower extremity edema. A diet history review reveals a high intake of fatty foods and processed meats  along with a sedentary lifestyle.

Patient Representation:  Our patient is a 56-year-old African American male with a known history of coronary artery disease  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  who presents complaining of intermittent episodes of crushing  sub-sternal chest pain for the past two days. The pain seems to be exacerbated by physical exertion and emotional stress but is relieved by rest. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. He reports smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and a diet high in saturated fats. His medications include Atenolol  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He has a family history of premature cardiovascular diseases with his father having died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 62. On examination  his blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/90 mmHg and he appears to be overweight.  This representation describes an individual with risk factors commonly associated with coronary artery disease  including African American ethnicity  male gender  middle-age  family history of premature disease  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  sedentary lifestyle with poor diet  and smoking habits.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and a 45-year pack-year smoking history who presents with central  squeezing chest pain radiating to the left arm  transient diaphoresis  and dyspnea  symptoms consistent with angina pectoris. The chest pain has been occurring intermittently over the past two months  more frequently when exerting himself physically  but also noted at rest. He admits to feeling increasingly fatigued over the same period. The patient also reports unintentional 10-pound weight loss over the last six months  decreased appetite  and occasional bouts of mild nausea. Family history is significant for father having had a myocardial infarction at age 62.

Patient Profile: A 61-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: The patient has a history of Hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  both of which are well managed with medication. He was a smoker for 20 years but quit 5 years ago. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases - his father died of a heart attack at the age of 64. He has a sedentary lifestyle and is obese (BMI 30.5 kg/m2).  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with recurring episodes of severe chest pain  particularly during physical exertion  which gets relieved during rest. The pain is characterized as pressure-like  located centrally and radiating to the left shoulder and arm. Occasionally  he also experiences shortness of breath and bouts of excessive sweating. These symptoms have increased in frequency and duration over the past month.  Impression: This symptom constellation suggestive of stable angina  a common presentation of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Given his demographic profile combined with several risk factors such as age  gender  obesity  smoking history  hypertension  diabetes  and family history of CAD; this presents a high suspicion for significant CAD. These symptoms warrant further investigation  such as lab tests  EKG  and potentially cardiac stress testing or angiography. Prompt cardiology consultation and management is essential to prevent possible progression to acute coronary syndrome.

Patient Profile: Mr. John Miller  a 65-year-old African American man  working as a school teacher hailing from an urban area.  Presenting Problem: Mr. Miller approached his primary care physician complaining of recurrent chest pain and dyspnea on exertion over the past two months. The chest discomfort typically occurs after physical activity or eating a large meal and usually subsides with rest.  Relevant Medical History: He has a documented history of Type II diabetes mellitus controlled with Metformin for the last 10 years  and hypertension managed with Amlodipine for 8 years. Additionally  he has a 30 pack-year smoking history  and mild obesity (BMI of 31).  Relevant Symptoms on Presentation: On presentation  Mr. Miller appears in no acute distress. He describes the chest pain as ""squeezing"" and ""pressure-like""  with occasional radiation to his left arm. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath following exertion  such as climbing stairs or walking a few blocks. He denies palpitations  syncope  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.   Given his medical history  risk factors(as diabetes  hypertension  smoking  obesity)  and presenting symptoms  Mr. Miller is suspected to have coronary artery disease  and further investigations are warranted. His age  ethnicity  and gender are also considered risk factors  as African American men have a higher risk for developing coronary artery disease in their 60s and 70s.

Patient Information: A 64-year-old African American male  known smoker with a 20 pack-year history.  Chief Complaint: Recurrent chest discomfort especially during physical activity over the past month  along with occasional bouts of shortness of breath.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports that the chest pain initially occurred around a month ago  which he attributed to indigestion. The pain  described as dull  tight  and occurring in the center of his chest  has gradually increased in frequency and severity with physical exertion  particularly walking up an incline or lifting heavy objects. Occasionally  it radiates to his left arm and is associated with shortness of breath. Each episode usually subsides within 5-10 minutes of rest. Symptoms seemed to be somewhat relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin that his brother  a known heart patient  offered him.   Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril) and type 2 diabetes managed with diet and Metformin. No prior history of angina  myocardial infarction  stroke  or peripheral artery disease. No known drug allergies.  Family History: Both his father and older brother had premature coronary artery disease (CAD) in their 50s. His mother passed away due to complications from type 2 diabetes.  Social History: The patient is a retired truck driver  smokes 1 pack/day for the past 40 years  occasionally drinks alcohol  does not exercise regularly.   Review of Systems: Negative for fever  cough  palpitations  syncope  lower extremity swelling  and changes in bowel or bladder habits.   Physical Exam: Vital signs are within normal limits. Chest is clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac auscultation reveals regular rate and rhythm; no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Abdomen is soft  non-tender. Extremities show no edema or cyanosis.  Based on the above  the patient's clinical presentation is consistent with stable angina  underlining the possibility of CAD which is common and severe in the African American population. Further diagnostic confirmation is required to develop an appropriate management plan.

Patient Information: A 63-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: The patient  a retired mechanic  has a notable history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia  along with a 30-year history of moderate-to-heavy cigarette smoking. There is a family history of early-onset coronary artery disease (CAD)  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at 55.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with a several-week history of progressive chest discomfort experienced primarily upon exertion  which has begun to interfere with his day-to-day activities. The chest pain is characterized as a gripping discomfort  radiating to his left arm and neck  and typically lasts for about 10 minutes  subsiding with rest. It is occasionally associated with shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea. Additionally  he reports increased fatigue and episodes of lightheadedness over the past month. He denies any symptoms of orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or leg swelling.  Interpretation: Given the patient's age  sex  significant past medical history  longstanding smoking habit  family history and presenting symptoms  the primary concern is stable angina pectoris secondary to likely coronary artery disease. Further diagnostic evaluation including ECG stress testing or coronary angiography is needed to confirm diagnosis and assess severity.   It's noteworthy that CAD is a leading cause of mortality and morbidity worldwide. It is more common among males  and age is a significant risk factor with prevalence increasing significantly after the age of 60. History of dyslipidemia  hypertension  diabetes  smoking  and a positive family history of premature CAD are well-known risk factors. Classic clinical presentation is exertional chest pain (angina)  which can be associated with additional symptoms like dyspnea  perspiration  lightheadedness  syncope  or fatigue.

Patient Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents with gradually worsening exertional chest pain for the past eight weeks  especially after heavy meals. Accompanied symptoms include shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional dizziness. Current comorbidities include hypertension and dyslipidemia  for which he has been on diet control and oral antihypertensives for the past 15 years. Patient has a history of smoking 1 pack/day for 20 years  but quit 10 years ago. His BMI is 28  and he leads a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activity. His father had myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  On examination  the patient is afebrile with a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  pulse 82 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 14 per minute. No edema in the lower extremities. Cardiac auscultation notes regular rhythm and rate without any murmurs or added sounds. His EKG shows T wave inversions in leads II  III  and aVF. His labs report elevated levels of cholesterol  LDL  and triglycerides; however  blood glucose levels are within the normal range. He is diagnosed with coronary artery disease.

Patient Profile: A 67-year-old African American male  Mr. J  living in an urban setting.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  with poor medication adherence overall. He quit smoking cigarettes 5 years ago but he had a 30-pack year history prior to cessation. He also has dyslipidemia. He has a family history of early onset cardiovascular disease; his father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 58.  Clinical Presentation:  Over the past four months  Mr. J developed progressive exertional chest discomfort that radiated to his left arm. Initially  the chest discomfort occurred while carrying grocery bags up two flights of stairs to his apartment  but more recently  it occurred while walking on level ground for about two city blocks. The chest discomfort is relieved by resting for about 5 minutes. In the past week  he also experienced diaphoresis and dyspnea coinciding with the episode of chest pain. He has no reported symptoms of syncope  palpitations  or lower extremity edema. His BMI is 32  and his blood pressure is consistently ranging 140-150/90-100 mmHg.  These recurrent episodes of chest pain associated with exertion and relieved by rest  lasting more than a few minutes  strongly suggest stable angina due to coronary artery disease. Associated symptoms of diaphoresis and dyspnea raise suspicion of a turbulent flow or ischemia  and his overall risk is elevated due to non-compliance to antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. Further diagnostic testing is recommended to confirm the diagnosis and guide the intervention.

Problem Representation:  A 63-year-old male with a history of smoking and hypertension reports to the emergency department with an escalating onset of chest pain over the past 24 hours. The patient describes the pain as ""squeezing"" in nature  located in the center of the chest  radiating to the left arm. This episode was precipitated by moderate exertion and unsuccessfully relieved with rest  escalating over time. The patient also reports associated symptoms of dyspnea  diaphoresis  nausea  and a fainting spell. He denies any changes in bowel or bladder habits  recent weight loss  or fever. Family history is relevant for a father who died of a heart attack at age 58. On physical exam  the patient is diaphoretic and displays signs of distress  with vital signs showing blood pressure 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate 88 beats/min  and respiratory rate 20 breaths/min.  The given symptoms and medical history suggest the patient is having an acute myocardial infarction secondary to chronic coronary artery disease. Immediate medical intervention is required to confirm diagnosis and treatment plan  which may include medications  lifestyle modifications  and possibly surgical interventions.

Problem Representation:   A 60-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking presents with progressive exertional chest pain over the past several months. The pain is characterized as a crushing sensation  radiating to his left arm  associated with shortness of breath and relief upon rest. The patient also reports occasional episodes of diaphoresis and nausea. Physical examination reveals blood pressure of 150/90mmHg and presence of xanthomas. The EKG indicates ST depression. The patient's father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. The patient has been non-compliant with his medications including his antihypertensive and statins. He is a retired blue-collar worker with a 40 pack-year smoking history. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. The clinical presentation coupled with risk factors such as smoking  age  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  family history of heart disease  and lack of medication compliance suggests a diagnosis of coronary artery disease.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both maintained well under medication. He was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia 5 years ago. A former smoker who quit 15 years ago  but with a 20-year smoking history. He is overweight with a BMI of 28 and has a known family history of coronary artery disease (his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  his older brother had a cardiac bypass at 60).  Presenting Complaints: The patient complains of recurrent episodes of chest discomfort  particularly during physical exertion or emotional stress  that usually resolves with rest. The pain is usually described as pressure-like or like ""an elephant sitting on my chest"" given in the central part of his chest  occasionally radiating towards his left arm. The patient also noted episodes of shortness of breath during exertion.  Physical Examination and Investigative Findings: Upon examination  blood pressure is at 150/90 mmHg and resting heart rate is 80 bpm. Chest auscultation reveals no abnormality. An electrocardiogram shows T-wave inversions in the anterior wall leads. Stress test shows significant ST depression.   Working Diagnosis: Given the patient's demographics  history  clinical symptoms and investigative findings  a working diagnosis of coronary artery disease is made.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old African American male sales technician.  Medical History: Patient has a known history of hypertension controlled with medication for the past 15 years  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus with suboptimal control. Patient is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history  but quit 10 years ago. He reports no known drug allergies.  Presenting Symptoms: Patient presents with episodes of central chest pain radiating down to the left arm for the past month  especially during physical exertion such as climbing stairs or heavy lifting at work  but the pain typically subsides with rest. He also reports of increased shortness of breath with minimal activity like walking and an episode of fainting last week. Patient also complains of feeling unexplainably fatigued for the last two weeks.  Emerging Problem: Likely symptomatic coronary artery disease (CAD)-stable angina given the exertional chest pain that subsides with rest  dyspnea on exertion  fatigue  and syncope. Comorbidities including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking history  and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes pose as significant risk factors. Obesity has not been confirmed but can be elucidated through further examination. Prompt evaluation with EKG  stress testing  or possibly cardiac catheterization will be warranted. Future management will necessitate aggressive cardiovascular risk factor modification and consideration for revascularization depending on severity of findings.

Problem Representation:  A 62-year-old African American male  with a history of smoking (15 pack years) and type 2 diabetes  presents with new-onset  exertional chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain has been recurring for the past 3 weeks and is getting more frequent and severe. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath and fatigue. The patient has no known allergies and his current medication regimen includes metformin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril.

Patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  who currently presents with worsening exertional chest discomfort over the past month. He does not report any cough  fever  recent travel  or sick contacts. He has a 45-pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 10 years ago. He has a family history of coronary artery disease - his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.

Problem Representation:  Mr. B.  a 64-year-old Caucasian male with a history of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension  presents with dull  persistent chest discomfort and diaphoresis. The chest discomfort  described as “pressure”  is located in the center of his chest and radiates to the left arm. It has been intermittently lasting for 30 minutes at a time over the past three days. Despite attributing the pain initially to indigestion  it has not been relieved by over-the-counter antacids. The symptoms are more pronounced during his routine morning walks. He admits to an increase in fatigue and shortness of breath over the past couple of weeks. He also reports a weight gain of about 10 pounds over the last two months due to lifestyle changes as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. He is a former smoker  quit 20 years ago  and consumes alcohol socially. His father had a myocardial infarction at 62. Medication includes Metformin and Lisinopril. He is non-compliant with his medications. Furthermore  he reports that his blood glucose levels have been consistently elevated for the past few weeks. BMI is 28. BP is 150/95 mmHg  pulse 90/min  RR 16/min. Upon physical examination  there is no cyanosis  but there is mild pedal edema noted bilaterally. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation and heart sounds are normal with no murmurs. All the mentioned features in the history raise high suspicion for coronary artery disease (CAD)  potential ischemia or an impending acute coronary syndrome could be the cause of his symptoms.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired  known hypertensive on medication  and diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus Type II five years ago. He has experienced episodes of shortness of breath and occasional dizzy spells. He also suffers from persistent fatigue despite adequate rest. He denies syncope  palpitations  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He is a former smoker  having smoked one pack per day for 40 years before quitting 10 years ago. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and admits to having a high-fat diet. Of note  he has had no history of other cardiac diseases or surgical procedures. On physical examination  his resting heart rate is 80 bpm  BP: 140/90 mmHg  and his BMI classified as overweight. Auscultation reveals no cardiac murmurs. The patient has normal first and second heart sounds; lungs are clear to auscultation. Other systems are unremarkable.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old African-American male.  Medical History: Patient has a 10-year history of hypertension  well controlled with medication. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago  for which he is on metformin. His family history reveals his father died from myocardial infarction at age 68. Patient is an ex-smoker  quit 15 years ago  and admits to being a regular consumer of alcohol but in moderate amounts. He does not undertake any specific physical activity. Problem Representation: A 65-year-old African-American male with prominent risk factors for coronary artery disease  including age  race  male gender  family history of premature heart disease  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  history of smoking  and a sedentary lifestyle  presenting with classic angina symptoms and exertional breathlessness  suggestive of possible coronary artery disease.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver   Medical History: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has been a smoker for 40+ years with average of 20 cigarettes/day. There is a family history of premature cardiovascular disease with the patient's father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 57.  Presenting Complaint: Came to the clinic reporting increasing episodes of chest pain over the last 3 months. The pain is described as a pressure-like sensation  situated in the substernal region  and often radiates to the left arm. Episodes typically last 5-10 minutes and are triggered by physical activity  such as walking or heavy lifting  but is relieved by rest or nitroglycerin use. Recently  he has also suffered from episodes of breathlessness on exertion  fatigue  and occasional light-headedness. These symptoms are reducing his capacity to carry out daily activities.   On physical examination: Blood pressure is elevated at 155/95 mmHg. He is overweight with a BMI of 29. Some peripheral pitting edema is noted in his ankles. The rest of the cardiovascular  respiratory  and abdominal examination is unremarkable.   This clinical scenario is suggestive of stable angina secondary to significant coronary artery disease in a patient with multiple recognized cardiovascular risk factors including older age  male sex  smoking  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia and family history of early onset coronary artery disease. Based off the clinical history  the patient fulfills criteria for high risk stable chest pain as per NICE guidelines  hence  further assessment and management is indicated.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Sex: Male - Age: 65 years old - Race: White  - Occupation: Retired  previously worked in a high-stress job (e.g.  corporate executive) - Socio-economic status: Middle- upper-class - Residential history: Lives in a suburban neighborhood - Marital status: Married - Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle  irregular exercise habits - Dietary habits: Preference for high cholesterol  high sodium  and sugary food   Past Medical history: - Hypertension (high blood pressure) diagnosed at the age of 55 - History of smoking for 30 years  quit smoking 5 years ago - Diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus at 60 years of age - Had a mild stroke two years ago with full recovery - Regularly takes medication for blood pressure and diabetes - Family history of coronary artery disease; father passed away at 70 due to heart attack  - Previous cholesterol levels often in the borderline high to high range    Presenting Complaints: - Chronic stable angina; characterized by chest pain and discomfort - Shortness of breath  especially during physical exertion - Occasional dizziness and fatigue - Sleep problems and anxiety  potentially related to chronic heart disease - Recent episode of uncharacteristic sweating and nausea  suspected to be unstable angina  Clinical Indicators: - High blood pressure (140/90 mm Hg) - High cholesterol (LDL -190 mg/dL) - Body Mass Index (BMI) – 30 (Category: Obese) - High blood glucose levels (HbA1c - 7.5%)  This representation is based on a typical case of coronary artery disease  which is commonly associated with older age  male sex  hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and a history of smoking. The family history of heart disease and previous stroke also add to the risk. The symptoms  hypertension  high cholesterol and high blood glucose levels are indicative of a possible worsening of the patient's condition.
