Learning Points This case highlights the importance of symptom recognition and early intervention in CAD. The patient’s non-compliance to medication regimen aggravated her risk factors. Regular follow-ups and medication compliance are crucial elements of disease management that cannot be overlooked. Furthermore  lifestyle interventions are equally essential in managing and preventing progression of CAD.  Despite being female and reported to have a lower incidence of CAD  her risk was elevated due to the presence of multiple risk factors such as hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  smoking  lack of physical activity  overweight  family history and advanced age. This illustrates that CAD is not exclusive to males  especially in the presence of significant risk factors.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Profile:  The patient is a 68-year-old African American male  retired office worker  referred to our cardiology department from the primary care clinic due to symptoms consistent with coronary artery disease. The patient is married  has two children  is a resident of the Midlands  South Carolina  United States  and frequently attends a local church as his primary social activity. Smokes one pack of cigarettes per day  a habit he has maintained for over 45 years. He admits to regular consumption of alcohol  primarily on weekends  and admits to a sedentary lifestyle and unhealthy diet rich in fats and processed foods.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known past medical history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus  for which he takes 2.5 mg of Ramipril daily and 1000 mg of Metformin twice daily. The patient's father and paternal uncle also had coronary artery disease; his father suffered a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 65. There is no history of stroke or other cardiovascular diseases reported in the family. The patient's BMI was noted to be 30  obtained from a weight of 200 pounds and a height of 5’9'’  an indication of obesity.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient reported experiencing moderate to severe episodes of chest pain that radiates to the left shoulder and lower jaw. Episodes are often precipitated by physical exertion or emotional stress. Symptoms are relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. He also reported shortness of breath  especially when climbing stairs or walking more than two blocks.  Clinical Examination and Diagnosis:  Cardiac auscultation revealed normal first and second heart sounds with no audible murmurs. The patient's blood pressure was 148/90 mmHg  which was high. An ECG indicated signs of possible previous myocardial infarction. Lipid panel showed elevated LDL cholesterol (140 mg/dL) and Total cholesterol (210 mg/dL)  reduced HDL cholesterol (35mg/dL)  and elevated triglycerides (300 mg/dL). Fasting blood glucose was 156 mg/dL.   Given the patient's age  obesity  lifestyle behavior  family history of premature coronary artery disease  and hypertension combined with hyperlipidemia  the patient was diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD) through a coronary angiogram  which showed two-vessel disease  including 70% stenosis of the left anterior descending artery and 60% stenosis of the right coronary artery.  Management and Follow Up:  The patient was started on Aspirin 81mg  Rosuvastatin 20 mg every night  and Metoprolol 25mg twice daily  with continuation of antihypertensive and antidiabetic medication. A comprehensive approach including smoking cessation  dietary modification  and regular physical activity was emphasized for managing the disease. The patient is scheduled for follow-up in three months to reassess symptoms and monitor treatment progress. Subsequent management will be tailored further based on follow-up evaluation.   This case represents a common presentation for CAD in the African American geriatric population with common risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia.

Title: A Case Report on a 65-year-old African American Male with Coronary Artery Disease  1. Patient Information  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male  retired  married  and a resident of New York. He is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. He has a BMI of 27  and his family history reveals both parents and a sibling having succumbed to cardiovascular disease complications in their 60s.   2. Chief Complaint  The patient came with a chief complaint of a recurring chest discomfort  notable during his slight physical exertions like climbing stairs or walking fast. He mentioned that the pain usually eases off with rest and usually lasts about five to fifteen minutes.  3. History of Present Illness  For the past two months  the patient has been experiencing episodes of chest pain that seemed to worsen with physical activity and intensifies under stress. No patterns related to meal intake or sleep were noted.   4. Past Medical History  The patient is known to have a controlled hypertension diagnosed eight years prior and hyperlipidemia diagnosed five years ago  maintained well on medication. There is no known history of diabetes mellitus or other chronic medical conditions.  5. Review of Systems  Apart from chest discomfort  he reports shortness of breath  occasional restlessness  or a sense of impending doom during the angina attacks. However  he denies episodes of sweating  syncope  nausea  or vomiting.  6. Physical Examination  He appeared anxious  but his vital signs were within normal limits. There was no cyanosis  clubbing  or peripheral edema. Normal heart sounds were present with no additional murmurs. His blood pressure was slightly elevated  but not alarming (150/85 mmHg)  and his oxygen saturation was maintained at 97%.  7. Diagnostic Assessment  An Electrocardiogram showed ST-segment depression suggestive of underlying myocardial ischemia. High-sensitivity troponin levels were within normal limits  ruling out a myocardial infarction. Lipid profile showed elevated total cholesterol and LDL levels.   The patient underwent a stress test  which demonstrated significant ST depressions  further suggestive of ischemia. Coronary angiography was subsequently performed and revealed significant stenosis in the left anterior descending artery  consistent with coronary artery disease.  8. Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was managed conservatively with dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin plus clopidogrel) and a high-intensity statin. His antihypertensive therapy was reviewed and optimized. He was referred to a cardiologist for possible revascularization therapy (PCI/CABG) based on the angiogram results.   The patient and his family were extensively counseled regarding lifestyle modifications  including a regimen of regular exercise  healthy diet  weight management  and stress management. The importance of medication adherence was reinforced.  9. Follow-Up  A close follow-up plan was designed for the patient including a repeat lipid profile  cardiac function assessment  and regular outpatient clinic visits to monitor his symptoms and assess response to the intervention.  10. Patient Consent  Informed written consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images.  This case report emphasizes the pivotal role of early detection and prompt management of coronary artery disease  particularly in individuals with high risk such as our patient - given age  race  male gender  genetic predisposition  and additional risk factors like hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

Patient Information:  An 82-year-old African American male residing in North Carolina  United States  was presented for evaluation due to persistent chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient is widowed  Catholic  and retired after working for over 40 years as a truck driver. He currently lives with his daughter and her family. He is covered by Medicare insurance.  Medical History:  The patient has an extensive medical history  including a 30-year history of Type II Diabetes and moderate renal insufficiency. His Diabetes is currently under control through diet and oral medication (Metformin). He also has been previously diagnosed with essential hypertension  for which he is on Amlodipine and Losartan. He does not have any known allergies to medications. Apart from these  the patient has lived a relatively healthy life  with his last hospitalization over twenty years ago due to a minor operation for a hernia.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient reported severe episodes of chest pain which he described as ""pressure"" on his chest  occasionally radiates to his left upper arm  and shortness of breath  aggravated by minimal physical activity. He also reported a frequent feeling of exhaustion and episodes of dizziness.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient appeared sweaty and in distress due to chest pain. His vitals recorded were as follows: BP - 170/90 mm Hg  HR - 100 bpm  RR - 22 breaths per minute  Temperature - 36.8°C  and Oxygen saturation - 90% on room air. On auscultation  his heart sounds were regular without any murmur or gallop and lung fields were clear.  Investigations:  His lipid profile showed high LDL cholesterol (180mg/dL) and relatively low HDL cholesterol (30mg/dL). Cardiac enzymes drawn showed a troponin level of 0.04ng/ml (normal <.03ng/ml). Further testing unveiled an elevated blood glucose level of 180mg/dL and impaired renal function with a creatinine level of 1.8mg/dL. ECG performed demonstrated signs consistent with ischemia  notably ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion. Subsequent coronary angiography confirmed significant obstructive disease in the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and left circumflex artery (LCX).  Diagnosis:  The patient was diagnosed with Unstable Angina secondary to Severe Coronary Artery Disease.  Management:  Treatment was initiated with sublingual Nitroglycerin for acute relief of the chest pain and increased dosage of his antihypertensive medications in order to control his blood pressure. Aspirin and a high dose statin were also commenced. A decision was made for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) targeting both the LAD and LCX lesions which was performed successfully without any procedural complications.  After PCI  cardiac rehabilitation was recommended  along with counseling for lifestyle modification  including smoking cessation  regular physical activity  and a healthy diet. He was also referred for close follow-up in the outpatient clinic with a cardiologist and an endocrinologist.   Informed consent:  The patient provided informed consent for his case report to be published.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Presentation  The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian male standing 5'10"" tall  weighing 210 lbs with a BMI of 30.1. He is presented in the clinic with the chief complaints of frequent episodes of chest discomfort associated with shortness of breath and light-headedness that increasingly occur even at rest. The pain reportedly radiates to his left arm and is frequently accompanied by a sensation of nausea. He lives in a middle-class suburban neighborhood with his wife  is a retired army officer  and reports a 30-pack per year history of smoking tobacco  though he quit five years ago. He reports consuming alcohol on social occasions.   Past Medical History  The patient has a history of type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) diagnosed at the age of 50 and is managed on Metformin (twice daily dose of 500mg). His mother died of a myocardial infarction in her seventies  and his 69-year-old sibling has T2DM and hypertension. He has been treated for high cholesterol (on statin therapy with Atorvastatin 20mg per day) and hypertension (metoprolol 50mg twice daily). He has never been prescribed anticoagulants and reports no allergies or drug sensitivities.   Clinical Findings  Physical examination reveals a body temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F)  pulse rate of 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and arterial blood pressure of 148/90 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 95% while breathing room air. Cardiac examination reveals distant heart sounds and a soft systolic murmur. His lungs are clear and other systems are unremarkable. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows T-wave inversions in the inferolateral leads. Blood tests revealed slightly raised troponin I (0.04 ng/mL; normal range: <0.03 ng/mL) and a HbA1c of 7.2% indicating suboptimal control of his diabetes.  Impression  Based on the findings of history taking along with physical examination and investigations done  he was diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD). His age  gender  smoking history  hypertension  dyslipidemia  and family history of cardiac disease put him in a high-risk category for CAD. Management has included dual antiplatelet therapy  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and beta-blockers. Patient has been counseled about lifestyle modifications including healthier dietary choices  moderate exercise  weight loss  and strict diabetic control.   Follow Up  The patient was taken for a coronary angiogram that revealed significant three-vessel disease. Percutaneous coronary intervention was initially considered. However  given the patient's three-vessel disease and diabetes  coronary artery bypass grafting was considered the best therapeutic option. He has been referred to discuss further management with a cardiothoracic surgeon.  This case stresses how important it is to screen and initiate appropriate treatment for at-risk individuals in a primary care setting. By considering coronary artery disease in the differential diagnosis  the primary care physician can act promptly  possibly preventing further cardiac damage or even fatal events.

Title: Management of Coronary Artery Disease in a 60-Year-Old African-American Male  Introduction: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality in African-American men. This case study presents the case of a 60-year-old African-American male with CAD  with a focus on his cardiovascular risk factors  diagnosis  treatment approach  and patient adherence to prescribed therapeutic regimens.  Patient Information: Mr. LB  a 60-year-old African-American male  presented to the hospital for a routine health check-up. He is a retired teacher and is currently living a sedentary lifestyle. He has had previous hospital admissions due to angina pectoris. The patient had past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which were diagnosed ten years ago. Mr. LB is also a former smoker who had quit 15 years ago.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  the patient was overweight with a BMI of 29 kg/m^2 and a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  beyond his target blood pressure (<130/80 mmHg). His blood sugar levels were elevated at 180 mg/dl (normal range: 70-110 mg/dl). His electrocardiogram showed ST-segment depression suggestive of ischemia.  Diagnosis: Based on patient history  clinical findings and racial predisposition  a provisional diagnosis of coronary artery disease was made. This was later confirmed through a coronary angiography which revealed a 70% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery.  Therapeutic Intervention: Initial management included lifestyle modifications such as dietary counseling for weight reduction  exercise prescription for at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise daily  and sodium restriction. Pharmacologically  the patient was already on metformin for diabetes. An ACE inhibitor was started for hypertension and the antiplatelet drug  aspirin  was added for his CAD. Statin therapy was also introduced to control his dyslipidemia.  Follow-up and Outcome: Within three months of starting therapy and lifestyle modifications  patient reported a significant decrease in episodes of angina. His blood pressure was reduced to 131/80 mmHg and blood glucose levels were better controlled at 140 mg/dl. The LDL cholesterol level also showed a significant decrease.  Discussion: This case underscores the importance of multi-factorial intervention on lifestyle modification and appropriate medication in managing patients with high cardiovascular risk. CAD is often part of a wider picture of multi-morbidity in patients with hypertension and diabetes  as is seen in this patient  and requires careful management.  Patient Perspective: Mr. LB had an overall positive outlook towards his condition and showed good adherence to the prescribed therapeutic regimens. The decrease in anginal episodes greatly improved his quality of life.  Conclusion: The case of a 60-year-old African-America male with CAD and multiple comorbidities highlights the importance of early identification  risk stratification  and comprehensive management of CAD in preventing further cardiovascular events.  Keywords: Coronary Artery Disease; African-American; Diabetes Mellitus; Hypertension; Lifestyle Modification; Pharmaceutical Management; Patient Adherence.

Title: A Case Report of a 64-Year-Old Hispanic Male with Coronary Artery Disease  Introduction:  Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) is a condition that involves narrowing or blockage of the coronary arteries due to atherosclerosis  further limiting the supply of oxygenated blood to the heart. There are approximately 18.2 million adults aged 20 and older with CAD in the United States  with men having a higher prevalence than women. Hispanics make up the second largest racial/ethnic group in individuals with CAD.   Patient Information:  We report the case of Mr. G  a 64-year-old Hispanic male with a documented diagnosis of CAD. Mr. G was born and raised in Puerto Rico before moving to the United States at the age of 30. His BMI is 27  making him slightly overweight. He is a former smoker  with a history of smoking one pack a day for twenty years  and quit ten years ago. He works as a mechanic and lives with his wife.   Medical History:  A past medical history revealed that Mr. G has a history of hypertension which was diagnosed eight years ago. He is currently on medication (50mg of Metoprolol once daily and 10mg of Lisinopril) and manages his blood pressure through nutritional restrictions and regular physical exercise. He also reported dyslipidemia  managed with 20 mg rosuvastatin. There is a family history of both heart disease and diabetes. His father passed away from a heart attack at 70 and his mother has been living with type II diabetes.  Current Presentation:  Mr. G reported episodes of chest discomfort for the past two months  more specifically following physical efforts such as climbing stairs. These episodes were characterized by a squeezing chest pain radiating towards his left shoulder  usually relieved by rest  and were occasionally accompanied by shortness of breath. ECG revealed evidence of slight ST-segment depression during the episodes of chest pain.   Management and Follow-Up:   The primary care physician referred the patient to a cardiologist for further evaluation. After his assessment  the cardiologist recommended a Trans-Thoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) and a coronary angiogram to delineate the disease severity and distribution throughout the coronary arteries.   Based on the patient's symptoms and past medical history  it was decided that a conservative treatment approach involving lifestyle modification  pharmacotherapy  and vigilant monitoring of the disease should be followed initially. This involved reinforcement of the need for adherence to a low-cholesterol  low-sodium diet  enhanced physical activity  maintaining a healthy weight  and regular follow-ups.   Conclusion:  This case aims to showcase CAD in a Hispanic male  emphasizing the importance of a comprehensive history  diagnostic tools  and the efficacy of conservative management as first-line treatment. Early diagnosis and optimal management of traditional risk factors remain crucial in CAD.  Also  it underscores the complexity in managing a patient with multiple comorbidities and draws attention towards the need for individualized patient care based on disease progression  lifestyle  tolerability  and ethnic/racial backgrounds. In such cases  collaborative efforts between primary care physicians and cardiologists can play a crucial role in preventing major cardiovascular events.

Patient Description  Mr. Ahmed  a 70-year-old South Asian man  born and currently living in Bangladesh  visited the cardiology clinic following a referral from his primary care doctor. He was accompanied by his son. His body mass index calculations showed 29.2 kg/m2 with a weight of 82 kg and a height of 1.70 m  indicating he falls into the obese category.  Medical Complaint  The patient reported a history of recurring chest pain for the past six months  which had been gradually increasing in intensity. The pain was primarily situated in the central left portion of his chest  often radiating to the left shoulder and arm. The discomfort typically occurred during physical exertion and subsided after rest or intake of glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) spray prescribed by his general practitioner.   Past Medical History  He has been diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes 10 years ago and is on regular medications since then (amlodipine 10 mg once daily and metformin 500 mg twice daily). His father had a history of coronary artery disease and had passed away due to a myocardial infarction in his early seventies. Mr. Ahmed is a retired teacher and quit smoking 15 years ago  but he reports a 20 pack-year history. He does not consume alcohol.  Examination Findings  On physical examination  he appeared well. His blood pressure was 142/90 mmHg and his heart rate was 80 beats per minute  regular. He had no jugular venous distention or peripheral edema. Breath sounds were clear and his belly was soft and non-tender. Cardiac examination revealed a regular rhythm with no murmurs  gallops  or rubs.  Investigations  His electrocardiogram displayed ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion in leads V2-V6  I and aVL. Elevated levels of troponin I were found in blood tests. Transthoracic echocardiogram disclosed myocardial wall motion abnormality with preserved ejection fraction. Coronary angiography was done which indicated significant stenosis in the left anterior descending artery and right coronary artery.  Management  Patient was treated with dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors)  beta blockers and statins. He was advised to have percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) considering his significant symptoms and coronary angiogram findings.  While suggesting lifestyle changes  Mr. Ahmed was recommended to introduce a regular  moderate-intensity physical activity program  dietary modifications favoring heart-healthy food choices  and weight management strategies to reduce his BMI. He was also referred to a specialized cardiac rehabilitation program where he can receive supervised exercise training and education to manage his cardiac risk factors.  Follow Up  His symptoms improved significantly after the intervention and he kept his appointment with the cardiac rehabilitation  making slow but steady changes to his lifestyle  subsequently losing weight and controlling his blood sugars and hypertension better.  Case Remarks  Mr. Ahmed's case represents a typical presentation of coronary artery disease (CAD) in an elderly South Asian individual with known risk factors such as obesity  hypertension  diabetes  and personal smoking history. His case underscores the importance of timely diagnosis and intervention along with lifestyle modification in managing CAD.

Title: Case Report: Managing Coronary Arthritis Disease in a Middle-Aged African-American Male  Introduction:   In the midst of the overwhelming global burden of cardiovascular diseases  coronary artery disease (CAD) remains one of the most dominant and impactful  particularly in developed countries. Effective prevention and management strategies are essential to reduce the impact of this pervasive disease.   Patient Information:  A 52-year-old African American male presented to the clinic with complaints of intermittent chest pain for the last three months. He describes the pain as 'crushing' in character  radiating to his left arm  associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. These episodes have been noted to occur primarily during exertion and alleviated with rest.   He is a resident of New Orleans  Louisiana  living with his wife and two children  and works as a high-school principal. He smokes one pack of cigarettes a day for the last 30 years and has a family history of heart disease; his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. His alcohol intake is restricted to social drinking.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient's vital signs were Temperature 37.2 C  Pulse 95 per minute  Blood pressure 140/95mmHg  and Respiration rate 20 per minute. His BMI was calculated to be 29.8 (height – 173cm  weight – 90kg)  falling into the 'Overweight' category. Auscultation revealed regular heart sounds  no murmurs or gallops. Lungs were clear  and his peripheral pulses were strong and regular.  Diagnostic Assessment:  His electrocardiogram (ECG) showed T wave inversions in leads V1-V4. Blood tests revealed raised Troponin I levels suggesting cardiac injury. Total cholesterol was 250mg/dL  low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) was 170mg/dL  and high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) was 38mg/dL.    Based on history  examination and investigations  he was diagnosed with Coronary artery disease (CAD).   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was prescribed aspirin 75 mg once daily for platelet inhibition  Atorvastatin 40mg once daily to lower cholesterol levels  and Metoprolol 50mg once daily for heart rate control. He was also advised to quit smoking  limit alcohol intake  follow a diet low in sodium and saturated fat  and engage in moderate-intensity exercise for at least 150 minutes per week. He was scheduled for follow-up every three months to monitor blood pressure  cholesterol levels and signs of any adverse drug reactions.  Outcomes:  Upon follow-up after three months  the frequency and intensity of his chest pain decreased significantly. His blood cholesterol levels have notably improved (Total cholesterol – 190mg/dL  LDL-C - 120mg/dL  HDL-C – 45mg/dL) and blood pressure controlled (125/80mmHg)  indicating a positive response to medication and lifestyle changes.  This case report emphasizes the importance of early recognition and prompt intervention in managing CAD  highlighting the significance of lifestyle changes along with pharmacological measures. Comprehensive care  including routine follow-up  is crucial for a better prognosis and improving the quality of life of CAD patients.   References: - Upon request.

Title: Case Report on a Patient with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)   Patient Profile: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  a retired mechanical engineer  who is currently residing in a suburban area. He is a non-smoker; however  he has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 30 indicating obesity.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with complaints of chest discomfort  primarily central chest pain  radiating to the left arm  along with shortness of breath  especially on exertion for the past 2 months. The frequency and intensity of pain have been progressively increasing in recent weeks.  Past Medical History: The patient was previously diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. His diabetes (HbA1C:7.2%) is managed with Metformin and Sitagliptin  and his hypertension (BP:150/95 mmHg) is controlled with Lisinopril. He also has a 10-year history of hyperlipidemia treated with Atorvastatin. He reported having experienced infrequent angina attacks  over the past one year  for which he was prescribed Sublingual Nitroglycerin.   Family History: His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62  and his mother had hypertension. He has an elder brother who is also hypertensive.   Clinical Findings/Physical Examination: On physical examination  he was tachycardic with an irregular pulse. Auscultation of the heart revealed a soft systolic murmur. Peripheral pulses were palpable. Electrocardiogram showed T-wave inversions in the inferior leads.   Investigations: Coronary angiogram depicted severe triple vessel disease. A stress test was positive for inducible ischemia. Other tests including echocardiography  lipid profile  and blood tests were ordered.  Diagnosis: Based on the patient's symptoms  physical examination  family history  and investigative findings  he was diagnosed with progressive Coronary Artery Disease  with a high risk of future events.  Management: The patient was initially managed with Aspirin  Beta-blockers (carvedilol)  and statin (atorvastatin) therapy. Lifestyle modification advice was given including a low-sodium  low cholesterol diet  regular aerobic exercise  and cessation of alcohol. The severity of coronary obstruction and the patient's symptoms indicated that he might soon require Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG).  Discussion: The patient's age  gender  and ethnicity  along with his history of hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  obesity  and a family history of heart disease categorize him among a higher risk group for CAD. He presents a classic example of CAD's multi-factorial etiology and underlines the importance of managing modifiable risk factors. Early detection and effective management are crucial in improving prognosis in CAD.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publishing the case.

Case Report  Patient Information: Mr. K  a 67-year-old African American male  currently residing in Brooklyn  NY  presents to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent chest pain for the past two weeks.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports that the chest pain is typically felt in the center of the chest and radiates towards his left arm. Each episode lasts approximately 5 - 10 minutes  occurring mainly during physical exertion or emotional stress  starting about two weeks ago. Relief is gained with rest. However  the pain became severe and longer-lasting (almost an hour)  compelling him to seek medical attention immediately. Mr. K also reported transient episodes of dyspnea and diaphoresis.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for about 15 years. This was well controlled with medications (Metformin and Lisinopril). He also has had a history of hyperlipidemia and is on Atorvastatin. However  he has missed some dosages lately due to his busy work schedule. He has no known allergy to any medication. He is a former smoker  having quit five years ago. Additionally  Mr. K's paternal family had a history of coronary artery disease.  Vital Signs and Physical Examination: BP: 160/90 mmHg  HR: 90 bpm  Resp: 20 breaths/min  Temp: 36.9°C. On examination  the patient appeared well-nourished  but slightly anxious. The pulmonary examination was within normal limits  as were peripheral pulses.  Investigations: Given the patient's symptoms and risk factors  a suspicion of coronary artery disease was made. An electrocardiogram (ECG) was done immediately at the emergency department which showed an ST-segment depression  followed by emergency cardiac catheterization  which confirmed the presence of significant stenosis in the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. His lipid profile revealed elevated LDL cholesterol and triglycerides.  Management and Follow-up: Mr. K was admitted to the coronary care unit. He was stabilized with aspirin  beta-blocker (metoprolol)  nitrates  and a statin. An angioplasty was performed on the following day with the placement of stents in the LAD artery. He was kept under observation for another three days  during which his status improved significantly.  Upon discharge  patient education was provided on the importance of medication compliance  lifestyle modifications  including a heart-healthy diet  regular exercise  and specific guidance about diabetes management was given. Scheduled follow-ups with cardiology and internal medicine were arranged every six weeks and three months respectively  for monitoring and adjusting medication  and for tracking his overall progress.  In conclusion  this case report underlines the importance of early detection and prompt management of coronary artery disease in high-risk patients  particularly in populations with a higher prevalence of uncontrolled risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. The significance of adhering to medication and adopting lifestyle adaptations was also highlighted in effectively managing the condition. Further research is needed to explore and address the barriers for effective disease control in underserved populations.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Profile:  The patient under scrutiny is a 72-year-old Asian male from a rural area  residing in Nacogdoches  Texas.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history remarkable for smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for almost thirty years  type II diabetes mellitus  and hypertension. He had been under medication for the last 8 years  in an attempt to moderate his blood pressure levels  but has struggled with medication adherence. He had smoked since the age of 20 but had quit 12 years earlier. His father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 58.   Presenting Issue:  The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of a 'crushing pressure' in the center of his chest that had been recurring intermittently for the past two days. He reported that the pain occasionally radiated to the left side of his jaw and down his left arm. He also experienced episodes of shortness of breath and diaphoresis. These symptoms were worsened by exercise and eased by rest.  Examinations and Diagnosis:  Physical examination revealed the patient to be overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 29. Blood pressure measurement revealed elevated systolic readings ranging from 140-145 mmHg and diastolic readings ranging from 90-95 mmHg. Rest of the examinations  including heart sounds and lung auscultation  were unremarkable.  Given the patient's symptoms and high-risk profile  electrocardiogram (ECG) and blood tests were promptly conducted. ECG demonstrated ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Blood works revealed elevated troponin levels  further solidifying the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction secondary to coronary artery disease (CAD).  Management and Outcome:  The patient was initiated on aspirin  nitroglycerin  and morphine for pain relief. He was immediately taken for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)  where a significant stenosis was identified in the right coronary artery  which was successfully dilated and stented. The patient was started on dual antiplatelet therapy  statin therapy  and ACE inhibitors following the procedure.  The patient was advised to take part in a cardiac rehabilitation program  dietary counseling was provided and stress management techniques were suggested to help mitigate risk factors contributing to his CAD.   Follow-up and Prognosis:  The patient's post-discharge plan consisted of rigorous control of his diabetes and hypertension  maintenance of a suitable body weight  and complete cessation of any form of tobacco use. With appropriate risk factor management and adherence to medication  while the prognosis of CAD is typically challenging  it is hoped that progression of the patient’s disease can be controlled to improve his quality of life and extend his life expectancy. Regular follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor the patient’s clinical status and manage the chronic conditions.  This case underlines the critical need to manage chronic conditions  lifestyle modifications  and adherence to medication regimens in controlling the risk of coronary artery disease.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease in an Elderly Male   I. Introduction   The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  a resident in the suburban of Orlando  Florida. He lives with his wife and is currently insured under Medicare. He is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol  but has a personal history of overweight  sedentary lifestyle  and unhealthy dietary habits.  II. Past Medical History  Prior to being diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD)  the patient has a documented history of hypertension for six years  and diabetes mellitus type 2  which was diagnosed three years ago. His mother had a similar medical history  having cardiovascular disease and succumbing to heart failure at the age of 74.   The patient was regularly taking Metformin 500mg twice daily for his diabetes  and Lisinopril 10mg once daily for hypertension.   III. Current Clinical Presentation   The patient presented to the emergency department with a complaint of recurrent chest pain that's been severe in nature since last night  radiating to his left arm and associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. The pain was aggravated by physical exertion and relieved somewhat by rest.   IV. Diagnosis   An emergent electrocardiogram was performed revealing ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  suggesting an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Labs showed increased cardiac enzymes: troponin I was 3.48 ng/mL and creatine kinase was 850 units/L  both significantly above normal limits.   Further cardiac examination and angiography confirmed severe coronary artery disease  with extensive atherosclerotic plaque in the right coronary artery.   V. Treatment and Follow-Up   The patient was immediately admitted to the cardiac care unit and management was initiated for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). He underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) of the right coronary artery with stent placement.   Post-procedure  he was started on dual antiplatelet therapy  beta-blockers  and statins for the long-term management of CAD. A tailored nutrition plan and physical therapy regimen were also recommended to the patient to address his lifestyle habits.   He has thus far completed a 3-month follow-up in cardiology outpatient clinic  showing good adherence to medications  improvement in exercise capacity  and a healthier diet pattern. His chest pain has also markedly reduced.   VI. Conclusion   This case underlines the importance of modifiable risk factors in CAD  such as poor dietary habits  sedentary lifestyle  and uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension. Timely intervention and appropriate management significantly improved the patient's cardiovascular status.

Title: Stable Angina Pectoris in a 60-year-old Caucasian Male with Coronary Artery Disease   _____  Case Report  Patient Information:   The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  from an urban middle socioeconomic class background. He is married  retired  and has a sedentary lifestyle.  Chief Complaint:   The patient primarily presented with chest discomfort  particularly during physical exertion such as walking up stairs. He described a tight  squeezing sensation lasting for several minutes and then subsiding with rest. The patient also reported experiencing episodes of breathlessness during such events.  Medical History:   The patient has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and Type II diabetes  which are being managed with medications (Amlodipine 5mg once daily for hypertension and Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes). There is also a significant family history of early-onset heart disease. The patient had an otherwise unremarkable health record and no known allergies.  Diagnosis:   Based on the patient's symptomatology  age  gender  ethnicity  and past medical history  a preliminary diagnosis of stable angina pectoris secondary to coronary artery disease was made. This was confirmed with an abnormal EKG  indicating myocardial ischemia  alongside elevated cardiac biomarkers (Troponin). Further investigations were carried out through coronary angiography  which revealed significant stenosis in the left anterior descending coronary artery and circumflex artery.  Treatment :   He was started on nitroglycerin 0.4mg sublingual tablets to be used as needed under the tongue during episodes of angina. The patient was also prescribed aspirin 81mg daily  Atorvastatin 40mg at night  Bisoprolol 5mg in the morning  and his existing diabetes and hypertension medications were adjusted.  Follow-up:   The patient was counseled regarding lifestyle measures to reduce cardiovascular risks such as regular exercise  dietary modifications  and optimal control of diabetes and hypertension. The patient is scheduled for re-evaluation in one month  with earlier appointment if symptoms worsen or fails to improve.  Learning Points:  This case underlines the importance of a thorough clinical evaluation for patients presenting with chest discomfort  especially in the context of multiple risk factors for ischemic heart disease such as male gender  age above 60 years  diabetes  hypertension  and a positive family history. Early diagnosis  initiation of treatment  and lifestyle modifications are key to prevent progression to unstable angina or myocardial infarction.

Title: Case Report: A 63-year-old Hispanic Male with Coronary Artery Disease  Introduction: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is among the leading causes of death worldwide. This report details a case of a 63-year-old Hispanic male patient diagnosed with this disease  recounting his demographic specifics  past medical history  symptoms  and the therapeutic measures taken.  Patient Information: The patient is a 63-year-old Hispanic male  named JJ  a retired engineer residing in Los Angeles  California. He is a non-smoker and occasionally drinks alcohol. He is married with three grown-up children and lives an average sedentary lifestyle. The patient is overweight with a BMI of 27.5 kg/m2. Family history reveals that his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and his mother has hypertension.  Medical history: JJ's past medical history is marked by Type II diabetes and moderately high blood pressure  for which he has been on medication for the past 12 years  namely Metformin and Lisinopril respectively. He also has a history of intermittent dyspepsia  for which he takes Pantoprazole. The patient does not report any medication intolerance or allergies.  Case Presentation: The patient consulted with complaints of experiencing intermittent chest pain  especially during physical exertion  over the past few months. The pain was described as a squeezing sensation in the chest  occasionally radiating to the left arm. Accompanying these symptoms were breathlessness and bouts of cold sweat.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  blood pressure was 142/90 mmHg  and pulse was 72 beats per minute with no unevenness. Cardiovascular examination revealed no heart murmurs or irregular heartbeat. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: Electrocardiogram (ECG) exhibited T-wave inversion and ST-segment depression  indicative of myocardial ischemia. His lipid profile revealed heightened LDL cholesterol (172 mg/dL) and reduced HDL cholesterol (35 mg/dL). Fasting blood glucose level was 160 mg/dL  highlighting poor diabetes management. A coronary angiogram confirmed severe CAD with two of the main coronary arteries (left anterior descending artery and right coronary artery) showing more than 70% stenosis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was referred to a cardiologist for angioplasty and stent placement. During this period  the patient’s medications were reviewed  resulting in titration of the current antidiabetic and antihypertensive therapy  adding Aspirin 75mg/day  and initiating statin therapy with Atorvastatin 40mg/night to control his LDL levels. Lifestyle modifications such as a low-salt  low-fat diet  regular aerobic exercises  and strict glycemic control were also advised.  Follow-up and Outcomes: On a three-month follow-up  JJ displayed significant improvement; he experienced fewer episodes of chest pain  achieved better control of blood glucose levels  and demonstrated a satisfying reduction in LDL cholesterol levels.   Conclusion: JJ's case underscores the critical need for early detection and appropriate management of coronary artery disease  especially among high-risk populations like older age  male  and those with a family history of CAD. The incorporation of both pharmacological management and lifestyle changes prove key to effective control of metabolic risk factors. Regular follow-ups were instrumental in disease management and improvement of this patient's quality of life.

Title: Severe Coronary Artery Disease in an African American Elderly Female with a History of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes.  Case Report:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 70-year-old African American female presenting with a recent history of angina pectoris and shortness of breath. She has a longstanding medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has been a non-smoker and non-alcoholic throughout her lifetime. She's a retired school teacher  lived in a low socio-economic urban neighborhood  and has a family history of coronary artery disease.  History & Clinical Examination: The patient was reported to have had an increasing frequency of anginal attacks over the past six months  experienced as moderate to severe chest discomfort  often radiating to her left arm and associated with shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional episodes of diaphoresis. The patient has a record of poor compliance with her antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications due to cost barriers. She also has a history of irregular follow-ups with physicians due to lack of health insurance and accessibility to healthcare services.   Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse 85 beats per minute  and BMI of 32 kg/m^2 indicative of obesity. The rest of her physical examination was within normal limits. Her glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) was consistently above 8% over a couple of years with the latest being 9.2%.   Diagnosis & Treatment: The patient underwent various tests  including blood tests showing elevated lipid profile and cardiac biomarkers  an echocardiogram revealed reduced ejection fraction  and an electrocardiogram showed T-wave inversions and Q waves  consistent with a history of myocardial infarction. Coronary angiography revealed multiple occlusions in three of her coronary arteries  confirming the presence of severe coronary artery disease. Her medical treatment was advanced to include high-intensity statin therapy  ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers  blood glucose-lowering drugs  and dual antiplatelet therapy. The patient was also advised to consume a heart-healthy diet (DASH diet) and regular follow-ups were scheduled to monitor her condition. A consultation was sought from a social worker to facilitate the patient's access to necessary healthcare resources.   Conclusion: This case illustrates the severe impact of noncompliance with medications  disparities in healthcare  and the failure of disease management in individuals with comorbid conditions such as CAD  hypertension  and diabetes. It highlights the importance of regular follow-ups  medication adherence  adequate control of blood sugar  blood pressure  and maintaining a healthy lifestyle. Social determinants of health and underlying systemic issues cannot be overlooked and are of utmost importance in managing such patients.

Patient Case Report - Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Profile: The patient  Mr. X  is a 65-year-old African American male  born and raised in Los Angeles  California  USA. He is a retired teacher  married with two adult children  and is not involved in any form of strenuous activity. He is a former smoker and occasionally drinks alcohol.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has a history of hypertension for which he is taking medication (Lisinopril). He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled on metformin and dietary modification. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a heart attack at the age of 60. Mr. X admits poor adherence to antihypertensive medication and irregular clinic visits.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. X was admitted to the emergency department after experiencing heavy chest pain radiating to his left arm  associated with sweating and shortness of breath. These symptoms started while he was doing house chores and subsided a little on resting.   Examination and Investigation: On examination  he appeared sweaty and agitated. Blood pressure was 160/100 and heart rate was 86 beats per minute. Cardiac examination revealed a S4 heart sound; the remainder of the examination was normal. An electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads suggestive of myocardial infarction.  Treatment and Follow-up: He was immediately administered sublingual nitroglycerin in the emergency department to relieve pain  and Morphine IV for pain control. Also  he was started on Aspirin 325mg chewable  Clopidogrel 600mg loading dose  Atrovastatin 80mg and heparin infusion for anticoagulation. He underwent an emergent cardiac catheterization which revealed significant coronary artery disease with 90% blockage of his left anterior descending artery. A decision was made to treat the blockage by placing a drug-eluting stent  which was successful.   Post-procedure  he was stable and his chest pain subsided. He was enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program. He was discharged on Aspirin 81mg daily indefinitely  Clopidogrel 75mg daily for a year  Atorvastatin 80mg daily indefinitely  Lisinopril 10mg daily  metformin and other medications as per his home medication list.   The patient was educated about the importance of medication adherence  regular follow-ups  a heart-healthy diet  regular exercise  and support for smoking cessation. He was also instructed to seek immediate medical attention if the chest pain recurs. He is scheduled for a follow-up appointment the following week at the outpatient clinic.  In conclusion  the case highlights the importance of understanding the patient's demographic background  clinical history  presentation  and management in the context of coronary artery disease.

Patient Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease   Demographics ------------ Patient Initials: J.K. Gender: Male Age: 66 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Location: North Dakota  USA  Presenting Issue: ------------------ J.K. has presented at the clinic complaining of intermittent periods of chest pain  mainly occurring during episodes of physical exertional activities.  Medical History: ----------------- J.K. has a history of hypertension for the past 10 years and has been on medications for the same. His blood pressure has been controlled well with Lisinopril. He also suffers from Type 2 diabetes mellitus and has been on Metformin for 3 years. His HbA1c levels have been maintained around 7.2-7.5 for the past year. He has been moderately adherent to a recommended low-sodium  low-carbohydrate diet. J.K was a smoker for 30 years but quit smoking about 10 years ago. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a myocardial infarction at 70.  Physical Exam: ----------------  J.K's weight is stable. He is overweight with a BMI of 28. His blood pressure during this visit was 130/85  and heart rate was 78 beats per minute. His cardiovascular examination revealed normal heart sounds with no murmurs.  Investigations: ---------------- An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed showing T wave inversions in the inferior leads. Based on the characteristic chest pain and changes on the ECG  he was suspected of having coronary artery disease. He was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation.  Additional tests  including Troponin levels and a Coronary angiography  were ordered. Troponin levels were normal  but Coronary angiography showed significant stenosis in the right coronary artery. He was diagnosed with coronary artery disease.  Treatment Plan: ----------------- J.K. was recommended to undergo Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI). Post-PCI  he was started on dual antiplatelet therapy- Aspirin and Clopidogrel. He was advised to continue his Lisinopril for hypertension and was recommended to take Statin therapy for his dyslipidemia. Lifestyle modifications  including maintaining his diet  engaging in moderate exercise  weight reduction  and regularly checking his blood pressure and glucose levels at home  were emphasized.  Follow-up and Prognosis: ------------------------ J.K. will have a one-month follow-up appointment post his discharge from the hospital to monitor his progress and adjust his medications as required. Considering his age and comorbidity  J.K.'s prognosis is uncertain. However  improvements in symptoms and quality of life can be expected with appropriate lifestyle changes  medication management  and regular follow-ups.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information:  Mr. Browning  a 64-year-old Caucasian man  presented to the emergency department. He was overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28.3. The patient resides in a suburban area in Maryland and is a retired mechanical engineer. He is a current smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. Mr. Browning is married and has two adult children  all of whom maintain good health.  Chief Complaint:  The patient reported experiencing prolonged episodes of severe chest pain radiating to his left upper limb over the past four days. The pain was associated with sweating and a feeling of faintness.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Browning has a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 12 years  managed with metformin and amlodipine respectively. He also has a history of hypercholesterolemia for which he has been on atorvastatin for the last 10 years. There was no history of previous surgeries  allergies  or other significant medical conditions. There were no relevant childhood diseases or accidents. His last known echocardiogram done two years ago showed no abnormalities. Family history revealed that his father had suffered from a heart attack at the age of 72.  Physical Examination:  On examination  Mr. Browning appeared anxious and diaphoretic. His blood pressure was 165/95 mm Hg  pulse 98 bpm  respiratory rate 22 breaths/min  and SpO2 95% on room air. His cardiovascular examination revealed soft S1 and a loud A2. He had no murmurs or additional sounds.  Further Evaluation:  An electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in leads V2-V6  suggestive of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. Blood workup confirmed the diagnosis with elevated cardiac troponin levels. Complete blood count  renal function  and electrolytes were all within normal limits. However  his lipid profile was deranged with elevated LDL and triglycerides levels.  Follow Up:  Given the urgency of the situation  Mr. Browning was immediately transferred to the coronary care unit and underwent primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The angiogram revealed a 90% lesion in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery  which was successfully dilated and stented. The patient responded well to the intervention with ST-segment resolution and alleviation of his symptoms.  Management:  Post-procedure  Mr. Browning was placed on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and ticagrelor)  along with continuation of statins  antihypertensive  and diabetic medications. He was also introduced to an aggressive lifestyle modification program including dietary changes  smoking cessation  regular cardio-based exercise  and stress management interventions.  Conclusion:  This case report underscores the importance of early identification and management of modifiable risk factors in patients with coronary artery disease. Efficient and prompt intervention in acute coronary syndromes can successfully restore myocardial perfusion and reduce morbidity and mortality associated with the disease.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Presentation  A 76-year-old African American male presented at the emergency department with an episode of severe chest pain associated with shortness of breath that commenced about 30 minutes prior to his arrival. He also stated that he was feeling light-headed and had been sweating profusely.  Demographics  The patient resides in a senior housing complex in Bronx  NY. He is a widower with three adult children. He is retired  having worked as a construction worker for 35 years. He is a non-smoker but reports indulging in alcohol only during social events. He also mentions a diet mainly consisting of high-fat foods and minimal physical activity due to degenerative joint disease in both knees.  Past medical history  The patient has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both currently controlled with medication—amlodipine 5mg once daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 40mg at bedtime for hypercholesterolemia. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago which is managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily and lifestyle modification advice. He also has a history of bilateral knee osteoarthritis and is on over-the-counter NSAIDs as needed.  Examination and investigations  On presentation  the patient appeared pale and diaphoretic. His blood pressure was 170/95 mmHg  heart rate 94 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  temperature 36.8°C  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. An electrocardiogram (ECG) was conducted immediately which showed ST-segment elevation in leads II  III and aVF  suggesting an inferior wall ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). He was transferred to the catheterization laboratory almost immediately. Coronary angiography revealed significant obstructions in the right coronary artery (RCA) and the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. A diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) was made based on these findings.  Management and Follow-up  The patient underwent successful percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) and had drug-eluting stents placed in the RCA and LAD. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel along with a beta blocker  angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor  and high-intensity statin. His blood pressure and diabetes medications were also optimized. After a period of in-hospital rehabilitation and education about the importance of lifestyle changes  he was discharged under the care of his cardiologist. Regular follow-ups at the cardiology clinic have been scheduled.  Discussion  This case highlights the catastrophic effects of multiple modifiable risk factors for coronary artery disease. The necessity for aggressive risk factor control  patient education about lifestyle modification  and the importance of regular follow-ups is emphasized by this case. The importance of rapid recognition and management of acute coronary syndromes is also underlined.

Case Report: A 58-year-old African American Male with Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: The patient is a 58-year-old African American male who has presented with increasing episodes of chest pain and shortness of breath  losing his breath especially after walking a relatively short distance. He weighs about 86 kg  stands 1.75m tall  and has a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28.05  indicating that he is overweight. He’s a businessman who spends most of his time sitting at his computer trading shares. This also makes him lead a sedentary lifestyle. He lives with his wife and two sons in California. He is a non-smoker but drinks alcohol socially  approximately once a week.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 7 years ago  which has been controlled with medication (Losartan 50mg/day). He's also been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago  for which he takes Metformin (500mg twice a day). He has been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia  with an LDL cholesterol level consistently above 190 mg/dL  despite being on Atorvastatin 40mg daily. Furthermore  the patient reports a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 67.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  blood pressure was elevated (155/95mmHg). Auscultation revealed distant heart sounds but normal rhythm. Pulses are strong and regular. No jugular venous distention observed. The patient appeared slightly anxious and pale. Breath sounds normal with no adventitious sounds. The patient was recommended for an ECG  echocardiogram  and blood tests including lipid profile  complete blood count  and troponin level.  Diagnostic Assessment: Results from the ECG confirmed evidence of previous myocardial infarction with possible left ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiogram demonstrated left ventricular systolic dysfunction with estimated ejection fraction of 40%. The lipid profile test provided the following results: total cholesterol: 255 mg/dL  LDL: 180mg/dL  HDL: 35mg/dL  triglycerides: 200mg/dL. The troponin level was slightly elevated.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Management includes lifestyle modification which includes regular exercise to reduce weight and alcohol intake reduction. The patient is recommended to continue the medication for hypertension and diabetes but the dose of Atorvastatin was escalated to 80mg daily to achieve better control of the LDL cholesterol level. The patient was also started on aspirin 81mg daily and a Beta-blocker (Metoprolol 50mg twice daily). The patient was referred to a cardiologist for further evaluation of cardiovascular risk and consideration for coronary angiography based on the presence of refractory angina despite medication.  Follow-up/Outcome: The patient will be asked to come in for a follow-up visit in three weeks' time to assess the response to the above changes. Further plans will be based on this response  symptoms  and any new findings.  The patient provided informed consent for the publication of anonymized clinical data for educational purposes.

Patient Description:  The patient is a 64-year old African-American male named Mr. Williams. He lives in uptown Chicago  Illinois  with his wife. The patient is a retired army veteran and has a medical history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a non-smoker and exercises regularly.   Presenting Problem:  Mr. Williams presented to the hospital with central chest pain radiating to his left arm and shortness of breath over the last 24 hours. He also complained of increased fatigue and slight loss of appetite.  Medical History:  Upon history taking  it was noted that the patient has had issues with hypertension and has been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus over five years ago. His hypertension has been fairly managed with amlodipine 5mg daily  and his diabetes has shown a good response to metformin 500 mg twice daily. There is family history of heart disease  as his father had suffered from a heart attack at the age of 60.  Clinical Examination:  On physical examination  the patient exhibited slight diaphoresis and appeared anxious. His heart rate was 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 per minute  blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Listening to the chest indicated a slight irregularity in heart rhythm.  Additional Testing:  The electrocardiogram (EKG) revealed ST-segment elevations indicative of a possible myocardial infarction. The troponin levels were obtained and came back significantly elevated.   Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical presentation  EKG findings  and elevated troponin levels  the diagnosis of Acute ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI) was made  indicating coronary artery disease.  Management:  The patient was managed immediately with aspirin  sublingual nitroglycerin  and a heparin drip. He was referred to the cardiology team and an urgent cardiac catheterization was performed  which confirmed occlusion in the left anterior descending artery. A stent was implanted successfully. Post-stenting follow-up included dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel.  Mr. Williams was also advised on lifestyle management strategies  including low salt and low sugar diet  moderate physical activity  and stress management techniques to cope with his conditions.  Discussion:  The prevalence of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) varies and is influenced by factors such as age  gender  and race. The literature suggests that the prevalence increases in males over 65 years old and is higher in African-Americans (like Mr. Williams). However  lifestyles  including diet and physical activity  can significantly contribute to disease outcomes. This case of Mr. Williams highlights the importance of timely and proper interventions in CAD management for better patient outcomes.

Patient Details: Mr. A.B is a 63-year-old African American male with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is retired  a former long-term smoker  and resides in an urban area with his wife. He denies alcohol usage and illicit drug use.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. A.B presented at the outpatient department with complaints of chronic chest pain characterized as squeezing and tightness in nature  radiating to his left arm. The chest pain is particularly pronounced during exertion and is often relieved by rest. He also reports experiencing episodes of shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional lightheadedness over a period of two months.  Clinical History: His medical history reveals diagnosis of type 2 diabetes 10 years ago (poorly controlled with metformin) and a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD)  with his father suffering a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 65. He was diagnosed with hypertension 7 years ago  which has been inadequately managed with intermittent use of Lisinopril.   Physical Examination: At consultation  his blood pressure recorded was 160/90 mmHg  BMI was 29.5  pulse was regular at 72 beats per minute  and his respirations were 18 per minute. On auscultation  his heart sounds were normal without any added sounds or murmurs. Lungs were clear on auscultation and the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   Investigations and Results: Given his presenting symptoms  risk factors  and medical history  the provisional diagnosis of coronary artery disease was made. Subsequently  patient underwent various tests including blood tests  chest X-ray  Electrocardiogram (ECG)  Echocardiogram  stress tests and coronary angiogram.  Lab results indicated elevated levels of HbA1c and LDL cholesterol  while an ECG showed evidence of T wave inversions in the inferior and lateral leads. Echocardiogram showed normal LV systolic function with an ejection fraction of 60%. Angiography revealed severe disease with 85% stenosis of the left anterior descending artery and 70% stenosis of the right coronary artery.  Diagnosis and Management: The patient was diagnosed with severe coronary artery disease.  Cardiology consultation was sought  and it was decided to manage the patient with Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI). Meanwhile  the patient was managed medically with dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin and clopidogrel)  statin therapy  and tight control of diabetes and hypertension. Patient’s hypertension was managed with an increased dose of lisinopril and introduction of a calcium channel blocker  amlodipine. He was also advised to quit smoking  improve dietary habits and commence a regular  moderate-intensity physical activity.   Follow-Up: The patient responded well to the treatment and lifestyle modifications. He has been compliant with the medications and has shown regular improvements in six-monthly follow-ups. His chest pain has drastically reduced  and his exertional capacity has improved  allowing him to engage in daily activities. His BP is now under control at 130/80 mmHg  with improved HbA1c and LDL levels. He will continue to be monitored regularly for any worsening of his condition.   Prepared By: Dr. X Date: (enter date)  Hospital: (enter hospital name)

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  I. Patient Information The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired automotive mechanic and resident of Pennsylvania  USA. His body weight is within the normal BMI range. He lives with his wife and admits to a history of smoking (1 pack/day for 40 years) but quit 8 years ago and reports average alcohol consumption. He does not have a known family history of coronary artery disease (CAD)  but his father had diabetes mellitus.  II. Clinical Presentation The patient reported to the hospital complaining of intermittent chest pain for the last few weeks  which was typically exacerbated by physical activity and mitigated by rest. There were no associated symptoms of radiation of pain  palpitations  syncope  or difficulty in breathing.   III. Past Medical History His past medical history includes hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril daily and type 2 diabetes mellitus  well controlled with Metformin. He has not previously been diagnosed with any cardiovascular diseases. There were no adverse drug reactions or allergies. He has avoided regular exercise throughout his life  noting sedentarism as his usual lifestyle pattern.  IV. Diagnosis A physical exam revealed standard values for blood pressure and pulse rate. An electrocardiogram (ECG) and echocardiogram were ordered given the characteristics and persistence of his symptoms despite antihypertensive medication. The ECG identified ST-segment depression  indicating possible myocardial ischemia. On further investigation with a coronary angiography  CAD was confirmed with the finding being consistent with multivessel coronary artery disease. Blood tests also indicated a raised LDL cholesterol level  contributing to atherogenesis.  V. Treatment and Follow-up The patient was treated with coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery to alleviate the blockages. He was also prescribed a beta-blocker (metoprolol)  aspirin  and a statin (atorvastatin) to manage his hypertension  improve blood flow  and lower his cholesterol levels. Following successful surgery  he was advised to attend cardiac rehabilitation.   He was recommended a diet low in saturated and trans fat  sodium  and added sugar  and encouraged to gradually introduce moderate-intensity physical activity into his daily routine taking his age and physical condition into account. The importance of regular outpatient check-ups was underlined to ensure the monitoring and control of his other risk factors  like diabetes and hypertension.  Six months later  the patient reported significantly reduced chest pain and greater capacity for physical exertivity. He remains under constant follow-up and continues to adhere to medication regimens and lifestyle modifications.   In conclusion  this case demonstrates the importance of quick diagnosis and comprehensive care in patients with a high-risk factor for coronary artery diseases. Timely revascularization (CABG)  appropriate medication  and strict follow-up were essential for a positive outcome in this case.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a 67-Year-old Caucasian Male with a History of Type 2 Diabetes and Hypertension  Patient Profile: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired  living in suburban Florida. His past medical history reveals long-term type 2 diabetes management for 22 years and hypertension for 18 years. He is a former smoker  having quit roughly 10 years ago after a 30-year history of tobacco use. The patient's lifestyle included limited physical activity and a high-fat  high-sugar diet.  Presenting Complaint: The patient came in complaining of recurrent episodes of chest pain for the past month  sometimes accompanied by shortness of breath and fatigue. He reported the pain as being more severe during physical activities or stress but subsided during periods of rest.  Clinical Findings: Clinical examination revealed a body mass index of 30 kg/m2  representative of obesity. The patient displayed moderate dyspnea on exertion. Blood pressure on presentation was 150/95 mmHg  and resting heart rate was 88 beats per minute. There were no acute distress  abnormal heart sound  or peripheral edema observed.  Diagnostic Assessments: An Electrocardiogram (ECG) displayed features indicative of myocardial ischemia. Initial blood tests showed elevated levels of cardiac enzymes (troponin I and CK-MB). Fasting blood analysis revealed hyperglycaemia (190 mg/dl) and hyperlipidemia (LDL 180 mg/dl  HDL 35 mg/dl). An echocardiogram revealed left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved ejection fraction. Coronary angiography was performed  which demonstrated significant stenosis in the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and right coronary artery (RCA).  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initially started on intravenous nitroglycerin for chest pain and oral aspirin  as well as a high-intensity statin. Glycemic control was maintained with Metformin and newly added Sitagliptin. Antihypertensive  including Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and a Beta-blocker  was introduced to control the blood pressure. Lifestyle modifications were suggested  including a healthier diet  regular exercise  and weight reduction. The patient was later taken up for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) considering significant stenosis.  Follow-Up and Outcome One month following the PCI  the patient reported a significant reduction in chest pain frequency and severity. Shortness of breath and fatigue had also improved. His blood pressure had decreased to 130/80 mmHg  and glycemic control improved (HbA1c 7.1%). He was advised to continue his medication and lifestyle modifications for optimal coronary artery disease management.  This clinical case sheds light on the multifactorial pathophysiology of coronary artery disease and highlights the importance of regular screening and comprehensive management strategies  particularly in patients with multiple risk factors like diabetes  hypertension  and a sedentary lifestyle.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Identification:   Mr. M.S.  aged 66 years  white male  retired engineer  non-smoker  with family history of heart disease and a resident of New York  USA. The patient resides with his spouse  is a father of two and has access to moderate healthcare resources and regular healthcare check-ups.   Medical History:   The patient has a well-documented history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which is moderately controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. He also has hyperlipidemia that has been partially controlled with statin therapy. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 27  signifying overweight  with sedentary lifestyle adding to his risk factors. His past medical history also reveals episodes of angina pectoris  which was managed with nitroglycerin. He has no history of asthma or any respiratory diseases  and no known allergies to medications.   Presenting Complaints:   On the day of visit  the patient presented with a one-month history of recurrent chest pain. The chest pain  described as a pressure or squeezing sensation in the chest  often radiating towards his left arm and jaw  typically lasting approximately 5-10 minutes. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath and occasional episodes of diaphoresis. These symptoms often occurred during physical activity or under emotional stress.   Examination and Laboratory Investigations:  His vital signs at admission were as follows:  BP :145/88mmHg  Pulse rate: 80 beats/min  Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths/min  Temp: 98.7F  Oxygen saturation: 98%. He appeared comfortable at rest.   Initial EKG showed T-wave inversion in leads II  III  and aVF. Subsequent Exercise Stress Test showed significant ST depression  indicative of myocardial ischemia. Fasting blood sugar levels were slightly elevated  along with elevated total cholesterol and LDL levels.   Diagnosis and Management:  Based on his presenting symptoms  past medical history and test results  a diagnosis of Chronic Stable Angina secondary to Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) was made.   Patient was started on anti-anginal therapy (Beta-Blockers  Calcium Channel Blockers  and long-acting Nitrates  as needed). Therapy for modifying risk factors was addressed- advised further sugar control  lipid-lowering statins  weight management  lifestyle modifications  and daily supervised exercise. Coronary angiography and possible revascularization procedures were discussed as future treatment options.   Current Status:  Patient is currently under regular follow-ups with cardiology  nutrition  and diabetes team  with regular monitoring of his symptoms and blood tests. His symptoms and disease is perceived to be under better control.   Created by: Dr. XXXXX  Date: XXXX (to be filled by practitioner)

Case Report  Patient Profile: Patient Initials: GM Gender: Male Age: 60 years Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Mechanic Smoking Status: Ex-smoker (15 years of abstinence  30 pack-years prior) Alcohol Consumption: Moderate (1-2 glasses of wine per day)  Chief Complaint: Chest discomfort and shortness of breath  aggravated following moderate physical activity such as gardening.  Personal Medical History: GM had hypertension diagnosed at the age of 50 and has been on and off antihypertensive medications due to poor compliance. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago  which is currently managed with oral antidiabetic medication (Metformin). His BMI is 28  indicating he is overweight.  GM was previously diagnosed with favorable prognosis localized prostate cancer at age 58 and completed treatment. He has also noted to suffer from mild osteoarthritis  triggering occasional joint pain.  Family Medical History: GM's father died of a myocardial infarction at age 67. His mother had hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. GM has a younger sister with type 2 diabetes mellitus and a younger brother who died in a motor vehicle accident at age 29.  Clinical Assessment:  Upon examination  GM's blood pressure was elevated at 145/90 mmHg  and heart rate was at 92 beats per minute. His lipids profile reported high levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) of 160mg/dL and total cholesterol of 220mg/dL. Blood sugar levels were slightly above the desired range indicative of sub optimal blood glucose control.   A resting electrocardiogram revealed a left ventricular hypertrophy  and a stress echocardiogram showed evidence of myocardial ischemia.  Diagnosis:  Considering the patient’s reported symptoms  family history of premature coronary artery disease (CAD)  presence of multiple risk factors like hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  dyslipidemia  and evidence of stress-induced ischemia  a presumptive diagnosis of the coronary artery disease was made.  Treatment and Management: Post-diagnosis GM was admitted and treated initially with nitroglycerin that provided considerable relief in chest discomfort. A dual antiplatelet regimen with aspirin and clopidogrel along with high-intensity statin therapy was initiated.
