He also started on a beta-blocker to control his hypertension and reduce the heart rate  as well as angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) for cardiovascular protection.  His diabetes and dyslipidemia management were optimized with strict patient education on medication compliance and commitment to lifestyle changes  including diet and exercise.  The patient was also referred to cardiology for consideration of angiography to understand the extent of the disease better.  This case illustrates the classic presentation of CAD and highlights the importance of considering CAD in older adult patients  especially when multiple modifiable risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and dyslipidemia are present. It also signifies the indispensable role of lifestyle modification and compliance to medication in disease management.

Case Report  Patient Information:  Mr. James  a 58-year-old African-American male  visited our Out Patient Department on November 12  2022. He lives in Chicago  Illinois  and is married with two children. He is an attorney by profession and leads a sedentary lifestyle. Mr. James is a former smoker  having quit around five years ago after a 30-year history of tobacco use. He continues to drink alcohol moderately and has a diet high in saturated fats.  Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with Stage 1 hypertension 10 years ago  which has been controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). Around 6 years back  he was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for which he takes Metformin 500mg twice daily. He is also known to have hyperlipidemia and is being treated with Atorvastatin (20mg daily). His weight and Body Mass Index has been steadily increasing for the last 10 years  currently weighing 230 pounds (BMI 30.4) indicating obesity.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. James approached the clinic complaining of chronic chest discomfort for the past 2 weeks  described as pressure-like pain located in the center of his chest  radiating to his left arm. The pain usually appears after heavy meals or physical exertion and is promptly relieved by rest. He also mentions occasional episodes of shortness of breath and heart palpitations. However  he denies any symptoms of light-headedness  syncope  fever  cough  or sweating.   Initial Impressions and Management:  These symptoms are suggestive of angina pectoris  pointing towards coronary artery disease (CAD). However  a definitive diagnosis can only be made based on detailed investigations. Mr. James was advised to undertake a series of diagnostic tests  including a complete blood profile  ECG  stress test  and coronary angiography. Meanwhile  patient's statin medication was continued and he was prescribed sublingual nitroglycerin tablets for immediate relief from chest pain.   Long-term management considerations include lifestyle modifications such as a low salt and low cholesterol diet  routine physical exercise  weight loss  and optimal control of blood pressure  lipids and blood glucose. Regular follow-up visits are scheduled for monitoring his overall health status and adjusting the medication regimen  as necessary.  This case highlights the potentially severe  yet often asymptomatic nature of CAD in its early stages. Given his age  race  gender  sedentary lifestyle  history of smoking  saturated fat-rich diet  and pre-existing conditions such as hypertension  Diabetes Mellitus and hyperlipidemia  this patient falls into the high-risk category for CAD. Therefore  it is essential to proactively manage his case to prevent the progression of the disease and development of life-threatening complications such as myocardial infarction.

Case Report - Patient with Coronary Artery Disease  Demographics:  Mr. M  a 65-year-old African American male  presented to the outpatient department in October 2021. He is a retired schoolteacher and a widower with two adult children. His insurance is Medicare  and he resides in a suburban area of New Jersey. He has a documented history of smoking (20 cigarettes/day for approximately 30 years). Mr. M reported that his diet was high in fats and salts  and his physical activity level is low due to a sedentary lifestyle.   Medical History:  The patient has a long-standing history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus (10 years)  Hypertension (5 years)  and Hyperlipidemia (6 years). He has been on Metformin 500 mg twice a day for diabetes  Lisinopril 20 mg once a day for hypertension  and Atorvastatin 40 mg once daily for hyperlipidemia.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. M was initially referred to a primary care physician by a visiting nurse after complaining of chronic dyspnea  fatigue  and occasional chest discomfort. The severity of discomfort increased while doing household chores and abated on rest.  Clinical Examination:  Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 160/90 mm Hg  BMI of 29 kg/m2  elevated waist circumference  and palpable pedal edema. Cardiovascular examination showed a regular rhythm  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.   Investigations and Diagnosis:  Comprehensive lab tests unveiled elevated levels of glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c  8%)  fasting lipid profile was disturbed with high levels of total cholesterol (5.8 mmol/L)  LDL-cholesterol (4.2 mmol/L) and triglycerides (2.9 mmol/L) whereas HDL-cholesterol was low (1 mmol/L).  An electrocardiogram (EKG) evidenced abnormal Q waves and ST-segment elevation  indicating possible myocardial infarction. Coronary angiography was subsequently performed  revealing three-vessel disease  involving the proximal left anterior descending (LAD)  left circumflex (LCX)  and right coronary artery (RCA)  thus confirming the diagnosis of severe coronary artery disease (CAD).  Management and Follow-up:  Given the severity of the disease and the patient's comorbidities  he has been referred to a cardiac surgeon for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He was also referred to a dietician to design a diet plan with lower salt and fat content. In terms of pharmacological management  his treating physician adjusted his hypertension medicine to a different one (Amlodipine 5 mg) because his blood pressure was not well-controlled with the previous one. It was also reinforced to Mr. M to adhere to his medication and to commit to lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking  engaging in daily physical activity and maintaining a cardiac-friendly diet.  This case highlights the complexity of managing coronary artery disease  especially in the presence of other comorbidities such as diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia -- conditions that are common among African American males. A multidisciplinary approach involving a team of cardiologists  physicians  dietitians  and nurses is essential to successfully manage and improve the overall quality of life of the patient.

Title: A Case Report of Coronary Artery Disease in a 60-year-old African-American Male  Introduction: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) is highly prevalent in the global population and is known to have varied demographic and racial trends. According to several epidemiological studies  African-Americans have a higher prevalence of CAD. Herein  we present a case of CAD in a 60-year-old African-American male.  Case Presentation: Mr. C  a 60-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of central chest discomfort for a duration of half an hour  which radiated to the left arm. The pain was associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. There was no nausea  vomiting  or syncope. The medical history of the patient included 20-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Further  Mr. C was a 30-pack year smoker with a body mass index (BMI) of 32.5 kg/m2. He reported no significant family history of heart disease.   Clinical findings: On examination  Mr. C was found to be dyspneic with blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 92 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Heart sounds were normal with no added sounds.  Diagnostic Assessment: Electrocardiogram revealed ST-segment depression suggestive of ischemia. Mr. C's troponin I levels were also elevated. These findings confirmed an acute coronary syndrome. Coronary angiography confirmed the presence of significant left anterior descending coronary artery stenosis (approximately 70%).  Other lab results indicated glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) of 7.2 % and LDL cholesterol level of 190mg/dl.  Therapeutic Intervention and Follow-up: Mr. C was initially managed with aspirin  clopidogrel  atorvastatin  and low molecular weight heparin. Given the significant coronary artery stenosis  a coronary artery bypass grafting procedure was performed. In the postoperative phase  Mr. C's blood pressure and sugar levels were well controlled. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue with medications  maintain a diet with a low sodium and sugar content  quit smoking  and engage in a moderate exercise regimen. He has been following up for the past 6 months and reports improved quality of life with no recurrent chest pain.  Discussion: This case portrays the common demographic representation in CAD  i.e.  in a 60-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and smoking  all well-established risk factors for CAD.  Conclusion: The prognosis of CAD greatly improves with early identification and intervention. It is crucial to meticulously evaluate patients with risk factors for CAD and offer lifestyle modification advice to prevent disease progression.  Keywords: Coronary Artery Disease  African-American  Male  Hypertension  Diabetes  Smoking

Case Report:  Patient Description: The patient is a 56-year-old African American male born and raised in Baltimore  Maryland. He is married with two adult children. He has worked as a construction worker for over 30 years. He is a smoker  having smoked 15 cigarettes/day for the past 35 years. He also reports a moderate intake of alcohol (2-3 drinks per week). He admits to a diet high in saturated fats and salty foods and a lack of regular physical exercise. The patient has a recorded Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31.5  within the obese range according to the WHO classification.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  diagnosed 6 years back and has been irregular in managing his condition through prescribed treatment. He has hyperlipidemia that has been managed with statins inconsistently for the past 3 years. The patient also suffers from Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  poorly controlled through oral hypoglycemics. Familial history reveals the patient's mother died from a myocardial infarction  and his father has a history of cardiovascular disease.  Presenting Problem: The patient presented to the emergency department with a complaint of acute  severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and shortness of breath that began while he was lifting heavy equipment at work. The pain did not subside with rest.  Investigations and Findings: Electrocardiogram (ECG) in the emergency department indicated ST-segment elevation in II  III  aVF  V5  and V6 leads. Initial Troponin level was elevated at 2.6 ng/mL. These findings are suggestive of acute inferolateral myocardial infarction. Coronary angiography was performed which revealed significant segmental narrowing of the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery and right coronary artery (RCA) suggestive of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Echocardiography showed a reduced ejection fraction of 45%.  Treatment and Follow-up: The patient underwent relevant treatment including percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with the insertion of drug-eluting stents in the LAD and RCA to restore blood flow. Management also includes antihypertensive medication  high-intensity statin for cholesterol  dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors  and medications to manage his diabetes. The importance of lifestyle modifications was emphasized  including smoking cessation  a low-sodium and low-cholesterol diet  regular exercise  and proper medication adherence.  In the follow-up visits  the patient reported reduced chest pain and improved quality of life. He has joined a local gym to maintain regular physical activity and is attending a smoking cessation programme. Adjustments to his medication regimen were made as needed to control his hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes. The patient will require regular monitoring and follow-up to ensure continued improvement of his health status and to prevent the progression of CAD.    Conclusion: This case demonstrates the negative impact of modifiable risk factors on an individual's health. Lifestyle modifications and adherence to prescribed medication can greatly improve a patient's prognosis. This case emphasizes the importance of primary prevention efforts and regular healthcare checkups for earlier detection of chronic diseases like CAD  especially in high-risk groups.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease in a 62-Year-Old Male   Patient Description  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with symptoms related to cardiac discomfort. He has been living in Raleigh  North Carolina  and has pain in the chest and shortness of breath  especially during physical activities. He was unable to indicate any family history of premature heart disease. His past medical history was significant with facing hypertension for ten years  type 2 diabetes mellitus for five years  and dyslipidemia. The patient is a non-smoker and claims very moderate alcohol use. He engaged in regular physical activity  which has been decreasing over the last six months due to fatigue and breathlessness.  Clinical Findings  Upon arriving at the clinic  his blood pressure was 145/95 mm Hg  pulse rate was 80 beats per minute  and BMI was 30 kg/m2 indicative of obesity. Cardiovascular examination showed a regular rhythm  no murmurs or gallops. The rest of his physical examination was unremarkable. Laboratory data revealed elevated blood glucose and HbA1c levels  attesting to poor diabetic control. His LDL cholesterol was also above target levels.   Diagnosis and Treatment  Based on these clinical presentations and the results of additional investigations - a resting electrocardiogram (ECG) that demonstrated ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion  and a stress test confirming ischemia  the patient was diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD). The diagnosis was later confirmed by coronary angiography showing a 70% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery.   The patient was deemed suitable for medical management. He was prescribed aspirin  a beta-blocker (Metoprolol)  an ACE inhibitor (Lisinopril)  a statin drug (Atorvastatin)  and a medication to control his blood sugar levels (Metformin). The patient was educated about lifestyle modification including smoking cessation  management of hypertension and dyslipidemia  diabetes regulation  moderate-intensity exercises  and a healthy diet.   Conclusion  This case highlights the common occurrence of coronary artery disease in older obese Caucasian males with risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and dyslipidemia. It emphasizes the importance of proper management of these conditions to prevent serious outcomes like myocardial infarction or stroke. The patient's cardiologist will monitor him regularly for any advancement in symptoms or need for intervention such as angioplasty or bypass surgery. It's also crucial to ensure the patient's compliance with medication and lifestyle modifications.   References  Will follow guidelines in accordance with the Journal of Medical Case Reports.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: Jason Morgan  a 62-year-old African American male  presented to the heart clinic in a state of constant discomfort and fatigue. He lives in the suburbs of Chicago  Illinois. Jason is a retired public school teacher who is married with two adult children. He has been a smoker for the past 35 years with a smoking history of 20 pack years. Jason is moderately alcohol-consuming person and lives a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activity. His family history reveals his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 64  and his mother suffered from hypertension and diabetes.  Past Medical History: Jason's medical record shows diagnosed hypertension and type 2 diabetes for the last 10 years  and he is currently on medication (Metformin for diabetes  Amlodipine for hypertension). He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and is on statins for the same.   Presenting Complaints: The patient arrived at the clinic complaining of recurring episodes of chest pain  especially during his attempts at light physical activity like climbing stairs. He also reported shortness of breath  nausea  sweating  and dizziness. Jason remarked his symptoms had been getting progressively worse over the last two weeks.  Examination & Investigation: On physical examination  his blood pressure was high at 160/100 mm Hg. The patient underwent a thorough diagnostic workup  including an electrocardiogram (ECG)  and a computerized tomography (CT) scan. His lipid profile showed elevated cholesterol levels. The angiogram findings revealed substantial blockage in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery and left circumflex artery. The team also performed an Echocardiogram that exhibited a lower ejection fraction  indicative of mild heart failure.  Diagnosis & Management: Considering the above clinical findings  demographic risk factors  and his symptoms  Jason was diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD) with a moderate risk of MI in future. The patient was immediately started on a comprehensive treatment plan. In addition to ongoing medications for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  treatment incorporated antiplatelet medicine  ACE inhibitors  and beta-blockers. A statin was also prescribed to control his cholesterol levels.  Moreover  Jason has been referred to the hospital’s cardiac rehabilitation program  where he will undergo sessions of supervised exercises. Also  the patient has been counseled regarding lifestyle modifications  including smoking cessation  diabetes management  regular physical exercise  and a heart-healthy diet plan.   Follow-Up: Jason has been scheduled a follow-up after 45 days to assess his condition  evaluate therapeutic response  and adjust the regimen if necessary. He was urged to seek immediate help if his symptoms worsened or he experienced severe chest pain. His family was also educated about the signs of a potential heart attack and the need for prompt action.  In Conclusion: This case portrays that managing CAD requires a comprehensive treatment plan  including lifestyle modifications  pharmacological management  and close follow-ups considering the severity and progression of the disease.

Title: Late-Onset Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) in a Non-obese  Non-smoking South Asian Male: A Case Report   Introduction:  A 65-year-old South Asian male presented with symptoms of persistent chest pain. The purpose of this report is to document the unusual presentation and course of his condition given his relative overall health and absence of major risk factors.  Patient Information:  Mr. A  a retired school teacher  grew up and resided in northern India until he retired two years ago  after which he relocated to the United States to live with his son. He reported having a well-controlled diabetic condition for the past 15 years but no history of hypertension  high cholesterol  or cardiovascular diseases. He had never smoked or consumed alcohol  and his diet was primarily vegetarian. His BMI was within normal limits (22.2 kg/m2). There was a family history of CAD with both his father and older brother who had been diagnosed above the age of 65.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient had tachycardia with an initial blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. Cardiovascular exam demonstrated minor non-specific ST-T wave abnormalities on ECG. Blood analysis showed mildly elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol (130 mg/dL)  but other lab parameters—such as triglycerides  HDL cholesterol  fasting blood sugar (FBS)  and HbA1c—were within normal range. No evidence of infection was found in the blood cultures.   Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  The patient underwent exercise stress testing  which was positive for inducible myocardial ischemia. The subsequent coronary angiography revealed 70% stenosis in the mid-left anterior descending branch and 50% stenosis in the right coronary artery.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the angiographic findings  the patient was prescribed a regimen that included aspirin  a statin  and a beta-blocker. A decision for an elective coronary artery bypass surgery was made considering the extent of the disease and his risk factors.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient tolerated the CABG procedure well and exhibited adequate recovery over the subsequent week. He was discharged with instructions to follow a strict medication regimen and advised lifestyle modifications. In subsequent follow-ups  the patient reported decreased symptoms of chest pain and improved general well-being.  Discussion:  This case report underlines the significant risk of CAD in South Asians irrespective of classic risk factors such as obesity  a high-fat diet  and smoking. Genetic predisposition  combined with type 2 diabetes—a common condition in this demographic—may play an important role in CAD development. This calls for increased surveillance and primary prevention efforts  even in seemingly healthy individuals who don't exhibit traditional CAD risk factors.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in an Elderly Female Patient with A History of Hypertension and Hypercholesterolemia  I. Patient Information  The patient is a 74-year-old Caucasian female from the Midwestern United States  living in an urban setting. She is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history who quit smoking 15 years ago. She is widowed and lives alone. She has two children who live out of state and visit occasionally.  II. Clinical Findings and Past Medical History  The patient presented in the clinic with recurrent substernal chest pain exacerbated by physical exertion and relieved by rest. The patient has a known medical history of hypertension  diagnosed 12 years ago  which is controlled on Losartan 50mg daily. She's also been treated for hypercholesterolemia  confirmed 10 years ago  on Atorvastatin 20mg once daily. Her cholesterol levels being monitored regularly and maintained within normal ranges. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with both parents having experienced myocardial infarctions above the age of 60.  III. Diagnostic Method  Electrocardiography at rest showed no myocardial ischemia but certain abnormalities were noted upon stress testing and echo-cardiograph (TMT)  with ST-segment depression triggered by activity. Her Laboratory investigation showed high-sensitivity Troponin I elevated at 0.04 ng/ml. Furthermore  a coronary angiogram was performed  revealing significant stenosis in the left anterior descending artery and the right coronary artery with 70-80% blockage.  IV. Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was started on sublingual Nitroglycerin as needed for chest pain and was recommended for a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with angioplasty and stent implantation. The medication regimen included dual anti-platelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  continuation of atorvastatin  and angiotensin receptor blockers  with a possible addition of beta-blockers.   V. Follow up and Outcome Post-operative recovery was uneventful. After a period of monitoring  the patient was discharged and provided with meticulous guidance about lifestyle changes  including low-sodium  low-cholesterol diet  regular exercise  and follow-up appointments. She was also referred to a cardiologist for further management. With the recommended therapy and interventions  her chest pain ceased  and her lifestyle and heart function saw marked improvements.   This case underlines the importance of assessing patients as individuals rather than just their symptoms while providing perspective into the management and treatment of coronary artery disease in patients with a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia.

Case Report: A 63-Year-Old Male with Severe Coronary Artery Disease   Patient Identifier: XY12345  Demographics: XY12345 is a 63-year-old African-American male with a body mass index (BMI) of 32  technically classified as obese. He has been married for 37 years and has three adult children. He is a retired mechanic  and he currently resides in a suburban community in the mid-west. He is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol.  Chief Complaint and History of Present Illness: The patient presented to the clinic complaining of intermittent episodes of chest pain over the past 3 months. The chest pain was described as a heavy feeling  usually lasting for 10-15 minutes  predominantly occurring following physical exertion but resolving with rest. He also reported episodes of shortness of breath during mild physical activities.  Past Medical History: XY12345 has a known history of hypertension for 10 years  for which he was prescribed antihypertensive medications. However  he has been inconsistent in taking his prescribed medication. He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes 8 years ago  and it has been controlled with Metformin and lifestyle modification. He does not have any allergy to drugs or food.   Family History: He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father had myocardial infarction at the age of 71  and his oldest sister was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Social History: The patient leads a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity. His diet is predominantly high in carbohydrates  and saturated fats with low fruit  and vegetable intake which is relatively typical in his community. His stress levels show a significant increase post-retirement due to reduced social contact  financial constraints  and transitioning to his current lifestyle.  Clinical Findings: On examination  his blood pressure was elevated at 155/95 mmHg. Overall  findings from routine physical examination were within normal limits except for obesity. However  chest retractions were observed during the episodes of breathlessness  and cardiac auscultation revealed a soft systolic murmur.  Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed T-wave inversion in the inferior leads. Elevated fasting glucose and cholesterol levels were noted in the laboratory findings suggestive of poorly controlled diabetes and hypercholesterolemia  respectively. A coronary angiogram was recommended based on the patient's symptoms  ECG changes  and risk factors  which confirmed the presence of triple vessel disease.  Management: The patient received counseling on the importance of medication adherence  lifestyle modifications  including smoking cessation  increased physical activity  and a healthier diet. A cardiologist initiated him on additional medications including a statin  aspirin  and a beta-blocker. Based on the angiogram results  the patient was referred for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).  Conclusion: This case underlines the importance of medication adherence  lifestyle modifications  and regular follow-ups in patients with known risk factors for coronary artery disease (CAD). It also highlights the importance of coronary angiography in symptomatic patients with multiple risk factors for CAD for early diagnosis and management. The findings of the patient also correspond with demographic representation in literature related to African-American males in their 60's being at an increased risk for developing severe coronary artery disease. His case further emphasizes the importance of addressing these risk factors to potentially decrease the incidence of CAD in this population.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Information -----------------------  Name: Patient X Age: 64 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Marital Status: Married Occupation: Retired mechanic Location: Minnesota  USA  Presentation  The patient presented with shortness of breath and irregular angina  particularly during physical activity. These symptoms had been progressively worsening over a span of last six months.   Medical History  The patient has a medical history of hypertension managed with medication for the last 10 years  dyslipidemia  and non-insulin dependent type 2 diabetes diagnosed 7 years ago  which has been irregularly controlled with metformin. His father had coronary artery disease (CAD) and passed away due to a heart attack at the age of 56. The patient quit smoking a year ago but had been smoking a pack a day for 30 years. The patient also has a 15-year history of heavy alcohol use but has recently limited his alcohol consumption to moderate levels.  Physical Examination  On examination  blood pressure was 155/95 mmHg and pulse was 85 beats per minute with a regular rhythm. The patient appeared typically healthy for his age  but seemed anxious due to ongoing chest pain. He was slightly overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 27.5. The patient's cardiac examination revealed normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs  rubs or gallops. The respiratory examination was normal and no abnormalities were noted in the abdomen and extremities.   Investigations  Given his symptoms and history  a detailed lipid profile was done  results of which supported dyslipidemia. Cardiac markers were tested and Troponin I was found to be slightly elevated. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed a slight ST-segment depression. A coronary angiography was recommended to confirm the suspected diagnosis.  Diagnosis  The coronary angiography revealed a 70% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery (LAD) confirming the diagnosis of coronary artery disease.  Treatment  Patient was continued on his anti-hypertensive medication and metformin. Aspirin and a statin were added to his medication regimen. Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement was planned for dealing with the obstructed artery. He was also recommended to continue smoking cessation and moderate alcohol consumption and to adopt a healthier lifestyle including a low-sodium  low-saturated fat diet and regular exercise.  Discussion  This case illuminates the effects of common modifiable risk factors of CAD like hypertension  smoking  uncontrolled diabetes  dyslipidemia and alcohol use. Screening  prevention  and management of these conditions is fundamental to prevent severe complications like CAD. The need for lifestyle management in addition to pharmacological treatment is also highlighted in this case.  The case conforms to the often-observed epidemiological pattern of higher incidence of CAD in males above 60 years of age  with a history of familial heart disease  which is more prevalent among Caucasians compared to other racial or ethnic groups.

Patient Profile: Mr. R  a 63-year-old African American male  who is employed as a taxi driver  presented to the emergency department (ED) with recurrent chest pain  shortness of breath  and fatigue. He resides in an urban environment in Chicago  Illinois  lives alone but has a close network of friends and family.  Past Medical History: Mr. R has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  along with type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he has been on metformin for seven years. He is a former smoker  quitting five years ago  but acknowledged a substantial smoking history of 30 pack-years prior. His body mass index is 30.4 kg/m2  indicating obesity. He has no history of alcohol or illicit substance use. He has no documented personal or family history of myocardial infarction. Increased work schedules had led to sporadic adherence to prescribed antihypertensive medicine  and a preference for high sodium fast food.  Presenting Complaints: He reported having intermittent episodes of chest pain over the past three weeks with the pain lasting from five minutes to as long as one hour. He described the pain as a heavy  central chest pressure radiating to his left shoulder. The pain increased in intensity during physical effort and emotional stress  and receded with rest. Accompanying symptoms included shortness of breath  cold sweats  and unexplained fatigue. No cough  fever  or weight loss was reported.  Examination: At presentation  his vitals were stable except for elevated blood pressure (150/90 mmHg) and an irregular heart rate of 85 beats per minute. Cardiovascular examination detected a fourth heart sound (S4) along with decreased breath sounds in the lower right lung field.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Electrocardiogram showed T wave inversions and ST-segment depressions suggestive of myocardial ischemia. Blood investigation results showed elevated levels of cardiac enzymes (troponin T)  reinforcing the suspicion of coronary artery disease. Left heart catheterization revealed 70% blockage in the left anterior descending artery  confirming the diagnosis.  Management and Outcome: Mr. R was managed with thrombolytic therapy along with nitrates and intravenous heparin. Subsequently  he was scheduled for coronary artery bypass grafting for long-term management. Lifestyle modification and adherence to medications for hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia were also emphasized.  Conclusion: Mr. R's case draws attention to several important aspects such as the impact of non-compliance to lifestyle modifications and medications in patients with comorbid conditions like hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. As the patient is from a high-risk demographic group  it underscores the need for targeted health education about the importance of adherence to treatment  regular check-ups  and a healthy lifestyle to prevent complications such as coronary artery disease.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Profile: - Name: [Anonymous for privacy reasons] - Gender: Male - Age: 63-years-old - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Machinist - Residence: Urban area  Boston  Massachusetts  Clinical History: The patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes mellitus diagnosed at the age of 50 and is currently under management with a combination of Metformin and Sitagliptin. He also has mild Hypertension  controlled with Hydrochlorothiazide and Atenolol for the last 5 years. There is history of smoking  roughly 1 pack/day for 35 years  but he quit 3 years ago. Patient is slightly overweight with a BMI (Body mass index) of 27. Reports moderate alcohol consumption.  Family history includes his father experiencing a myocardial infarction at age 67 and his older brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD) at age 60. There is no known history of any familial hyperlipidemia.   Presenting Complaints: The patient visited the clinic with complaints of increasing episodes of exertional chest pain for the past 8 weeks. He describes the pain as a constricting discomfort localized in the center of his chest and occasionally radiating towards his left arm. He has also experienced episodes of shortness of breath post moderate physical activity.  Physical Examination: A thorough physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg and a resting pulse rate of 72 beats per minute. Chest auscultation was unremarkable. Examination of the cardiovascular system showed no signs of heart failure  with no peripheral edema or jugular venous distention noticed.   Investigations & Tests: An electrocardiogram (ECG) performed at rest displayed minor ST-T wave changes. Blood tests were ordered which showed moderately elevated LDL cholesterol levels (LDL-C 180mg/dL) and raised fasting blood glucose levels of 140mg/dL. His HbA1c was 7.2%.   Given the history of chest pain and findings from the ECG  the cardiologist suggested doing a treadmill stress test  which showed ST depressions in the inferior and lateral leads during exercise. This suggested significant ischemia.  The patient was then referred for coronary angiography  which showed triple-vessel coronary artery disease with significant (>70%) stenosis in the left anterior descending artery (LAD)  the right coronary artery (RCA)  and the circumflex artery (LCX).  Diagnosis: Based on the history  clinical presentation  and results of diagnostic tests  the patient was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease with significant narrowing in 3 vessels - LAD  RCA  and LCX.  Treatment and Follow-up: The presence of significant three-vessel disease in this patient necessitates that he be considered for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG). He was commenced on aspirin  a statin (Atorvastatin) for cholesterol control  and a beta-blocker (Atenolol). His diabetic medications were reviewed and continued. Lifestyle modifications were also prescribed including regular exercise  a healthy diet  and cessation of alcohol.   The patient  on understanding the severity of his disease  agreed to undergo CABG at the earliest convenience. For the same  he was referred to a cardiothoracic team. He was also referred for cardiac rehabilitation post-surgery to aid in his recovery and help reduce the risk of future cardiac events.   This patient’s diagnosis and treatment highlight the vital importance of early identification  suitable intervention  and suitable risk factor management in CAD. His case will be continually reviewed at cardiology follow-up appointments.                                     [This case report is intended for educational purposes only and not as medical advice. Any specific queries should be directed to a healthcare professional.]

Title: Case Report: Management of Coronary Artery Disease in a 66-year-old Hispanic Female with a History of Hypertension and Type-2 Diabetes   Patient Information:  The patient is a 66-year-old Hispanic female  community-dweller  and a retired teacher. She is a widow with three adult children. She is a nonsmoker and reports occasional alcohol consumption.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of type-2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 12 years and has been under medication for both conditions. The patient's blood sugars and blood pressure readings are generally well-controlled under medication. She has a family history of cardiovascular disease with her father dying of a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. The patient is also overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 29.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presented at the clinic with occasional chest discomfort over the past month which she described as a feeling of pressure and tightness  in the central part of her chest  especially during physical activity or exposure to cold.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared mildly anxious. Vital signs measured were blood pressure at 150/85 mmHg  resting heart rate of 78 beats per minute  respirations at 18 per minute  and an O2 saturation level of 96% on room air. Her physical examination was notable for a normal rhythm without murmur  rub  or gallop on cardiac auscultation. No edema was noted in lower extremities. Her lab results showed elevated LDL cholesterol of 170 mg/dL and a Hemoglobin A1C of 7.6%.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An Electrocardiography (ECG) showed normal sinus rhythm but with T wave inversions in the inferolateral leads. Following the ECG  a stress test was conducted which the patient was unable to complete due to fatigue and increasing chest pain. Following the stress test  the patient underwent a coronary angiography which revealed significant stenosis in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery and the right coronary artery (RCA).  Therapeutic Intervention: As the patient was symptomatic and angiography showed significant stenosis  she was referred for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Two stents were successfully placed in the LAD artery and RCA  resulting in improvement in the blood flow. The patient was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor  a high-intensity statin therapy  and medications for her hypertension and diabetes were reviewed and adjusted.   Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient was discharged 3 days post-PCI with instructions for strict medication adherence  lifestyle modifications including diet control  increased physical activity  and regular follow-up visits. At the 1-month follow-up  the patient reported marked improvement in chest discomfort and overall well-being.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed satisfaction with the care received and was grateful for the improved quality of life post-intervention. She showed commitment toward medication adherence and lifestyle changes for healthier living.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images.

Patient Profile:   Gender: Male Age: 65 years  Ethnicity: Caucasian Country of Residence: USA  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented with complaints of chest pain radiating to the left arm and intermittent breathlessness that has been occurring for the last six months  but has progressively worsened over the past week. The patient also reported palpitations  fatigue  and episodes of dizziness.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  having been diagnosed 15 years ago. He also has a history of smoking for the past 20 years but quit 5 years ago. His father had a heart attack at the age of 60.  Current Medications:  The patient currently takes amlodipine 5mg OD for hypertension and Simvastatin 40mg nocte for hyperlipidemia.  Examination:  On examination  the patient was conscious  oriented with mild respiratory distress. Blood pressure measured was 150/90 mmHg; Pulse rate was 88 bpm; Oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. He had a BMI of 28 indicating overweight. Cardiovascular examination revealed soft S1 with S4 gallop. Auscultation of the lungs was clear bilaterally.  Investigation:  The patient's blood tests included a full blood count  a lipid profile  cardiac biomarkers  a liver function test  and kidney function test  the results showed raised LDL cholesterol levels and increased Troponin I levels. ECG revealed T-wave inversion and ST-segment depression in the anterior leads  suggesting ischemia.   Management/Intervention:  The patient was admitted to the hospital’s cardiac care unit. Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  along with a beta-blocker (metoprolol)  an ACE inhibitor (lisinopril)  and a statin (at high-intensity  such as atorvastatin)  were initiated per guidelines for managing acute coronary syndrome  and a diet low in sodium and cholesterol was recommended. An early invasive strategy (angiography) was deemed necessary given the patient's high risk from clinical and ECG findings.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of promptly recognizing and managing coronary artery disease in a high-risk individual who was symptomatic and had multiple risk factors. Despite the challenges associated with comorbid conditions  implementing evidence-based guideline-directed medical therapy is crucial for optimizing patient outcomes.  NOTE: The case report above represents a typical situation and does not reflect any specific individual’s medical condition. Also  the practices described are based on standard medical protocols and may vary based on individual circumstances or evolving research. The information should be used cautiously and always should be discussed with a qualified healthcare provider.

Patient Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  1. Introduction:  Coronary artery disease (CAD) is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. This case study is of a 63-year-old male diagnosed with coronary artery disease. The aim is to provide insights into prevention  diagnosis  and management of this disease. This disease's dominant risk factors are age  male gender  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  diabetes  smoking  and obesity.  2. Patient Information:  The patient is a 63-year-old African American male  employed as a mechanic  residing in the urban district of Houston  Texas. He is a widower with two adult children. He has a history of smoking approximately one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and occasionally drinking alcohol. The patient's social history also reveals minimal physical activity and a diet rich in fast food heavily salted and fried. The patient is not on regular medication and does not have any known drug allergies.  3. Clinical findings:  The patient had been experiencing chest pain  shortness of breath on exertion  fatigue  and periodic episodes of perspiration and palpitations for the past six months. These symptoms were initially sporadic and mild but increased in frequency and intensity over time  affecting his daily activities and prompting medical consultation.  4. Timeline:  Upon arrival at the clinic  the patient was put under observation  and all relevant tests were ordered. Physical examination revealed hypertension  with a blood pressure of 160/95mmHg  and a body mass index of 30.5  classifying him as obese. An electrocardiogram (ECG) performed showed T-wave inversion in the anterior leads.  5. Diagnostic assessment:  Following the initial examination  laboratory tests indicated elevated lipid profile with total cholesterol of 7.1 mmol/L  Low Density Lipoproteins (LDL) of 4.9 mmol/L  and High Density Lipoproteins (HDL) of 1.0 mmol/L. Fasting blood sugar tests showed a blood glucose level of 130 mg/dL  suggesting an undiagnosed type 2 diabetes. A subsequent exercise stress test demonstrated ST-depression  and the patient was referred for cardiac catheterization  which revealed significant obstructive lesions in the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery and the right coronary artery.  6. Therapeutic intervention:  Following the diagnosis  a collaborative approach involving lifestyle modification  pharmacotherapy and interventional cardiology was adopted. The patient was counseled about smoking cessation  regular exercise  and following a balanced diet. He was prescribed aspirin  β-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  and high-grade statins for cholesterol management. Given the severity of his CAD  he underwent coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery.  7. Follow-up and outcomes:  Postoperative recovery was uneventful  and the patient displayed marked improvement in terms of symptom relief and cardiovascular function. Close follow-up will be necessary to monitor his adherence to lifestyle modifications and medication. He is scheduled for regular follow-up appointments with interventional cardiology  endocrinology and a dietitian  given his diabetes and the need for lifestyle modification.  8. Discussion:  This case underscores the importance of early detection and comprehensive management of CAD  especially in patients with multiple risk factors. CAD is a preventable disease if modifiable risk factors  such as smoking  physical inactivity  obesity  and uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension  are appropriately managed. A multidisciplinary approach is necessary to make sustainable lifestyle changes and effectively manage the disease.  9. Patient Perspective:  Following his recovery  the patient acknowledges that the sudden diagnosis of coronary artery disease made him realize the importance of lifestyle modification  routine health checkups  and early intervention for symptom management. He has expressed motivation to commit to a healthier lifestyle and regular follow-up.

Patient Information: Mr. S.K.  a 55-year-old Asian male  normal body mass index of 22.1 kg/m2. He is a resident of metropolitan city  employed as a corporate lawyer.  Chief Complaint: He came to the hospital with symptoms like severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and increased fatigue  persisting intermittently for the past 7 days and progressively increasing in intensity. He reported that the pain is often provoked by physical exercises and subsided during rest.  Past Medical History: Mr. S.K. has a history of hypertension for the past 10 years  for which he was on medication (Losartan 50 mg daily). He was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus 5 years ago  for which he was taking Metformin 500mg twice daily. He has a history of smoking for 25 years  consuming more than 15 cigarettes per day  but has quit smoking for the last 3 years. There is also a family history of coronary artery disease(CAD); his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58.  Physical Examination: Mr. S.K was in apparent distress  appeared chronically ill. The blood pressure was 150/95 mmHg and the heart rate was 92 beats per minute. His radial pulses were regular but weak. Heart sounds were muffled  with no gallop or rubs. He had slight pallor and the Chest examination was normal with clear lung bases bilaterally.  Diagnostic Assessment: The ECG showed ST-segment depression and T wave inversion suggestive of myocardial ischemia. A lipid panel test showed elevated levels; LDL cholesterol level was 166 mg/dL and total cholesterol was 240 mg/dL. Fasting plasma glucose level was 200mg/dl. Coronary angiography showed critical narrowing (>70%) in the left anterior descending artery and right coronary artery.   Therapeutic Intervention: Mr. S.K was admitted to the coronary care unit. An emergency percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was performed for the occluded left anterior descending artery and stenting was done. Antiplatelet therapy with aspirin (325 mg) and clopidogrel (75 mg /day) was started. Modification of his antihypertensive medication was made; amlodipine (10mg/day) was added. His antidiabetic medications were optimized.  Follow-up and Outcome: He was discharged 5 days later with advice to continue medications  regular follow-ups  and lifestyle modifications. Regular physical exercise  calorie-restricted diet  and stress management were recommended. One month after discharge  his symptoms improved  BP and blood sugar were well-controlled. He is currently in the cardiac rehabilitation program.  In conclusion  this case emphasizes the significance of aggressive management of modifiable risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  and smoking for CAD  early detection  and management of CAD to prevent further serious complications like myocardial infarction in high-risk individuals.

Title: A Case Report on Coronary Artery Disease in a 53-year-old Caucasian Male  Introduction: This case report describes a Caucasian male with a diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) set against a background of multiple risks factors.  Patient Information: The patient  Mr. B  is a 53-year-old Caucasian man  living in the inner city of Chicago  Illinois. He is a long-term smoker with a 30-pack-year history. He is employed as an office administrator  leading a sedentary lifestyle with no regular physical exercise. Mr. B stands 5'9"" tall and weighs 220 pounds  with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32.5  categorizing him as obese. He lives with his wife  and they have two grown-up children who are not living with them. He reports that he drinks alcohol moderately  with the consumption of approximately 10 units per week. He denies any illicit drug use.  Medical History: Mr. B has a significant past medical history. He has been treated for hypertension for the past ten years and for type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past five years. He also has hyperlipidemia for which he intermittently takes cholesterol-lowering medication. His father had myocardial infarction at the age of 62  and his mother was diagnosed with stroke at 67 years of age. There is no record of him having any allergies or infectious diseases.  Case Presentation: Mr. B presented to the emergency department with an acute onset of central chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain was associated with profuse perspiration and shortness of breath. His initial electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  indicative of an acute anterior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Blood tests revealed elevated troponin levels. He received immediate thrombolytic therapy as per hospital protocol  and a stat echocardiogram revealed left ventricular dysfunction.  Intervention and Outcome: Subsequently  a cardiac catheterization was performed  which showed triple-vessel disease. He underwent successful coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery involving three vessels. Postoperatively  Mr. B was started on a comprehensive medical regimen including aspirin  beta-blocker  ACE inhibitor  and statin. He was found to show significant improvement during two weeks of cardiac rehabilitation.   Discussion: Our patient  a 53-year-old Caucasian male with a significant risk factor profile  including age  obesity  smoking history  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  sedentary lifestyle  and family history  presented with typical symptoms of CAD. This case underscores the composite role of major cardiovascular risk factors in the development of CAD.   Conclusion: Given the patient’s multiple risk factors and late presentation to the hospital  this case underscores the importance of early recognition and management of cardiovascular risk factors and timely access to healthcare services in the prevention of CAD and its complications.

Case Report: 68-year-old African-American male presenting with Coronary Artery Disease  Introduction: This case involves a 68-year-old African-American male who presented complaining of episodic chest pain worsening over the past 2 months. Primarily targeted towards primary care physicians  this case detail serves to enhance recognition and appropriate management of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Patient Information: The patient is a retired long-time resident of New York City  living with his wife in an apartment. He is an ex-smoker  having quit 10 years ago after a 30-year history of smoking. He has had a sedentary lifestyle since his retirement and a self-reported diet high in fat and low in fruits and vegetables.  Clinical Findings: The patient complained of central chest pain which was usually precipitated by exertion and relieved by rest and nitroglycerin. The character of the pain was often described as “pressure” or “squeezing” and sometimes associated with shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  for which he is on metformin and lisinopril  respectively. He has no known allergies. The patient has no prior surgeries and his family history is significant for CAD in his father who died at the age of 60.  Investigations: Electrocardiogram (EKG) on admission showed nonspecific ST segment and T wave changes. Lab results were significant for elevated cholesterol levels. The patient underwent an exercise stress test which demonstrated ST depressions indicative of myocardial ischemia.  Diagnosis: Considering the patient's clinical presentation  past medical history  and results from the investigations  he was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease.  Management and Follow-up: The patient was started on a beta-blocker  a statin for his elevated cholesterol levels  and aspirin as prophylaxis for his CAD. He was also advised to incorporate lifestyle modifications for risk reduction. These were to comprise a healthy balanced diet  regular physical activities  maintaining a healthy weight and continued abstinence from smoking. Patient was subsequently referred for cardiac catheterization to further evaluate the extent of disease and to guide possible revascularization strategy.  Psychosocial Considerations: Given the associated risk of anxiety and depression in patients with CAD  mental health screenings and potential treatment referrals were recommended during follow-up appointments.  This case highlights the need for ongoing management and secondary prevention in elderly patients with coronary disease. Controlling risk factors with both lifestyle modifications and pharmacological interventions can help reduce disease progression and improve overall patient outcomes.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who resides in a suburban community west of Chicago  IL. He is a retired mechanical engineer  currently living with his wife. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and has a 40-year history of smoking. He generally drinks alcohol socially  approximately two to three units per week.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  diagnosed when he was 50 years old  and hyperlipidemia  diagnosed a decade later. He has been on medication for both conditions. He has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father having had a heart attack at the age of 60. The patient himself had a myocardial infarction (heart attack) at the age of 65  and at that time underwent a triple coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). He is also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and is taking metformin.  Presenting Problem: The patient came into the clinic complaining of chest pain radiating to his left arm and shortness of breath  which was exacerbated with exertion and partially relieved by rest. These symptoms have been occurring intermittently for the last two weeks. The patient states that he has experienced some nausea and diaphoresis (excessive sweat) during these episodes.  Investigation and Diagnosis: An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed T-wave inversion and ST elevation  suggesting myocardial ischemia. Coronary angiography revealed significant coronary artery stenosis in the left main and circumflex coronary arteries. The right coronary artery graft was occluded  and the other two grafts from the previous CABG were stenosed. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed normal left ventricular function with an ejection fraction of 60-65%.   In light of these findings  the diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) was made  with angina pectoris due to multiple vessel disease and occluded grafts.  Treatment: A drug regimen was started  including aspirin  beta-blockers  and an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. Percutaneous coronary intervention was deemed too high risk due to the patient's age  severity of disease  and poor graft status. After discussing with the patient and his family  a decision was made for non-invasive management and lifestyle modifications.  The patient was advised to quit smoking  reduce alcohol consumption  and initiate a low-sodium  low-cholesterol diet. Regular exercise was recommended under the supervision of a cardiac rehabilitation team. Stress management was also advised.   The patient is scheduled for regular follow-ups to monitor symptom progression and the impact of lifestyle changes on disease management.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a 62-Year-Old African American Male  Case Report:  Patient Information:  The patient is a 62-year-old African American male  who lives in an urban environment.  Presenting compliants: The patient reported experiencing frequent episodes of chest discomfort and fatigue  especially during physical activities or periods of stress.   Medical history: The patient had a history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for which he had been managed on medication. His BMI pointed towards moderate obesity and he reported a lifestyle that included poor diet and sedentary behaviour with limited physical exercise. He had a 30-year smoking history  smoking about half a pack of cigarettes daily. There was no personal history of other cardiovascular diseases or surgeries. His family history is significant as his father had coronary artery disease and underwent a myocardial infarction at the age of 68.   Clinical findings: Physical examination revealed that the patient had a blood pressure reading of 150/90 mmHg. Other findings were fairly normal  and lung auscultation was clear. However  cardiac examination revealed a quiet systolic murmur in the aortic area which radiated to the carotids.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The patient's ECG revealed T-wave inversions indicative of possible myocardial ischemia. A complete blood panel was ordered which revealed elevated fasting blood sugar  suboptimal lipid profile (raised total cholesterol and LDL  reduced HDL) and increased HbA1c (7.1%). The patient was then referred for a coronary angiogram which revealed significant stenosis in the proximal segment of the Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery.  Therapeutic interventions: Initial treatment involved providing the patient with sublingual nitroglycerin for immediate symptom relief. Subsequently  the patient was advised to take secondary preventive measures including lifestyle modifications  such as regular physical activity  healthy diet  smoking cessation and weight loss. Medications prescribed were Aspirin 81mg daily  Atorvastatin 40mg daily  Metformin 500mg twice daily  Ramipril 5mg daily and Metoprolol 50mg twice daily. Considering the significant stenosis in the coronary angiogram  he was recommended to undergo angioplasty with stent placement for revascularization.  Follow-Up: The patient was recommended for regular follow-up visits on a monthly basis. He was also referred to a dietitian and a physiotherapist for dietary consultation and exercising instructions respectively.  Conclusion: This patient’s case emphasizes the importance of significant lifestyle modifications  regular monitoring for early detection of disease progression  and optimal control of risk factors in the management of coronary artery disease. It is particularly important in African American populations who are at a greater risk for this disease.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Information:  Mr. J  a 58-year-old African American male  born and raised in Utah  United States  presented himself to our clinic. He has recently retired from his job as a truck driver and currently lives with his wife. He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and admits to a sedentary lifestyle with sparse irregular physical activity. He has a family history of heart diseases  with his father having passed away from a myocardial infarction in his mid-60s.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  diagnosed five years ago  for which he's been prescribed hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg once daily. He also has hyperlipidemia for which he's treated with atorvastatin 20 mg daily. However  he admits to occasional non-compliance with his medications. He does not have diabetes. His BMI is currently 29.5 kg/m2  with a waist circumference of 105 cm  indicative of abdominal obesity.  Presenting Issue:  Mr. J presented to the clinic primarily complaining of moderate  dull  constricting chest pain radiating towards his left arm and neck that started a week ago. He noticed the pain mainly occurs after meals and during instances of emotional stress but alleviates with rest. He has also complained of recent bouts of shortness of breath and excessive fatigue on minimal exertion  such as climbing stairs or walking short distances.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  his blood pressure was elevated at 150/95 mm Hg. Heart sounds were normal with no murmur  but his heart rate was slightly increased. He demonstrated reduced pulmonary ventilation but no edema. Blood tests revealed elevated levels of LDL cholesterol (190 mg/dL)  triglycerides (245 mg/dL)  and hs-CRP (4.5 mg/L). His HbA1C was within normal limits.  Diagnosis:  Given the nature of the symptoms  clinical examination findings  blood results  and his high-risk profile - male  age  smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history of heart disease  the initial diagnosis was stable angina due to Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). This was later confirmed by an abnormal exercise stress test and subsequent angiography showing significant stenosis in the left anterior descending and right coronary arteries.  Treatment:  In addition to optimal medical therapy with aspirin  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and high dose statins  the patient was also referred to a cardiologist for further assessment and consideration of revascularization strategies. Lifestyle management guidance was provided  including dietary changes  regular exercise  smoking cessation  and maintaining medication compliance.  Follow-up & Adherence:  Mr. J was scheduled for follow-up in our heart clinic monthly for the first three months and then every 3 months afterward. He was also enrolled in a patient education program to help recognize the importance of adhering to his medical and lifestyle modification regime.  Teaching Points:  This case emphasizes the significance of early symptom recognition and intervention in individuals with CAD. Notably  lifestyle modifications combined with correct adherence to medication are critical in managing CAD and its complications.

Title: Presentation and Management of Coronary Arthritis Disease in a Middle-aged Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Coronary artery disease (CAD) remains a leading cause of death globally. This case exemplifies the importance of proactive management in preventing CAD related complications.  Patient Information: Mr. J  a 56-year-old African-American male  from a mid-sized urban city in the United States presented to the outpatient clinic for a routine check-up. His chief complaints were intermittent bouts of left-sided chest pain brought on by moderate intensity exercise  which was relieved by rest. His medical history revealed he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension ten years prior  and he also had a 30-pack year history of smoking.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  the patient had a BMI of 28 indicating overweight  blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg and a heart rate of 85 bpm. His cardiovascular examination uncovered a soft S4 gallop rhythm and mild wheezing in the lower respiratory fields bilaterally.  Diagnostics: The ECG showed horizontal depression of the ST-segment and inverted T-waves in leads V1-V4. Lab results showed slightly elevated blood glucose level  lipid profile and an increased HbA1c. Two-dimensional echocardiography showed a reduced ejection fraction of 50 %.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was diagnosed with CAD and managed by a cardiologist. Interventions included anti-anginal  anti-platelet  lipid-lowering  and anti-hypertensive medication  along with lifestyle interventions such as dietary modification  physical activity enhancement and smoking cessation.  Follow Up and Outcomes: The patient was advised to follow-up every three months to monitor his lipid profile  blood pressure and blood glucose levels. He also received counseling for maintaining a healthy lifestyle. After six months of continuous follow up  his symptoms improved  with lesser episodes of chest pain and controlled diabetes and hypertension. His repeated Echo showed improved cardiac function with ejection fraction of 55%.  Discussion: This case underscores the importance of early diagnosis and management of coronary artery disease  particularly in patients with risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes and a history of smoking. Detecting these factors enables holistic  patient-centered care that can significantly decrease the risk of further cardiovascular events and improve the quality of life.  Patient perspective: The patient expressed relief with the management of his symptoms and regrets neglecting his health for years. He is now personally committed to lifestyle changes in addition to regular medication and clinic follow-up.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for this case report.  Conclusion: An early identification and effective management of risk factors can limit the progression of CAD especially in an individual with multiple risk factors such as the patient in this case.  This case reinforces importance of regular follow up visits and compliance to medication to control the damage from CAD.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a Middle-Aged Man with a History of Smoking and Uncontrolled Hypertension  Introduction:  This case report describes a 57-year-old Caucasian male with previously uncontrolled hypertension  a history of smoking  and Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). This representation aligns with demographic data suggesting that CAD is more frequently diagnosed among middle-aged and older Caucasians  particularly among individuals with relevant risk factors (American Heart Association  2021).  Case Presentation:  The patient  a 57-year-old Caucasian man  presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of intermittent  crushing chest pain radiating towards his left arm for the past three days. He described the pain as 8 on a scale of 1 to 10  occasionally accompanied by shortness of breath and profuse sweating. His past medical history was significant for uncontrolled hypertension for the past seven years and a 25-year smoking history of approximately one pack per day  but he had quit two years ago. The patient admitted that he regularly consumed alcohol but had no history of illicit drug usage. His father had a history of myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  Physical Examination and Investigation:  The patient appeared anxious and pale  with a mildly increased respiratory rate. The initial blood pressure reading was 165/95 mmHg. An electrocardiogram displayed significant ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  aVF  suggesting an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Lab work revealed elevated cardiac enzymes - Troponin I (2.6 ng/mL  ref. <0.04 ng/mL) and CK-MB (55 U/L  ref. <25 U/L). Total cholesterol (245 mg/dL  ref <200 mg/dL) and LDL (160 mg/dL  ref <130 mg/dL) levels were also elevated.   Management and Follow-Up:  Immediately  the patient was started on aspirin  nitroglycerin  and intravenous heparin along with supplemental oxygen. He was then taken for an emergency cardiac catheterization  which confirmed significant three-vessel CAD. The patient underwent a successful coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. He was further recommended for antihypertensive and statin therapy  along with lifestyle modifications involving a low-sodium and low-cholesterol diet. Regular outpatient follow-ups were scheduled for blood pressure and cholesterol monitoring and further medical adjustments.   Conclusion:  This case underscores the undeniable link between CAD and uncontrolled hypertension and smoking. The patient's unhealthy lifestyle choices highlight the importance of primary prevention  indicating that regular monitoring and proper control of blood pressure  cessation of smoking  modification of dietary habits  and regular exercise are crucial for reducing CAD risk among high-risk populations.

Title: Advanced Coronary Artery Disease in a 68-Year-Old African American Male Patient  I. Demographic Information: Patient Identifier: Mr. X Age: 68 years old Gender: Male Race: African American Occupational History: Retired tax consultant Residence: Houston  Texas  II. Chief Complaint: Mr. X sought medical intervention with the chief complaint of chest pain that he described as a ""squeezing"" sensation  extending to his left arm and neck lasting for about 10-30 minutes  often accompanied with light-headedness  shortness of breath  and profuse sweating. These episodes often followed physical exertion or emotional stress.  III. Medical History: Mr. X reported a medical history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus  managed with a stable regimen of lisinopril and metformin for the past eight years. His beyond medical history is remarkable for a 40-pack year smoking history  although he quit smoking ten years ago. He denied any history of major surgeries or familial heart disease. He acknowledges inconsistent compliance to his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medication which could be a contributing factor to his current health status.  IV. Current Medications: 1. Lisinopril 20 mg once per day 2. Metformin 1000 mg twice per day  V. Physical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure was recorded as 158/90 mmHg; heart rate was 96 beats/minute; his BMI was 29  indicating obesity. There were no noticeable physical defects  and the patient was in apparent distress due to pain. Cardiac auscultation revealed no significant murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  VI. Clinical Course: In light of the patient's notable history  clinical examination  and symptoms  a preliminary diagnosis of coronary artery disease was made. Diagnostic tests  including an EKG  echocardiogram  and cardiac catheterization confirmed the diagnosis. The results showed evidence of significant stenosis in his left anterior descending artery and left circumflex artery.   A multidisciplinary team proposed a treatment plan that included lifestyle modifications  continuation of his current medications  and introduction of additional drug treatments including a statin  beta-blocker  and low-dose aspirin. The possibility of revascularization via stent placement or coronary artery bypass grafting was considered pending the patient's stabilization and response to the drug treatments.  VII. Conclusion: This case demonstrates the clinical progression of advanced coronary artery disease in a patient with known risk factors  notably hypertension  type-2 diabetes  a history of smoking  and an element of non-compliance with prescribed treatment. Early detection and strict management of these risk factors are crucial to prevent potential life-threatening complications of coronary artery disease.

Patient Profile  Patient: Mr. J. T. (Initials used to maintain confidentiality) Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Residence: Baltimore  Maryland  US  Presenting Complaint: Mr. JT presented with an intermittent central chest pain for the past three weeks. The pain  which was worsened during exertion  including climbing stairs and carrying heavy objects  lasted for approximately 15-20 minutes. The pain was described as “pressing” in nature and radiated to his left shoulder and arm. He also reported shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and palpitations during the episodes. He sought medical attention due to a noticeable increase in frequency and intensity of these episodes.   Past Medical History: He is a lifelong smoker with a 40-pack year history. He is also a diagnosed hypertensive for the past 10 years and Type II diabetic for the past eight years. Both his hypertension and diabetes are controlled through medications. He reports moderate alcohol consumption and has a diet rich in trans fats and cholesterol. There is a family history of coronary artery disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58.   Clinical Findings: On examination  Mr. JT was slightly overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 27 kg/m2. His blood pressure was high at 160/90 mmHg. His electrocardiogram (ECG) showed slight depressions in the ST segment. His lipid profile showed elevated levels of total cholesterol of 250 mg/dL and LDL of 160 mg/dL with a lowered HDL of 35 mg/dL. His HbA1c was also high at 8.5%. His chest X-ray was normal and his echocardiogram showed impaired left ventricular function.  Diagnosis: Based on the patient’s clinical history  examination findings  and test results  a diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) was made.  Treatment: Mr. JT was immediately started on antiplatelet therapy (aspirin)  a statin (for cholesterol control)  nitroglycerin (for immediate relief of angina)  beta-blockers (for high blood pressure)  and an ACE inhibitor. Lifestyle modifications were suggested including smoking cessation  increased physical activity  dietary modification  and weight loss.   He was referred for further coronary angiography for possible revascularization procedures  such as angioplasty or bypass surgery.  Outcome: The patient is stable and slated for follow-up examinations. Proper follow-up  medication compliance  and lifestyle modifications will be essential for preventing major adverse cardiovascular events.  Conclusion: Mr. JT demonstrates many factors present in those more likely to suffer from CAD  including old age  male  hypertension  diabetes  high cholesterol  smoking history  family history of CAD and physical inactivity. This case illustrates the importance of early diagnosis and management in patients with risk factor profiles to prevent severe cardiac events.

Title: A Case Report on Coronary Artery Disease Coupled With Hypertension in a 56-Year-Old African American Male   Patient Profile: The patient is a 56-year-old African American male  living in an urban area. He is a smoker  with a history of a 20-pack-year smoking habit  and works as a warehouse manager. His medical history includes controlled hypertension and dyslipidemia with a disadvantageous lipid profile - low HDL cholesterol of 36mg/dl and high LDL cholesterol of 160mg/dl. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father suffering from a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.   Presenting Complaints: The patient sought medical help for chest pain experienced predominantly whilst at work  usually following physical activity  over the past month. The pain was described as dull  squeezing in nature  in the center of his chest. He also reported occasional episodes of shortness of breath  and nausea  primarily during intense work.  Clinical Examination & Investigations: Upon clinical examination  the patient had slightly elevated blood pressure at 140/90. His body mass index (BMI) was 28  falling in the overweight range. Electrocardiogram (ECG) findings were normal at rest but demonstrated ST-segment depression during an exercise stress test indicative of myocardial ischemia. Subsequently  a coronary angiogram was scheduled which demonstrated significant stenosis in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery and right coronary artery (RCA)  confirming the diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Management: Based on the patient's symptoms  risk factors  and diagnostic findings  the healthcare team decided to initiate a course of medical management before considering any invasive approaches such as angioplasty or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). The patient was prescribed aspirin  a beta-blocker  a statin  and a nitrate for angina. He was also urged to modify his lifestyle by incorporating a low-sodium diet  regular moderate exercise  weight reduction  and smoking cessation.  Outcome & Follow-Up: With a two-month follow-up  the patient reported a reduction in the frequency and intensity of chest pain. Both his cholesterol levels and blood pressure indicated improvement. He had managed to partially quit smoking and lose some weight. Further management will be tailored based on his progress and future symptoms.  The patient's racial background  smoking  hypertension  age  and family history put him at a higher risk for coronary artery disease. His case reiterates the significant role of lifestyle modification in managing CAD and  more importantly  priorly controlling risk factors to prevent the onset of the disease.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Profile:  Age: 62 Gender: Male Ethnicity: African-American Living Situation: Lives with wife  retired engineer Location: Urban setting  Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania  USA  Presenting Complaints:  The patient  Mr. J  presented with complaints of intermittent chest pain over the past couple of months. The pain is mostly experienced during physical exertion and usually recedes with rest. Mr. J also reported recent episodes of breathlessness and fatigue.
