Past Medical History:  Mr. J has been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and has been managing it with medication for the past 7 years. Over the last few years  he has been dealing with mild hypertension and was intermittently compliant with prescribed antihypertensive medications.  Family History:  There is a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father and two uncles dying due to myocardial infarctions. His father passed away at the age of 64 and his uncles in their early 60s.  Assessment & Diagnosis:  On examination  Mr. J's vital signs were generally stable. His blood pressure was slightly increased  confirming the patient's history and indicating uncontrolled hypertension.   Blood tests revealed increased cholesterol levels with high LDL (low-density lipoprotein) cholesterol and low HDL (high-density lipoprotein) cholesterol. His HbA1c level was 7.5%  suggesting that his diabetes has been sub-optimally controlled.   Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of past silent myocardial ischemia. An exercise stress test was positive for inducible ischemia. Coronary angiography was then conducted  which confirmed the presence of significant stenosis in two coronary arteries.   Based on the assessment  medical history  and investigation outcomes  Mr. J was diagnosed with atherosclerotic coronary artery disease (CAD).  Discussion:  In the case of Mr. J  the combination of advanced age  male gender  African-American ethnicity  family history of premature heart disease  personal history of type 2 diabetes  uncontrolled hypertension  and high LDL cholesterol significantly contributed to his risk for CAD.  This case emphasizes the importance of consistent compliance with prescribed medications  especially in patients with high-risk comorbidities like diabetes and hypertension. It also emphasizes the necessity of regular screening and optimal control of risk factors in patients with a family history of premature CAD.  Treatment and Follow up:  Mr. J received comprehensive treatment including coronary artery revascularization  antihypertensive medications  and statin therapy for controlling his cholesterol levels. Regular review and good control of his diabetes have been emphasized  and he was referred to a dietitian to help manage his diabetes and reduce LDL cholesterol levels naturally. He was also advised to engage in mild to moderate aerobic exercise after recovery from the intervention  given the physical condition and personal preference. Regular follow-ups have been advised for managing his condition and minimizing further cardiac risks.   Informed consent for the case report was taken from the patient. This case has been reported with no identifiers for maintaining patient confidentiality.   In conclusion  this case report clearly highlights how multiple risk factors can contribute to CAD and that regular screening and stringent control of these factors is key for preventing severe cardiac events like myocardial infarction.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a 65-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Patient Information:  Mr. X is a Caucasian male aged 65 years  residing in a suburban location in Midwest  United States. He is retired and has been living alone since his wife passed away three years ago.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. X presented to the emergency department reporting a persistent severe chest pain radiating to his left shoulder and neck that starting approximately 2 hours earlier during his evening walk.  History of Present Illness:  This episode of chest pain was described as a heavy  squeezing pain lasting about 10 minutes  subsiding with rest  but it reemerged with any exertion  making them more frequent and severe over the time.  Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a known case of hypertension for the past 15 years  marginally elevated cholesterol levels for ten years  and a 40-pack year history of smoking  though he quit 5 years ago. He also has a family history of early-onset coronary artery disease (CAD)  as his father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. He has been moderately compliant in taking his prescribed hypertensive and lipid-lowering medications.   Physical Examination:  On admission  Mr. X was conscious  oriented but appeared to be in distress. He had a blood pressure reading of 160/95 mm Hg  a pulse rate of 92 beats per min  and moderately labored breathing. Cardiac auscultation revealed no abnormal heart sounds or murmurs  but he did have crepitations at the chest's lower lung fields.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An electrocardiogram was done  which showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Blood tests showed elevated levels of cardiac enzymes - Troponin I and CK-MB  confirming the diagnosis of acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction  a type of CAD.   Treatment:  Mr. X was promptly treated with aspirin  nitroglycerin  and a high-dose statin. After that  he was taken to the cath lab for emergency coronary angioplasty.  Prognosis:  Mr. X successfully underwent angioplasty for left anterior descending artery stenosis. He is now being closely monitored in the coronary care unit and has been referred for rehabilitation and counseling regarding his lifestyle modification  medication adherence  and chronic disease management.  Conclusion:  This case reflects the significance of addressing modifiable risk factors such as hypertension  smoking  and dyslipidemia in preventing the onset and progression of CAD  especially in individuals with a family history of premature CAD.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a Hispanic Female Patient: A Case Report  Patient Presentation A 63-year-old Hispanic female attended a routine check-up at a primary care clinic  presenting with unusual fatigue during routine activities and sporadic chest discomfort.  Patient Information The patient is a housewife  born and raised in Mexico  who migrated to the US 25 years ago. She is currently living in a suburban locality in California with her husband  a retired construction worker  and three adult children. She's a non-smoker and reports occasional alcohol consumption.   Clinical Findings On examination  the patient had a BMI of 30 kg/m2  blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  and heart rate of 76 beats per minute. Initial EKG showed minor ST-segment depressions in leads II  III  AvF  and V6. Laboratory findings revealed an elevated LDL cholesterol (180 mg/dL) and normal blood glucose levels and kidney function.   History The patient's medical history indicates incidents of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Her father had passed away due to a myocardial infarction at 67 years old. She has been on antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 5mg) and metformin for diabetes management. The patient reported adherence to pharmacotherapy but had a sedentary lifestyle with infrequent exercise and a diet high in carbohydrates and fats.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment The initial diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) was suspected based on symptoms  risk factor profile  examination findings  and history of premorbid conditions. To accurately assess cardiac function and confirm the diagnosis  she was referred to a cardiologist. Coronary angiography revealed significant stenosis in the left anterior descending artery and right coronary artery  confirming the diagnosis.  Therapeutic Intervention Considering the patient's clinical history and current condition  the specialist advised a dual approach  comprising lifestyle modifications and pharmacotherapy. She was prescribed statins (Atorvastatin 20mg)  antiplatelet (Aspirin 81mg) and ACE inhibitor (Lisinopril 10mg) for hypertension  adding to her existing medication profile. Lifestyle interventions include dietary modifications  adopting a structured exercise program  focusing on weight loss and good glycemic control.   Follow up and Outcomes The patient was followed up after 2 months. She reported improvements in her symptoms. Her blood pressure was down to 136/84 mmHg and an overall reduction in LDL cholesterol levels. Despite this positive note  she still must continue with her treatment to manage the residual risk factors and ensure good cardiovascular health.  Conclusion This case emphasizes the high prevalence rate of CAD within the Hispanic/Latino population  especially among women  primarily due to commonly observed risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and familial history. The report underscores the necessity of a multifactorial approach to CAD management that integrates pharmacological intervention with lifestyle modifications  patient education  and early intervention to prevent disease progression.   Patient Perspective Regular exercises and dietary changes have helped me manage my symptoms of CAD. Persistent routine follow-ups ensured that I can monitor my health conditions better. As a patient  the importance of adhering to prescribed medication and lifestyle changes is comprehended.

Case Report: A Sixty-Year-Old Hispanic Female with Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information:  The patient is a 60-year-old Hispanic female with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  who was referred to the Cardiology Department due to worsening anginal symptoms.  Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago and is managed with Metformin. Hypertension and hyperlipidemia were diagnosed 5 years ago  currently managed with Lisinopril (ACE inhibitor) and Atorvastatin (Statin drug)  respectively. She is a non-smoker and denies any form of substance abuse. She adheres to a dietary plan consisting of low-sodium and low-cholesterol foods.  Family History:  The patient’s mother died at the age of 65 due to myocardial infarction  and her father  aged 82  has a history of diabetes and stroke. Her older brother  aged 67  is currently being treated for angina.  Presenting Issue:  The patient reported experiencing moderate to severe chest pain radiating to her left arm over the past three months. The frequency and severity of the angina had increased over the past couple of weeks. Besides  she reported experiencing dyspnea on exertion. However  she denied experiencing associated symptoms such as syncope  palpitations  or dizziness.  Physical Examination:  Physical examination was largely unremarkable. The patient’s blood pressure was adequately controlled at 128/78 mmHg  heart rate- 82 beats/min  respiratory rate - 18 breaths/min  and body mass index of 28. The cardiovascular examination revealed a normal S1 and S2 without any additional heart sounds or murmurs. The chest was clear on auscultation and there was no peripheral edema.  Investigation and Diagnosis:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed evidence of T-wave inversion in leads V1-V4  consistent with ischemic changes. Subsequently  coronary angiography was recommended  revealing significant stenosis (~70%) in the left anterior descending artery. A diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) was therefore confirmed.  Management and Follow-Up:  Considering her symptoms and results  percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug eluting stenting was performed successfully. She was discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin and Clopidogrel)  along with continued Atorvastatin and Lisinopril. She was referred also for ongoing management of the risk factors for CAD  including dietary modification  exercise  weight reduction  and better glycemic control of her diabetes.  Discussion:  This case emphasizes the particular importance in managing risk factors  notably hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes in populations with a high incidence of CAD  such as the Hispanic community. The American Heart Association recommends that adults aged 20 and older should have their cholesterol and other traditional risk factors checked every 4 to 6 years.  The patient is scheduled for a follow-up in three months' time. She has been advised to monitor her symptoms closely  and she was educated on the signs and symptoms of potential complications  and when to seek immediate medical attention. A referral was also made to the Diabetes Education Center for the patient to better manage her diabetes in order to help prevent further development of CAD.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in an Elderly Asian Male: A Case Report   Demographic Information: Patient X is a 65-year-old Asian male residing in urban New York. He has a past employment history as an office worker  leading a sedentary lifestyle. Patient X's social history reveals he is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. He follows a diet leaning towards high saturated fat content.  Medical History Over the last 10 years  he has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which he has managed with oral medication. His family history notes the early demise of his father due to myocardial infarction at the age of 60. Patient X does not have any known allergies.  Presenting Complaint The patient was admitted to the emergency department reporting severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm lasting for about an hour. The pain was associated with sweating and shortness of breath.  Clinical Assessment On examination  he appeared pale and distressed. His initial blood pressure was 160/100 mmHg  pulse 105 bpm  and oxygen saturation 90% on room air. His Body Mass Index (BMI) was 28  suggestive of overweight. Electrocardiogram (EKG) findings indicated ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  suggesting inferior wall ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI). Later  elevated troponin levels confirmed this diagnosis.  Management and Follow-up He received immediate medical attention under the hospital's STEMI protocol  including nitroglycerin  aspirin  and clopidogrel. He subsequently underwent successful primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the right coronary artery  which was 100% occluded. Post-PCI  the patient was initiated on beta-blockers  statins  and ACE inhibitors. He was advised to follow a low-fat diet and referred for cardiac rehabilitation. The patient was regularly reviewed in the outpatient department and displayed marked improvement in symptoms and lifestyle modifications.  Discussion This case illustrates the importance of early detection and intervention in patients presenting with STEMI  particularly in individuals with multiple risk factors such as old age  Asian ethnicity  male sex  sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  diabetes  and a family history of premature coronary artery disease (CAD).  In conclusion  this case emphasizes that a multidisciplinary approach  incorporating immediate medical intervention  lifestyle modification  and regular follow-up  is pivotal in managing patients with CAD to prevent adverse outcomes.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in an Elderly African-American Female Patient with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension   Patient Information: The patient is a 75-year-old African-American female  a resident of Memphis  Tennessee  who was referred to the cardiac department due to persistent chest pain. She is a retired librarian  primarily guided by English with a limited comprehension of other languages. She has been living alone since her husband's death five years ago.  Chief Complaint: Her primary complaint was severe and intermittent chest pain that has been progressive over the past month. The pain usually starts during activity or stress and stops at rest or after taking sublingual nitroglycerine.  History of Present Illness: A thorough examination revealed that the patient has a history of escalating angina over the past month  characterized as exertional chest discomfort and shortness of breath. Tolerance to physical exertion has significantly deteriorated from a block walk to a few yards over the past two weeks.  Medical History: She has a ten-year history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  well-monitored with a combination of oral hypoglycemic agents and antihypertensives. She was diagnosed with Hyperlipidemia three years ago and was started on statin therapy. The patient is also moderately obese with a BMI of 33. She denies tobacco or alcohol use  but confesses to a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity and a diet rich in processed foods.  Social History: She lives alone  but her daughter  who lives nearby  ensures to pay a regular visit and oversee her daily needs. She reports financial stability and accesses medical care without substantial hardship.  Clinical Findings: Her blood pressure was 145/87 mmHg; heart rate was 81 beats per minute; respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 98% in room air at rest. A physical exam revealed decreased breath sounds in both lungs  elevated jugular venous pressure  and a displaced left ventricular impulse.  Diagnostic Assessment: Lab tests revealed elevated levels of HbA1c (8.2%) and LDL cholesterol (160 mg/dl)  indicating suboptimal control of diabetes and hyperlipidemia. The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion. Echocardiogram indicated left ventricular hypertrophy and impaired left ventricular function. Coronary angiography was performed  revealing two-vessel disease with significant stenosis of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and left circumflex artery (LCX).  Therapeutic Intervention: Based on the angiographic findings  the patient was advised for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). However  due to her high surgical risk linked to age  diabetes  and left ventricular dysfunction  the family chose medical treatment.  Conclusion: This case report displays the complexities faced in managing coronary artery disease in elderly patients with co-morbidities. The case also highlights the importance of regular follow-ups  effective communication  and the application of patient-centric medicine in the management of intricate cases.

Case Report – Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information:  A 65-year-old African American male presented to the clinic with complaints of elevated blood pressure  consistent fatigue and frequent tightness in the chest. The patient is a retired construction manager  married with two adult sons. He lives in a suburban area and smokes approximately half a pack of cigarettes daily. He occasionally consumes alcohol  mainly beer during the weekends. He has a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32.5 kg/m2  height of 5ft 7in  and weighing 228 pounds (103kg). He is currently not under any medication but has used aspirin occasionally for headaches. No known allergies to drugs or foods.  Past Medical History:  According to his past medical record  the patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago  which was managed through dietary changes and regular exercise. He did not require medication. The patient also has a long history of hypertension diagnosed at the age of 45 and familial hypercholesterolemia identified at the age of 50. He has acknowledged non-adherence to dietary recommendations and physical activity  but no substantial evidence of the advancement of disease has been recorded. No past surgeries  no history of cancer  asthma  or other chronic diseases were documented in his medical history. His father had passed away in his early 50s from a myocardial infarction.  Clinical Findings:  Vital signs at presentation were blood pressure 158/92 mm Hg  pulse rate 88 bpm  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and temperature 98.6 F. Upon physical examination  minimal crepitations were noted in lower lung fields and the patient exhibited minor difficulty in breathing after short walks.   Diagnostic Assessment:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) displayed ST-segment depression and T-wave inversions suggestive of probable cardiovascular disease. Lipid profile showed elevated total cholesterol levels (240 mg/dL)  increased LDL ('bad' cholesterol - 160 mg/dL) and reduced HDL levels ('good' cholesterol - 34 mg/dL). Blood glucose levels were also elevated (145 mg/dL).   Diagnosis:  Based on the findings  the patient was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient has been advised to quit smoking  exercising regularly and to follow a strict  heart-healthy diet to manage his type 2 diabetes  high cholesterol  and hypertension. Medications prescribed include aspirin 81 mg/day (for platelet inhibition)  lisinopril 10 mg/day (for hypertension and protective effect in diabetes)  atorvastatin 40 mg/day (for cholesterol)  and metformin 500 mg twice per day (for diabetes management).  Status:  The patient is currently undergoing prescribed therapy. He has been instructed to return for a follow-up appointment in 4 weeks where further assessments will be performed to monitor progress and adjust treatment as required.

Title: Case Report on a 63-year-old African-American Male with Coronary Artery Disease   Patient Information: The patient is a 63-year-old African-American male who is a retired construction worker. He is married with three adult children and lives in an urban setting. The patient is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. He is diagnosed with Type II diabetes and has been under medication for the past 10 years. He also has hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he has been taking blood pressure and lipid-lowering drugs. His BMI was recorded at 29  indicating that he is overweight. He has no known allergies.  Clinical Findings: The patient visited the clinic with complaints of intermittent chest pain  especially on exertion  and shortness of breath. His blood pressure was measured to be 150/90 mm Hg. He also reported fatigue and occasional episodes of dizziness.  Diagnostic Assessment: Based on the symptoms and preliminary physical examination  suspected diagnosis was coronary artery disease (CAD). The subsequent electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed an abnormal heart rhythm. An exercise stress test was carried out  which the patient could not complete due to fatigue  further indicating heart disease. Coronary angiogram revealed significant blockages in two major coronary arteries  confirming CAD.  Therapeutic Interventions: The patient was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)  specifically angioplasty with stent placement  to help ensure better blood flow through the narrowed arteries. He was prescribed aspirin and a beta-blocker to manage his hypertension  along with additional medication to control his blood sugar and lipid levels.  Follow-ups and Outcomes: At one-month follow-up  the patient reported relief from chest pain and improved physical stamina  indicating a positive response to the intervention and medication adjustment.   Patient perspective: The patient expressed relief and satisfaction with his treatment plan and results so far. He also showed determination to make lifestyle changes including diet modification and regular physical exercise as recommended.  Informed consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for reporting this case.  Learning points: This case reports exemplifies the importance of comprehensive evaluation and individualized treatment of elderly African-American male patients with CAD  considering risk factors such as ethnicity  age and presence of metabolic diseases like diabetes and hypertension. Also  it underlines the need for encouraging lifestyle modifications along with medical interventions to manage CAD effectively.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  I. Demographic Information  The subject of this case report is a 72-year-old male of Caucasian descent  who is a retired professional. He is married with three children and lives in a suburban area. He has a history of smoking but quit about a decade ago. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has a diet rich in cholesterol and fats. He also has a history of high alcohol consumption. His family medical history is significant  with his father having died from a heart attack in his late 60s and his older brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease in his early 60s.  II. Presenting Concerns  The patient presented to the cardiovascular department complaining of consistent severe chest pain  extending to his left arm and sometimes to his back and jaw  and accompanied by shortness of breath and fatigue. He reported that these symptoms initially only appeared during physical activity  but they had recently started to manifest even while he was at rest. The patient also indicated experienced lightheadedness and occasional bouts of dizziness.  The chest pain  clinically termed angina  was described as pressure or squeezing sensation in his chest. These signs are typically suggestive of coronary artery disease (CAD). His symptoms particularly in view of his past medical and family history signalled a requirement for urgent investigation.  III. Clinical Findings  Upon assessment  his vitals showed a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg  heart rate of 90 beats per minute  BMI of 30.6 kg/m² (classified as obese)  and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Electrocardiogram (ECG) signs evidenced ST-segment depression suggestive of myocardial ischemia. His laboratory results depicted raised troponin levels and a lipid profile outside a healthy range (LDL-cholesterol- 180 mg/dL  triglycerides- 220 mg/dL).  IV. Diagnosis  Given the patient's age  male gender  high blood pressure  obesity  positive history of smoking and alcohol consumption  elevated cholesterol levels with a diet high in fats  sedentary lifestyle  consistent symptoms of severe chest pain  and familial predisposition  his diagnosis was delineated towards Coronary Artery Disease.  V. Treatment Plan  The patient was immediately initiated on medical management involving a combination of drugs such as aspirin  beta-blockers  nitroglycerin  and statins to slow the progression of CAD and prevent any imminent cardiac events. Subsequently  a coronary angiogram was performed that showed significant blockages in his coronary arteries for which he underwent Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) and guideline-directed medical therapy was reinforced. He was also advised to incorporate lifestyle changes; cutting back on alcohol  adopting a healthier diet  weight reduction  and regular moderate-intensity exercise.  VI. Follow-Up Plan  The patient was scheduled for regular follow-ups every 3 months initially  alongside a comprehensive cardiac rehabilitation program. Regular monitoring of serum lipid levels  cardiac function  blood pressure  BMI  and adherence to medications and lifestyle modifications were stressed upon in follow-up visits to reduce the risk of further cardiac events and to optimize the management of the disease.   No conflict of interest to declare. All personal patient details have been de-identified for privacy reasons.

Title: Severe Coronary Artery Disease in a 58-year-old Male with Past Medical History of Diabetes and Hypertension  Case Report:  Patient Information:   The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male who presented with recurrent episodes of angina pectoris. He resides in Boston  Massachusetts  and is currently retired after spending most of his life working in the transportation industry. He is a former smoker  averaging 1 pack/day over a period of 30 years  but quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol socially and has no known drug allergies.   Chief Complaint:  The patient came with a major complaint of recurring chest discomfort  which was exacerbated upon physical exertion and relieved by rest. He also reported episodes of shortness of breath upon exertion  chronic fatigue  and lower extremity edema.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a confirmed history of Type II diabetes mellitus for the last 8 years  which is controlled with Metformin. He also has a 10-year history of essential hypertension managed with Lisinopril. There is no known history of previous myocardial infarction  stroke  or other cardiovascular diseases. There is no relevant family history of coronary artery disease  but his father had diabetes  and his mother died of stroke at the age of 72.  Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  he was found to be overweight with a BMI of 30 kg/m2. His blood pressure was elevated at 145/90 mmHg  heart rate was regular at 92 bpm  and his respiratory rate was slightly elevated at 18 breaths per minute.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An ECG revealed ST-segment depression suggestive of myocardial ischemia. The lab tests showed elevated levels of total cholesterol (270 mg/dL) and LDL cholesterol (180 mg/dl). HbA1c was at 7.2% signaling uncontrolled diabetes. An exercise stress test was positive for ischemia  after which he was advised to undergo coronary angiography. The angiography revealed multiple significant lesions in the left anterior descending artery and right coronary artery with over 70% stenosis.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the multifocal severe disease and his clinical condition  the patient was referred for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. He was also prescribed a statin (Atorvastatin)  an antithrombotic drug (Aspirin)  and his hypertension medication was intensified.  Follow-up:  The patient's post-operative period was uneventful  and he was discharged on the fifth day with appropriate medications and advice on the continuation of cardiac rehabilitation  dietary modifications  and lifestyle changes. He was asked for a follow-up after 2 weeks  then 3  6  and 12 months post-surgery.  In 6-month follow-up  the patient reported significant improvement in symptoms  and cardiac rehabilitation was found to be satisfactory.  In summary  this is a case involving a 58-year-old male patient with significant coronary artery disease  with relevant past medical history of diabetes and hypertension  which suggests the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate multidisciplinary management in such cases.

Title: Fatal Progression of Coronary Artery Disease in a 62-Year-Old Caucasian Male with Prediabetes and Smoking History  Patient Profile: Mr. A is a 62-year-old Caucasian male living in suburban Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania where he retired as an accountant. His family consists of his wife and two adult children; both are self-sufficient.  Medical History: Mr. A has been diagnosed with prediabetes two years ago  for which he has been prescribed Metformin. He leads a somewhat sedentary lifestyle  with limited physical activity. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history  which he quit five years ago. His family history is significant with his father dying from a heart attack at the age of 55. He drinks socially  consuming an average of 5–7 drinks per week. He has no known drug allergies. Regular screenings and exams have not revealed any sign of cancer  stroke  or neurological disorders.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. A presented at a local hospital with severe chest pain radiating to his left arm. He rated the pain as 8 on a scale of 10. He noticed an incident of crushing chest pain while mowing his lawn  accompanied by shortness of breath  diaphoresis and nausea.  Examination: On examination  Mr. A appeared in discomfort. His pulse was 90/min  blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  respiratory rate was 20 breaths/min  and all these vitals were within normal ranges. His body mass index was calculated to be 29.8 kg/m2  indicating he falls within the 'overweight' category.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation indicating an acute myocardial infarction. The patient's lipid profile showed elevated low-density lipoprotein cholesterol at 198 mg/dL and reduced high-density lipoprotein cholesterol at 28 mg/dL  suggesting dyslipidemia. The test also revealed increased fasting serum glucose (140 mg/dL) and Hemoglobin A1c (6.5%); confirming the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.   A coronary angiography was performed which revealed substantial stenosis in the left anterior descending artery. Echo cardiography revealed the left ventricular ejection fraction of 48%. Collectively  the clinical and diagnostic findings confirmed the diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Course and Treatment: Mr. A was immediately treated with aspirin and nitroglycerin followed by a successful emergency percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the stenosed artery. He was encouraged to adopt a healthier lifestyle  increase physical activity  and a diet low in saturated fats  trans fats  cholesterol  salt  and added sugars was recommended. He started on pharmacotherapy including dual antiplatelet therapy  a statin for long-term lipid management  a beta-blocker  ACE inhibitor  and an anti-diabetic medication. His prognosis is guarded due to his age  delayed presentation  and established risk factors.  Discussion: This case underlines the significance of timely recognition and management of CAD. As Mr. A had several risk factors for CAD: male  age  prediabetes  smoking history  sedentary lifestyle  family history of CAD  and dyslipidemia. These factors should be thoroughly and regularly assessed in such high-risk patients for better outcomes. In conclusion  lifestyle modification along with therapy is critical and CAD patients like Mr. A should be educated about the importance of regular follow-up and monitoring.  (Case report is fictional and does not represent any specific individual's health history or condition).

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a Sedentary  Diabetic  Elderly Female   Patient Introduction:   The patient is a 68-year-old female of Filipino descent residing in a metropolitan area. She weighed approximately 67 kg and measured 5'2'' in height (BMI 27.6). She was a former school teacher who had retired five years ago. She is a widow and lives alone. She has two children  both are residing in another city.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a significant past medical history due to type II diabetes and hypertension  diagnosed 12 and 15 years ago  respectively. She managed her diabetes with metformin and her blood pressure with amlodipine  both prescribed by her primary health care provider. She was not regularly active and had a moderately unhealthy diet  mainly high in refined carbohydrates. She had no known drug allergies. Her family history revealed her father died of a heart attack  and her mother had type II diabetes.   Presenting Complaint:  She presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of severe chest pain  breathlessness  and dizziness  which had started while she was gardening. The chest pain was precipitated by exertion and relieved by rest.  Clinical Findings:   Upon examination  the patient appeared diaphoretic and complained of nausea. Her blood pressure was 150/95 mmHg  pulse rate was high at 92 beats per minute  and her respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute. Her lungs were clear on auscultation  and heart sounds were normal.   Diagnostic Assessment:  An Electrocardiogram (ECG) was immediately performed  which showed ST segment elevation in inferior leads suggestive of myocardial infarction. Serum troponin level was also elevated. Fasting blood sugar levels were slightly elevated. For further evaluation  coronarography was performed that showed a significant stenosing lesion on the right coronary artery. She was diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD).  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately taken to the Cath lab where a successful primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was performed on the right coronary artery. She was started on aspirin  beta-blockers  statins  and Angiotensin-II receptor blockers (ARBs). Anti-diabetic treatment was intensified  and she was advised to improve her lifestyle  particularly her diet  and include daily mild exercise in her routine.   Follow up and Outcomes:  She was followed up after one month and reported a marked improvement in her symptoms. Her diabetic control improved  and her blood pressure dropped to normal ranges.  Learning Points/Discussion:  This case highlights the relationship between sedentary lifestyle  diabetes  and the development of CAD in the elderly. Diabetes is a significant risk factor for CAD. Enhancement of physical activity and diet modification are crucial preventative strategies for CAD  especially in individuals with diabetes and hypertension. Early diagnosis and intervention can lead to a favorable outcome as seen in this case.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a 68-Year-Old African-American Male with a History of Hypertension and Cigarette Smoking  Case Details: The patient is a 68-year-old African-American male who presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of angina characterized by central  crushing pain radiating to the left arm and neck that has been increasingly intensifying over the past six months. The pain was particularly severe for the last five days  with episodes becoming more frequent and now occurring even at rest  rendering him incapable of exerting himself physically.  The patient's past medical history includes hypertension which was diagnosed at the age of 45 and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus diagnosed at 55. He reports antihypertensive medication compliance but admits to irregular glycemic control and non-adherence to his diabetes medications. His body mass index (BMI) on examination was 30 suggesting obesity. Furthermore  he has been a smoker for the past three decades with a 20 pack-year history.  His family history is significant  with his father having experienced a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 62. His mother has hypertension and his younger brother is diabetic.  On examination  a blood pressure of 160/90mmHg and a heart rate of 80 beats per minute were noted. He appeared uncomfortable with visible diaphoresis. Chest examination revealed early signs of cardiac failure  with mild chest wall tenderness and distant heart sounds. An EKG showed ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion indicative of possible ischemia.  Blood investigations revealed elevated cholesterol levels with LDL at 160mg/dl and HDL at 30mg/dl. Fasting glucose levels were also elevated at 200mg/dl indicating poor glycemic control. A high-sensitivity cardiac troponin I assay indicated an elevated level of 0.08ng/ml.  The patient was subsequently referred for angiography which demonstrated triple vessel disease - significant stenoses in the left anterior descending artery  right coronary artery  and circumflex artery.   Management: Under the diagnosis of coronary artery disease  the patient was started on aspirin  beta-blockers  statins  and ACE inhibitors. He was counselled about lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation  dietary changes  regular exercise  and strict adherence to his diabetic medication. Cardiac rehabilitation was suggested. Given the severity of his coronary artery disease  the case was discussed with a cardiothoracic surgeon and the patient was referred for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).  Summary: This case illustrates the significant risk factors for coronary artery disease including advanced age  African-American ethnicity  male gender  hypertension  diabetes  smoking  obesity  and family history. It emphasizes the importance of medication adherence  lifestyle modifications  and the possible need for surgical intervention in managing such patients.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Demographics: Patient: Mr. John Smith Age: 67 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Residential Location: New York  USA  History: Mr. John Smith presented to the clinic on July 12  2022  reporting chest discomfort experienced over the past several weeks  primarily during physical exertion. He described the discomfort as pressure and a squeezing sensation in the chest  often radiating to the left arm and jaw. Additionally  he reported episodes of shortness of breath following mild physical activity and occasional feelings of indigestion. He has a documented history of Hypertension and Type-2 Diabetes  for which he takes Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively.  Mr. Smith smoked approximately a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 10 years ago upon diagnosis of Type-2 Diabetes. He reports a diet relatively high in cholesterol and saturated fats and a largely sedentary lifestyle.  Family history includes his father who had suffered a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and a paternal uncle diagnosed with angina. His mother  aged 94  is living and has a history of stroke. Mr. Smith has two siblings - his elder brother  aged 71  has Hypertension  and his younger sister  aged 64  has no reported cardiovascular disease.  Clinical Assessment: Mr. Smith’s body mass index (BMI) is 29  suggesting overweight nearing obesity. His blood pressure on examination was 145/90 mmHg  which is relatively high. The cardiological examination revealed a normal rhythm but a slight murmur was also noted. An electrocardiogram showed minor ST-segment depressions. Exercise stress test induced chest pain and reflected ST-segment depressions  suggesting possible ischemia. Further analysis was advised.  A coronagraphy was performed  revealing severe stenosis in the left anterior descending artery and moderate stenosis in the right coronary artery. The left ventricular ejection fraction was calculated to be around 45%  indicating impaired function.  Case Diagnosis: Based on the medical history  symptoms  and clinical and diagnostic evaluations  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Conclusion: Given the patient's risk factors of age  gender  family history of CAD  history of smoking  sedentary lifestyle  suboptimal diet  and medical history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes  the diagnosis was made. Mr. Smith was counseled on the importance of lifestyle alterations  told to continue his anti-hypertension and diabetes medications  and was started on low-dose aspirin therapy  Statin for cholesterol control  and sublingual nitroglycerin for chest pain relief. Regular follow-up visits were scheduled for closer monitoring of his cardiovascular health.

Case Report: Male Patient with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Demographics: The patient is a 67-year-old African American male  retired  married  living in San Diego  CA. He is a non-smoker with a history of high alcohol intake  which ceased five years ago. The patient reported a regular  fairly sedentary lifestyle  with minimal physical exercise. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 29 which falls in the overweight range.  Medical History:  Aside from his current complaints  the patient reports a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past ten years  which he manages with oral medications. His family history reveals that his father also had coronary artery disease.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presented with a history of recurrent chest pain  which is intense and pressure-like and typically lasts for 30-45 minutes. He also suffers from shortness of breath during physical exertion and experiences occasional dizziness and fatigue.  Clinical Findings & Investigations: The patient's physical examination showed slightly elevated blood pressure (145/90 mmHg). His EKG indicated the potential of myocardial ischemia. Subsequently  he was advised to undergo a stress test which confirmed the presence of ischemia  and a coronary angiogram was conducted later. The angiogram showed occlusion in the left anterior descending artery.  Diagnosis: Based on his symptoms  physical examination  EKG  stress test  and angiogram results  the patient was diagnosed with coronary artery disease.  Treatment and Follow-up: The patient was initially treated with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to open up the blocked coronary artery and a drug-eluting stent was placed.  His complete CAD treatment plan also includes long-term medications like aspirin  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  statins  and nitroglycerin for episodes of chest pain. He was encouraged to make lifestyle modifications  including healthier dietary habits and participation in regular physical activity. Regular follow-ups are planned  with the first six weeks from the procedure to review his physical condition  medications  ongoing symptoms and lifestyle management.  The patient was educated about the seriousness of the disease and the importance of compliance with medications and lifestyle modifications. His family was involved in understanding the scenario to provide necessary support at home.  This case report highlights the common demographic risk factors associated with CAD  particularly ethnicity  age  male gender  obesity  hypertensive  diabetic history and lack of physical activity.    Reference:  Multiple sources  including Roth GA  Mensah GA  Johnson CO  et al.  Global Burden of Cardiovascular Diseases and Risk Factors  1990–2019. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2020;76(25):2982-3021.

Patient Information  A 65-year-old Asian male patient  known as Mr. X  visited the hospital with complaints of frequent angina along with shortness of breath  especially during physical exertion. He is a retired banker and resides in New Jersey with his wife in a middle-class community.  Mr. X has a history of Type-II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years  and it has been controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. He also has hypertension for ten years and is on medication (Ace Inhibitors). He has been smoking one pack of cigarettes a day for about 25 years but quit 5 years ago. He consumes alcohol moderately. There is no known genetic history of any heart diseases in the family.  Clinical Findings and Diagnosis  His Body Mass Index (BMI) was 30  pointing towards obesity  and his blood pressure was recorded as 145/95 mmHg. His ECG presented signs of ST-segment depression. Laboratory tests showed that his glycated hemoglobin (Hb1Ac) was 7.8% and serum cholesterol levels were high (total cholesterol 245mg/dl). His Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) level was 160mg/dl and High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL) was 35mg/dl.  Based on the clinical findings  past medical history  and symptoms  he was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Treatment  Initially  he was advised lifestyle modifications  which included a low cholesterol  low salt diet  moderate aerobic exercise  and controlling his diabetes and hypertension. For CAD  he was prescribed Aspirin  Statins  and Beta-blockers. He underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for blockages in two of his coronary arteries. His hypertension was managed with ACE inhibitors and diuretics  and his diabetes was managed by oral hypoglycemic agents.  Follow-up and Outcome  He was advised to visit every two months to manage his CAD and associated conditions. He was put under the supervision of a dietician and a physiotherapist. With medications and necessary interventions  his chest pain  shortness of breath symptoms were managed effectively.  In the subsequent follow-ups  the patient responded reasonably well to the treatment and lifestyle modifications. His Body Mass Index (BMI) decreased to 26  and his Hb1Ac level reduced to 6.8%. His Blood pressure and cholesterol levels were found normal in the subsequent visits.   Learning Points  This case emphasizes the significance of controlling risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  obesity  and smoking  especially in a multidisciplinary approach  for managing CAD. The patient's quick decision to seek medical help and willingness to adapt to lifestyle changes contributed significantly to the positive outcome in this case.

Case Report: Coronerary Artery Disease  Patient Identification - Name: John Doe (alias) - Age: 66 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired engineer - Race: Caucasian  - Residence: Oregon  USA  Presenting Complaints - The patient complained of experiencing chest pain on exertion for approximately six months prior to this appointment.  Past Medical History - The patient is known to have Type 2 diabetes mellitus which has been under control with Metformin for the past ten years.  - He also has a history of hypertension for which he is taking Lisinopril.   Family History - His father died of a heart attack at the age of 70 and his mother has hypertension.  Social History - He is a former smoker  quitting 15 years ago  and has a history of moderate alcohol intake.    Clinical Findings  - Upon physical examination  the patient appeared anxious.  - His vital signs were Blood Pressure - 140/90 mmHg  Pulse - 90 bpm  regular  temperature - 37.2℃  and respiratory rate - 16 breaths per minute.  - Cardiac examination showed normal S1 and S2 sounds with no murmurs.  - There were no signs of heart failure like peripheral edema or raised JVP.  Investigations - An electrocardiogram showed some ST segment depressions suggestive of possible ischemia.  - Blood investigations including lipid profile  kidney function test  and blood sugar tests were carried out. - Treadmill stress test was moderately positive. - A coronary angiography demonstrated significant blockages in two of the patient's coronary arteries.  Diagnosis - Based on the clinical findings  patient's history  and investigation results  the patient was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Treatment - The patient was immediately started on dual antiplatelet therapy (Asprin and Clopidogrel)  a statin (Atorvastatin)  and a beta blocker (Metoprolol).   Conclusion The patient was referred for coronary artery bypass graft surgery considering the significant blockages in his coronary arteries. He was also advised to make lifestyle changes including diet modification and regular exercise after recovery from the procedure. The prognosis after treatment would need to be evaluated regularly.   Follow-ups - The patient was advised regular follow-up after surgery to assess the benefit of treatment  evaluate the necessity for adjustments in his medication regime  and ensure the proper management of his comorbid conditions. This case underscores the importance of regular health check-ups in individuals with risk factors for cardiovascular diseases.

Case Report - ""Coronary Artery Disease in a 69-year-old African-American Male""  Introduction:  Mr. X is a 69-year-old African-American male from the urban area of Detroit who has presented to our clinic with a medical history of hypertension  obesity  and Type-2 diabetes mellitus. He is a retired automobile factory worker  with a 30-year history of smoking (1 pack/day). Mr. X is widowed  lives with his son  and has a monthly retirement income. This case highlights the prominence of coronary artery disease among older African-American males with a history of hypertension  obesity  and diabetes.  History:  His symptoms began approximately 1 month ago with occasional chest tightness  and an increased shortness of breath while climbing stairs. The chest discomfort progressed over weeks to include episodes of angina at rest.   He has a significant past medical history  with the diagnosis of hypertension and diabetes 15 years ago  currently being managed by Enalapril (10mg/day) and Metformin (1g twice a day)  respectively. Further  his body mass index remains >30 over the past 10 years  despite different weight reduction programs.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  his vital signs were stable but showed an elevated blood pressure of 155/95mmHg. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia with no heart murmur. There were no notable sounds on lung auscultation. Lower limb examination showed no signs of peripheral edema.   Investigations:  An ECG revealed the presence of T wave inversions in leads II  III  aVF  and V1-V4. Blood investigations showed a slightly elevated cholesterol level of 210 mg/dL  triglycerides of 180 mg/dL  LDL- 150 mg/dL and glucose of 170mg/dl.  Given the symptoms and abnormal ECG  he was immediately referred for an angiogram.  The coronary angiogram showed multi-segment disease with a 70% stenosis in his left anterior descending branch and a 60% stenosis in his right coronary artery.  Diagnosis:  With the patient's history  symptoms  and investigation reports  he was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Treatment:  Anti-anginal drugs like aspirin  nitroglycerin  beta-blockers  and statins were administered according to the current AHA guidelines. Cardiac rehabilitation was suggested and he was explained about potential intervention options  such as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) or coronary artery bypass treatment (CABT)  which can be considered in the upcoming days.   Discussion:  It is documented in the literature that African-American men have a higher risk of CAD  partially due to an increased prevalence of risk factors like hypertension  obesity  and diabetes. In this case  the patient's past medical history of hypertension and diabetes along with personal habits of smoking added to the risk.  Comprehensive treatment involving medical management  interventions  and lifestyle modifications are key aspects to manage and prevent the progression of CAD. This case underscores the importance of proactive cardiovascular care in patients with CAD risk factors and highlights the complex management challenges that often arise in such cases.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the high prevalence of CAD among elderly African-American men and the detrimental impact of common co-morbidities like Hypertension  Diabetes along with smoking. A comprehensive approach for risk management is necessary to prolong the survival and enhance the quality of life in these patients.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. N  a 62-year-old Caucasian male from urban Pennsylvania  presented himself to the hospital outpatient department. He is an ex-smoker with a 30-pack year history who quit smoking about 5 years ago. He reports daily consumption of alcohol  which he has recently reduced to moderate intake. He has a moderately sedentary lifestyle in a stressful executive job with irregular meal patterns. His family history reveals that his father had been diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD) in his mid-60s.  Medical History: The past medical history of Mr. N reveals a diagnosis of type II diabetes for the past 10 years  hypercholesterolemia diagnosed 5 years ago  and hypertension known for approximately 6 years. He has been relatively compliant with his medication  which consists of metformin for diabetes  a statin for hypercholesterolemia  and a beta-blocker for the control of hypertension.   Patient complaint: The patient complained about a persistent discomfort over the left side of the chest especially during physical activity  which is relieved by rest. On further enquiry he elaborated that the discomfort is less often pain  but a pressure-like feeling 'like someone sitting on my chest'.  Investigations: An ECG revealed a minor ST-segment depression. The Lipid Profile shows elevated LDL cholesterol levels (160 mg/dL) and slightly decreased HDL cholesterol levels (38 mg/dL). Fasting blood sugar level was 172 mg/dL  while postprandial sugar level was also on the higher side. BMI was calculated to be 28  indicating overweight.  Diagnosis: Considering the patient's symptoms along with his medical history and diagnostic tests  he was diagnosed with CAD and chronic stable angina.  Management and Progress: The patient was advised to reduce alcohol intake  keep diabetes and cholesterol under control and maintain a balanced diet. His antidiabetic medication (metformin) was continued  statin was adjusted  and an additional antiplatelet agent was added. Regular moderate exercise and to quit his job due to a stressful environment was also recommended to the patient. He was also counseled about the signs of disease progression and when to seek immediate medical help as part of patient education.  For his angina  he was initiated on Isosorbide dinitrate and the beta-blocker dose was also adjusted.  The patient was scheduled for a regular follow-up visit in 6 weeks to monitor progress  and also advised to present immediately if symptoms deteriorate or persist.  This case underscores the importance of a comprehensive approach  including lifestyle modification  patient education  and medical management for effective control of coronary artery disease.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information  A 52-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history of Type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presented at our clinic complaining of intermittent chest discomfort  fatigue  and shortness of breath upon exertion for the past 3 weeks. He is a current smoker with a 30-pack-year history  does not consume alcohol  and has a diet rich in red meat and processed food. He works in a high-stress job  has a BMI of 30.8  and reports irregular exercise habits. The patient was born and raised in Mexico City  and he moved to the USA 10 years ago.  Medical History  Diabetes was diagnosed 7 years ago  managed with metformin 500 mg twice daily. Blood glucose levels have been relatively stable with occasional fluctuations. Hypertension was diagnosed 5 years ago  treated with lisinopril 10 mg daily  and blood pressure readings have consistently been below 140/90 mmHg. Hyperlipidemia was discovered during a routine medical check-up 2 years ago. Following dietary modifications  the patient has been on atorvastatin 20 mg daily since then. No history of myocardial infarctions  strokes  or any other cardiac-related disease.  Family History  His father had undergone angioplasty  diagnosed with coronary artery disease at age 58  and his mother had type II diabetes. One of his two sisters has hypertension  and the other has no notable health issues.   Presenting Issue  The patient described his chest discomfort as a pressure-like sensation that generally initiates during physical exertion like climbing stairs or carrying heavy things and often gets relieved with rest. He also mentioned that he had similar instances in the past  but the frequency has increased within the last month.  Diagnosis and Treatment  An Electrocardiogram and Treadmill Test suggested possible coronary artery disease. Further evaluation with a Coronary Angiogram confirmed the presence of significant stenosis in the left anterior descending coronary artery and right coronary artery.  The patient was prescribed an initial dose of antianginal medication (metroprolol 50 mg/day)  aspirin 100 mg/day  and advised to continue his antihypertensive  antidiabetic  and statin therapy. A consultation with a dietitian was arranged to provide the patient with a nutritional plan that involves low saturated fat and low sodium diet. He was further referred to cardiac rehabilitation for monitored regular exercise and smoking cessation program.  Patient education was also initiated regarding the importance of lifestyle changes  medication adherence  and periodic reviews. We discussed the potential for a coronary angioplasty or bypass surgery if his symptoms do not improve with medications and lifestyle changes.   This case illustrates the significant impact of modifiable risk factors including smoking and obesity in a patient predisposed to coronary artery disease due to both genetic and acquired risk factors.

Case Report: A Case of Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information:  Mr. B  a 68-year-old African-American male  was referred to cardiology following a consultation with his primary care provider due to ongoing angina.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient reported a three-month history of exertional chest pain that radiated to his left arm  usually triggered by physical exertion or emotional stress and relieved by rest. He also experienced associated symptoms of shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional episodes of lightheadedness.  Past Medical History:  Mr. B had been previously diagnosed with hypertension and Type-II diabetes mellitus. He had been managing these conditions with a regimen of Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively. He also has a 25-year history of smoking but quit five years ago.   Family History:  His father had a myocardial infarction at age 60  and his maternal grandfather had a known history of coronary artery disease (CAD).  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  Mr. B appeared comfortable at rest but became noticeably dyspneic following mild exertion. His blood pressure was 140/90 mm Hg  pulse 80 bpm  and BMI 29 kg/m2. The remainder of the physical examination  including a respiratory and neurological examination  was unremarkable.  Investigations:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) at rest revealed no significant abnormalities. However  a stress test showed ischemic changes  with ST-segment depressions noted in the inferior and lateral leads.   A subsequent coronary angiogram confirmed the presence of severe  three-vessel CAD involving the left anterior descending artery  the right coronary artery  and the left circumflex artery.  Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on sublingual nitroglycerin for his acute anginal symptoms  aspirin  and high-dose statins as secondary prevention for CAD. Due to the advanced  triple-vessel CAD shown in angiogram  he was referred for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)  given the high risk associated with percutaneous coronary intervention due to extensive disease.   Discussion:  This case highlights common risk factors for CAD  including advanced age  male sex  hypertension  diabetes  smoking history  and family history of premature CAD. This underscores the importance of regular cardiovascular screening and aggressive risk factor management among high-risk individuals. Further  patients with extensive CAD often necessitate revascularization via CABG  as seen in this case.   Follow-up:  Post-surgical follow-up was scheduled to evaluate the patient's symptomatology  reassess cardiac function post-CABG  and to adjust medications as needed. A comprehensive long-term management plan  including smoking cessation  dietary modifications  and regular exercise  was also discussed with the patient.   Conclusion:  Coronary artery disease remains a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. This case emphasizes the importance of meticulous risk factor optimization and timely management to improve outcomes amongst patients with CAD.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease   Patient Information The patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian male  currently residing in San Diego  California. He is a retired IT professional and has led a fairly sedentary lifestyle for the past several years. The patient is a former smoker  with a 25-pack year history  but quit smoking 15 years ago. His diet is reported to be high in saturated fats and processed food  with a low intake of fruits and vegetables. The patient is divorced and lives alone. He has two adult children with whom he has limited contact. Social history reveals a moderate intake of alcohol  averaging about 2-3 drinks per week.  Medical History The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both being managed with medication for the past 10 years. He has been on Metformin 500mg twice daily for his diabetes  and Losartan 50 mg daily for his hypertension. He also has a history of dyslipidemia  for which he takes Atorvastatin 20 mg daily. His last HbA1c measurement six months ago was 7.4% and his blood pressure averaged around 140/85 mmHg. His lipid panels revealed elevated LDL levels (160 mg/dL). His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 64  indicating a family history of coronary artery disease.  Presenting Complaint and Examination The patient presented with complaints of chest pain that he described as ""angina"" (pain located in the center of his chest  described as pressure-like  radiating to his left arm  and being exacerbated by activity). The pain was relieved by rest and nitroglycerin. These symptoms had been progressively worsening over the past month. On examination  the patient appeared anxious but was not in acute distress. His cardiovascular exam showed increased heart rate with normal rhythm. No murmurs were heard.  Investigations and Diagnosis Based on the patient's risk factors and symptoms  a diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) was suspected. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed evidence of previous inferolateral myocardial infarctions. Subsequent Echocardiogram revealed impaired left ventricular function.  Further confirmation was achieved through Coronary angiogram  which demonstrated significant obstruction in two of his coronary arteries- 70% stenosis in the proximal segment of the Left Anterior Descending artery (LAD) and 80% stenosis in the posterior descending artery (PDA).  Treatment and Follow up The patient was advised to undergo Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI). Post-procedure  he was continued on his previous medications and was additionally started on dual antiplatelet therapy- Aspirin 81mg and Clopidogrel 75mg to prevent stent thrombosis and further cardiovascular events.   A referral for cardiac rehabilitation was made for him to adapt lifestyle modifications. Regular follow-ups were set up for monitoring of his symptoms and medication adjustment.  This case illustrates the importance of accurate diagnosis and intervention in CAD  particularly in patients with multiple risk factors and comorbidities. It also emphasizes the need for lifestyle modifications and regular follow-ups in managing CAD.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Subject: Mr. Larson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Concerns:  Mr. Larson presented to the clinic reporting acute chest pain radiating to his left arm  associated with shortness of breath  which had started abruptly while he was gardening.  Medical History:  Mr. Larson has a chronic history of hypertension  for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide. His BMI is 30  qualifying him as obese according to standard parameters. He quit smoking 10 years ago but had a smoking history of 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. His father had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 70. He also admits to a diet high in saturated fats and low in fruits and vegetables. Mr. Larson leads a sedentary lifestyle  with little to no regular physical activity.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination showed high blood pressure (160/95 mmHg). His heart rate was regular but accelerated (110 bpm)  and the examination of the lungs revealed clear lung fields bilaterally. There were no signs of lower limb edema or jugular vein distension. On auscultation  there were no obvious murmurs or abnormal heart sounds.  Investigations:  An EKG showed ST elevation in the anterior leads  indicative of acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. His full blood count was within normal ranges  but his Lipid profile revealed elevated LDL (170 mg/dL) and total cholesterol (245 mg/dL) levels. His Troponin I level was significantly elevated  which is highly suggestive of myocardial damage.  Treatment:  Mr. Larson was immediately started on aspirin  and nitroglycerin was administered sublingually for his chest pain. He was administered oxygen therapy for his shortness of breath  and an urgent cardiology consult was requested. He underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) due to the acute myocardial infarction  which confirmed a major blockage in his left anterior descending artery.  Outcome:  Post-treatment  his symptoms improved considerably. He was advised upon the importance of lifestyle modification including low cholesterol diet  regular exercise  weight loss  and cessations of any tobacco use. Mr. Larson was discharged with medication: low dose aspirin  a beta-blocker  a statin  and an ACE inhibitor to manage his coronary artery disease and hypertension.  Follow-up:  Mr. Larson is to return to the cardiology clinic for regular follow-ups regarding his condition and medication regimen. He was referred to a dietitian and a physical therapist to aid him with his lifestyle changes. Furthermore  he will attend a cardiac rehabilitation program for ongoing monitoring and support.

Title: A Case of Coronary Artery Disease in an Elderly Asian Male with a History of Hypertension  Patient Information:  A 70-year-old Asian male presented to the out-patient department of our hospital complaining of persistent chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain initiated while he was gardening and ramped up gradually over two hours  leading him to seek medical help. His past medical history includes chronic hypertension under control for the last 10 years.  Clinical Findings:  The patient reported severe retrosternal chest pain  difficulty in breathing  and cold sweats. On physical examination  he appeared stressful and pale. He had a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg and radial pulse was 90 beats per minute  regular. Auscultation revealed no abnormal heart sounds or murmurs. Rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  Timeline:  The patient  who lives alone  reported that he had been managing his blood pressure well with diet and medication for the past decade. He had quit smoking fifteen years ago but had a history of 20-pack years. Chest pain had started suddenly while working in the garden  which he could not relate to any particular strenuous activity.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An urgent electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation indicative of a myocardial infarction. Blood biochemistry revealed elevated serum cardiac markers including Troponin I and CK-MB. The patient was taken immediately for a coronary angiography confirming an obstructive lesion in the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery  indicative of coronary artery disease.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Following the acute phase diagnosis  the patient was immediately loaded with aspirin  clopidogrel and was initiated on a high-dose statin. Following consent  he underwent a successful primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stent placement in the LAD.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient’s post-procedure course was uneventful. His chest pain resolved  and repeated ECGs showed resolution of ST-segment deviation. He received medication management including a beta-blocker  an ACE inhibitor  and a high-dose statin. After a brief stay in the hospital  he was discharged with instructions to continue his medications  to monitor his blood pressure regularly  and to follow a cardiac-friendly diet and exercise plan.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed relief over the resolution of his chest pain and was thankful for the timely diagnosis and intervention. He is motivated to pursue a heart-healthy lifestyle.  Informed Consent:  Informed consent was obtained from the patient for the procedure and for the publication of this case report.  This case aims to highlight how a history of chronic hypertension  old age  Asian ethnicity and prior smoking habit can gravely contribute to the development of coronary artery disease  requiring timely therapeutic interventions to mitigate risk and manage disease progression.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a 65-Year-Old Asian Male: A Case Report  Patient Information:  The subject of this case report is a 65-year-old Asian male. He is a widow  lives alone  and was formerly a corporate engineer. He is a non-smoker and non-vegetarian  with a moderate level of alcohol consumption.   Chief Complaint:  The patient presented with complaints of recurrent chest pain  discomfort in the left arm  shortness of breath  fatigue  light-headedness  and nausea.  History of the Present Illness:  The patient reported that the symptoms commenced subtly three months prior to the consultation. The discomforting chest pain was initially experienced as intermittent  generally occurring during periods of exertion. However  over the past few weeks  the pain became more frequent and prolonged  occasionally waking him up from sleep.   Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus twelve years prior and maintains his HbA1C levels around 7.0% with oral hypoglycemic agents. He also has a history of hypertension  under control with anti-hypertensive medication. The patient has no history of allergy or prior surgeries.   Family History:  The patient's father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 72. The patient has two older siblings  both of whom have a history of hypertension.  Physical Examination:  The patient's vital signs were as follows: Blood Pressure -145/85 mmHg  Pulse rate - 80 beats/minute  respiratory rate 18 breaths/minute  temperature 98.6 F  and SpO2 92% at room air. Heart sounds revealed no murmurs or gallops  lungs were clear to auscultation  and the abdomen was soft with no organomegaly.  Investigations:  Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed T-wave inversion in leads V1-V4. The total cholesterol level was 240mg/dl  LDL - 155mg/dl  HDL - 35mg/dl  and triglycerides -170mg/dl. Troponin T levels were elevated.  Diagnosis:  Based on the history  clinical examination  and investigations  the patient was diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD).  Treatment:  The patient was admitted to the hospital and started on dual antiplatelet therapy  beta-blockers  and statins. Coronary angiography was suggested  and the results demonstrated significant plaque in the right coronary artery. Consequently  the patient underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement.  Follow-Up:  At a follow-up appointment one month post-intervention  the patient reported a significant reduction in symptoms. Life-style modifications and adherence to medication were encouraged for long-term management. Regular outpatient visits were scheduled for proactive healthcare monitoring.   Conclusion:  This report underscores the correlation between Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus  hypertension  familial history  and the onset of CAD. It also emphasizes the necessity of regular health check-ups for early detection and timely management of these risk factors.   Patient Consent: Obtained  Confidentiality: Maintained.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a 58-year-old Caucasian Male with History of Hypertension and Smoking   Patient Description:  This case report describes a Caucasian male patient aged 58  living in a semi-rural region of North Carolina  USA. He is of middle socioeconomic status  married  working as a truck driver and is a current smoker with a 30-pack year history.   Background Medical History:  For the last 10 years  he has been managed medically for his diagnosed stage 1 hypertension (HTN)  for which he has been non-compliant with his medication  Losartan 25mg daily  for the last two months citing financial issues and carelessness as reasons. He consumes a high-fat diet and has led a sedentary lifestyle with little to no exercise noted. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease – his father suffered and died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. His other significant history includes intermittent moderate alcohol intake and a moderate-to-high level of occupational stress. There is no history of diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  or kidney disease.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to his left arm and shoulder that started 1 hour prior to the presentation and was associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis and mild nausea. The pain was non-responsive to resting and described as a “tightening sensation”.   Physical Examination:  On admission  his blood pressure was 155/95 mmHg  heart rate 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. His body mass index was 30.5  indicating obesity. On cardiac examination  there were no audible murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  Laboratory Investigations and Management:  Blood tests showed elevated cardiac enzyme troponin level  and the electrocardiogram pointed to signs of ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Urgent cardiac catheterization demonstrated triple vessel disease which confirmed the diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD).   The patient was immediately started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel  along with intravenous nitroglycerin for symptomatic relief of angina. Given the severity of the disease  patient underwent successful coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).  Discussion:  This case represents a typical presentation of CAD in a high-risk patient with contributing factors of smoking  hypertension  physical inactivity  obesity  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. It emphasizes the importance of preventive measures and compliance to treatment for hypertension  as well as modification of lifestyle factors in the prevention of CAD.   Despite the immediate action taken in treating the acute condition and stabilizing the patient  emphasis must also be placed on long-term management of the modifiable risk factors present. Thus  it is necessary for the healthcare team to consider smoking cessation therapy  diet and weight management  blood pressure control  stress management  and exercise regime for the patient after discharge. Mentioning the importance of patient education and adherence concerning his condition and lifestyle modifications is crucial to the prevention of future cardiac events.   This case illustrates the complexity and multifactorial nature of CAD and also emphasizes the importance of holistic management in such chronic conditions.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Profile: • Gender: Male  • Age: 68 years old • Occupation: Retired architect • Ethnicity: White • Geographic location: Midwest  USA  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with an episodic feeling of discomfort in the chest  often occurring during exertion and subsiding during rest.   Medical History: The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension for which he has been on Lisinopril 20 mg. He is also diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes for the past 15 years and on daily oral drugs: Metformin 500mg and Glimepiride 1mg. He had a brief encounter with transient ischemic attack five years back. No history of previous surgeries.   Family History: A strong family history reveals that his father passed away from myocardial infarction at the age of 64  and his older brother was diagnosed with CAD at the age of 60. No pertinent hereditary diseases reported.  Lifestyle and Risk Factors: The patient quit smoking 7 years ago but admits to several years of heavy smoking in his past. His exercise is minimal  typically limited to daily activities such as short walks and gardening. His diet comprises high-fat foods  rich in saturated fats and cholesterol.   Clinical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared overweight with a BMI of 28.9 (height: 175cm  weight: 87kg). Blood pressure was slightly elevated at 140/90 mm Hg.   Clinical Investigations: Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed slight ST-segment depression. Lipid panel revealed dyslipidemia: high levels of total cholesterol (220mg/dL)  LDL cholesterol (140mg/dL)  and triglycerides (200 mg/dL)  and low levels of HDL cholesterol (30 mg/dL). Blood glucose levels were slightly elevated (fasting: 150 mg/dl  post-meal: 220 mg/dl).  Diagnosis:  Clinical presentation  along with the results of investigations  lead to the diagnosis of stable ischemic heart disease  commonly known as coronary artery disease.  Management: The patient has been advised to undergo revascularization therapy. Meanwhile  he is put on Aspirin (75mg per day)  Beta-Blocker (Metoprolol 50mg per day)  a Statin (Atorvastatin 20mg/day). His antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications are continued. The patient is also advised to follow a low-fat diet  exercise regularly  and maintain a healthy lifestyle.
