Past Medical History:  Mrs. Gonzalez has a medical history of hypertension diagnosed five years ago  for which she takes once-daily Lisinopril (10mg). She also has Type 2 diabetes mellitus over the past ten years managed with Metformin (500mg BID). She is non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. Patient's mother suffered from Coronary Artery Disease and had a myocardial infarction in her late 60s.  Key Complaints:  Over the past two days  Mrs. Gonzalez has been experiencing episodic  dull ‘squeezing’ chest pain radiating to her left arm. The pain typically lasts for around 15 minutes and is particularly triggered by physical exertion such as climbing stairs or after having a meal. She reports that she has felt increasingly fatigued over the past week and has been experiencing disturbed sleep due to shortness of breath.   She has had mild to moderate episodes of pain prior to this  but it was never as severe. She initially dismissed it as indigestion but decided to seek medical attention when her medications for indigestion failed to relieve the symptoms. She also noticed that she now gets easily tired even on doing tasks which didn't exhaust her before.   She denies having any fever  cough  gastrointestinal or urinary complaints. However  she expressed significant concern relating to her heart disease risk given her familial background.  **Please note: Although this case reflects general demographic trends for Coronary Artery Disease  each patient should be considered unique and treated on their individual presentation.**

Case Subject: Mr. George Martinez  Demographics: Mr. Martinez  a 62-year-old Hispanic male  residing in the Southeastern United States  is retired from a managerial position. He currently lives alone  smokes about a package of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years  and drinks alcohol socially. He admits to a diet high in saturated fats and carbohydrates with minimal physical activity. He also has a significant family history of coronary artery disease with both his father and paternal uncle having myocardial infarctions in their early 60s.  Past Medical History: Mr. Martinez has a history of type 2 diabetes diagnosed at age 50  which is poorly controlled (latest HbA1c is 9.2)  moderate hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. His medication history includes metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. Mr. Martinez also has a short history of erectile dysfunction. He does not report any allergies.  Presenting complaints: For the last three weeks  Mr. Martinez has been experiencing episodes of discomfort localized in the central chest area. The discomfort is dull in nature  comes on with exertion (primarily while climbing stairs)  and is relieved with rest in about 10 minutes. More recently  he has noted that the discomfort starts even with less exertion  such as walking short distances.  He denies experiencing this discomfort at rest  in cold weather  or during moments of stress or emotion. The discomfort does not radiate and is not associated with dyspnea  nausea  or sweating. Over the last few days  he has begun to experience it more frequently.  Objective Data to be collected: Objective data collections should focus on physical examination findings such as blood pressure  heart rate  signs of heart failure  or other related illnesses. It should also include relevant lab findings including blood lipids levels  blood glucose levels  ECG  stress test  etc.  Brief Summary: Mr. Martinez  a 62-year-old Hispanic male with a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking  presents with exertional chest discomfort consistent with the typical angina pattern. Given his risk factors and symptoms  coronary artery disease should be high on the differential diagnosis. The objective data collection will assist in confirming or discarding this diagnosis and guide the subsequent management pathway.

Case Report:  Patient Profile:   Name: John Doe Age: 65-year-old Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Past Medical History:  - Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 for 15 years  well-managed on Metformin. - Hypertension for 10 years  on Lisinopril. - Prior 30-year smoking history  quit five years ago.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Doe presents to his primary care physician with a 2-month history of worsening chest pain  particularly on exertion. He describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation in the center of his chest that sometimes radiates to his left arm. There has been no associated nausea  vomiting  diaphoresis or loss of consciousness. The pain usually subsides after rest.  He admits to feeling fatigued more than usual and has been having bouts of breathlessness  especially when climbing stairs or other physical activities he could previously manage without any trouble. He is currently living alone and is anxious about his symptoms  which interfere with his daily activities and hobbies.  Data Reference:   Hoffman  J. I.  & Kaplan  S. (2002). The incidence of congenital heart disease. Journal of the American College of Cardiology  39(12)  1890-1900.-  Anderson JL  Adams CD  Antman EM  et al. ACC/AHA 2007 Guidelines for the Management of Patients With Unstable Angina/Non–ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction: Executive Summary. Circulation. 2007;116(7):803-877.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Robert Hastings  a 62-year-old Caucasian male occupies an upper middle-class economic status. Mr. Hastings is an executive at a corporate firm which involves high levels of stress and sedentary work activities. He has been a smoker for 40 years and has reduced his physical activity over the past 10 years. He currently consumes a diet high in saturated fats.  Past Medical History: Mr. Hastings has a significant past medical history including: 1. Hypertension (diagnosed at 45 yo) 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (diagnosed at 55 yo) 3. High cholesterol levels (diagnosed at 50 yo) 4. Family history of cardiovascular diseases (Father died at 65 yo due to myocardial infarction).  Key complaints: - Over the past three months  Mr. Hastings has episodically experienced a sensation of heavy pressure in the mid-chest region  described as being ""squeezed in a vise."" - The pain often radiates to his left shoulder and arm. - These episodes are most frequently triggered by stress or physical exertion and typically last for about 10-15 minutes. - Rest or nitroglycerin  prescribed for his angina  seems to relieve this pain. - In the past week  he has noticed this pain persisting at rest  and episodes have increased in both severity and frequency.  This real-world case centers on a representative patient based on the demographics of those most commonly affected by coronary artery disease  as found in the literature. Numerous risk factors are notably present in Mr. Hastings' history  including advanced age  male gender  hypertension  smoking history  sedentary lifestyle  poor diet  diabetes  hypercholesterolemia  stressful professional background  and family history of cardiovascular disease. As such  this case encourages medical students to consider the multifactorial nature of coronary artery disease and its strong tie to modifiable lifestyle factors.  Moreover  the recent change in frequency  duration  severity  or ease of provocation of angina episodes displayed in Mr. Hastings case could represent a transition from stable angina to unstable angina  potentially signaling the onset of acute coronary syndrome.

Case Report:  Patient Information: The patient is a 60-year-old African American male named Mr. Jones. He is a retired mechanical engineer  married with three adult children  and a resident of a suburban community. He is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol use.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jones has a notable past medical history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. These conditions are reasonably well-controlled with medication  and regular follow-up with his primary care physician. He maintains a stable weight but has a poor dietary habit  primarily eating red meats  fried food  and processed food with low fiber and low fruits/vegetables. He also has a sedentary lifestyle with little physical exercise.  Family History:  He has a family history of premature coronary artery disease  with his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. His mother suffered from hypertension and diabetes mellitus similar to him but is alive and well at the age of 80.  Key Complaints:  Over the past couple of weeks  Mr. Jones has been experiencing intermittent chest discomfort on moderate exertion  such as climbing two flights of stairs  but the discomfort subsides at rest. The discomfort is described as a central squeezing sensation  sometimes radiating to his left arm which lasts approximately 5 to 10 minutes. Abnormalities are noted as fatigue  occasional shortness of breath  and lightheadedness.  Note: He has not sought any medical advice regarding the above symptoms prior to this visit  attributing the pain to ""just getting old"" and stress. However  he now presents to the emergency department due to the increasing frequency and intensity of the chest discomfort and a general feeling of unwell. There were no associated symptoms of syncope  palpitations  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or lower extremity edema.  Based on this  a working diagnosis of stable angina due to suspected coronary artery disease is made. The contributing factors appear to be a mixture of genetic predisposition and lifestyle choices such as poor diet and lack of regular exercise.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Details: Maria  a 65-year-old Hispanic female.  Past Medical History: Maria has a history of hypertension  diagnosed 10 years ago  and type-2 diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years. She is a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol use. She leads a sedentary lifestyle and is classified as obese with a BMI of 32. Her family history reveals that her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 67.  Chief Complaints: Maria reports progressively worsening chest discomfort over the past six months. She describes the pain as heavy and squeezing  typically lasting for several minutes and more frequently presenting during times of stress or physical labor. She has also been experiencing episodes of unexplained fatigue and breathlessness upon exertion.   Discussion Guide: This case is representative as coronary artery disease (CAD) is more prevalent in females over the age of 60  particularly in those of Hispanic heritage. The patient's history of poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and family history all contribute to an increased risk of CAD. Her symptoms of exertional chest discomfort  fatigue  and breathlessness are classic presentations for angina pectoris which may indicate underlying CAD. According to literature  women with CAD experience more non-traditional symptoms such as fatigue and shortness of breath in comparison to men.  The discussion should drive students to consider the risk factors  presentation  and investigations necessary for diagnosing CAD  including physical examination  ECG  stress testing  and possibly coronary angiography. This case encourages reflection upon lifestyle modifications and pharmacological interventions that could be recommended to this patient to manage her condition and risk factors  including hypertension and diabetes.  Moreover  it is an opportune time to discuss disparities in healthcare  as studies have revealed Hispanic communities have higher rates of obesity and diabetes  both primary risk factors for CAD  and may suffer from decreased access to healthcare. They may also experience language barriers  which could impair patient-physician communication and hinder the delivery of optimal care.

Case Study: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Demographics Patient: Mr. Richard Wilson Age: 58 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Structural engineer Lifestyle: Sedentary  with a history of heavy tobacco smoking and moderate alcohol consumption  Past Medical History:  Mr. Wilson has had a diagnosis of hypertension for the past 10 years controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). He also suffers from type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with Metformin HCL 500mg twice daily and has a history of high cholesterol for which he has been taking Atorvastatin 40mg at bedtime. He had a few close family members who died unexpectedly of heart disease below the age of 60.  Key Complaints:  For the past few months  Mr. Richardson has been experiencing episodes of chest discomfort and shortness of breath during exertion  typically while climbing stairs or performing heavy construction-related work. He has described the pain as a central  pressure-like discomfort in the chest  which usually resolves upon rest. Recently  however  these episodes have begun to occur with lesser activities and sometimes at rest  interfering with his daily life. Last night  he woke up from sleep due to severe chest pain that radiated down his left arm. The pain lasted about 15 minutes and  though it resolved on its own  it left him feeling weak and sweaty.  Please note: Despite the above-mentioned findings  CAD can affect anyone regardless of age  gender  or ethnicity. However  some factors such as older age  male gender  ethnicity like African American  and having family history of heart disease can increase the risk of developing CAD.  The instructor can then guide the students in interpreting the patient's clinical picture and defining the next steps in management. The teaching focus should be on learning about the risk factors and typical symptoms of coronary artery disease  its diagnosis process  including ECG  blood tests  and coronary angiography  as well as management strategies like lifestyle changes  medications  and possible interventions (angioplasty/stent placement  bypass surgery).

Patient Information:  Name: Mr. John Walcott  Age: 52 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Office worker  leading a sedentary lifestyle Smoking Status: Former smoker (20 years  quit 5 years ago) Alcohol Use: Moderate (social drinker) Family History: Positive for coronary artery disease (Father died suddenly at age 58  one older brother underwent coronary angioplasty at age 50)  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension (diagnosed 7 years ago  under medication) 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus (diagnosed 3 years ago  under medication) 3. Hyperlipidemia (diagnosed 4 years ago  under medication)  Key Complaints:  Mr. Walcott visited the clinic complaining of atypical chest pain that he describes as a 'heavy' and 'tight' sensation. The pain started 2 weeks ago. Initially  it occurred intermittently  especially during physical exertion  but has since been increasing in frequency. The pain sometimes radiates to the left arm and is also associated with shortness of breath  excessive sweating  and light-headedness. He has also noted the feeling of fatigue even at rest  unexplained weight gain  and swelling of feet  especially noticed at the end of the day.  Mr. Walcott's case highlights some of the typical features and risk factors associated with coronary artery disease  such as age  male gender  African American ethnicity  history of smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and strong family history of CAD. Furthermore  the presence of comorbid conditions such as hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia significantly accelerates the likelihood of coronary artery disease. The symptoms he presents with point towards angina – probably a sign of significant coronary artery occlusion. It's also important to note the risk of silent ischemia due to his history of diabetes. The symptoms of fatigue  unexplained weight gain  and swelling of feet might indicate possible heart failure  a complication of unchecked CAD.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. Juan Almeida  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  resides in New York City with his wife. He is a retired construction manager  a non-smoker but used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day for around 20 years before he quit 10 years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol. There is a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases  his father passed away due to a heart attack at the age of 70.  Past Medical History:  Over the last 5 years  Mr. Almeida has been managing Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He has been compliant with Metformin 1 gm twice daily and Losartan 50 mg once daily. His most recent Hemoglobin A1c level was measured at 7.2% three months ago  and more recent blood pressure readings have consistently been around 135/85 mmHg. He also frequently suffers from indigestion and has a history of peptic ulcers. His BMI classifies him as overweight (BMI=28).  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Almeida has recently been experiencing episodes of central chest pain radiating to his left arm  especially while walking up stairs or other exertion. The pain is often relieved by rest. These episodes have become increasingly frequent over the past week.   Recent records show slightly elevated cholesterol and LDL levels  with reduced HDL levels.  This case highlights significant clinical risk factors for Coronary Artery Disease including age  gender  ethnicity  family history  physical inactivity  hypertension  history of smoking  diabetes  dyslipidemia and being overweight. The characterizing chest pain is typical of angina pectoris  an important symptom suggesting Coronary Artery Disease.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. Lopez Age: 63 years old  Sex: Male Ethnicity: Hispanic  Occupational History: Retired truck driver.  Demographics: The patient resides in a large metropolitan area known for its multicultural demographics. He is married with two adult children. His socioeconomic status is a low-income bracket.  Past Medical History: The patient was previously diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 15 years ago  and hypertension 10 years ago  managing both conditions with medication and lifestyle adaptations. His one noteworthy surgery was a hernia operation 5 years ago. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 50  indicating a family history of coronary heart disease. His mother has hypertension and diabetes. He smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 25 years but quit 15 years ago. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in fats and carbohydrates.  Key Complaint/Reason for Visit: Mr. Lopez presented to the clinic feeling consistent chest discomfort described as 'pressure-like'  especially when performing physical tasks such as mowing the lawn or climbing stairs. These bouts of discomfort usually last approximately 10 minutes and are typically relieved by rest. He also reported shortness of breath and fatigue on exertion  which have progressively worsened over the last two months. He has not experienced a loss of consciousness  nausea  vomiting  or sweating during these episodes. He has also denied any abnormalities in bowel movements or urination. These symptoms have caused him to stop much of his physical activity  increasing his concern. He denies having ever experienced any similar episodes in the past.  Current Medication: Metformin 1000mg/bid for diabetes  Lisinopril 20mg/once daily for hypertension.  This case represents the demographic group (elderly Hispanic male) known to bear a disproportionately high burden of coronary artery disease owing to a higher prevalence of risk factors such as diabetes and hypertension. This patient’s history of diabetes and hypertension  combined with a family history of early heart disease  and personal history of smoking and ineffective diet serves to increase his risk. With these considerations  potential diagnosis of coronary artery disease is of concern.-degree angle to the long axis of the body and slightly to the left.   End of Case Report.

Patient Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Rivera Sex: Male Age: 62 years  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Bank Manager Insurance Status: Medicare Smoker: Yes (40 pack year history) Alcohol Use: Moderate Body Mass Index (BMI): 28  Past Medical History:   1) Hypertension managed with Lisinopril 2) Type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin 3) Hyperlipidemia managed with Atorvastatin 4) Family history of premature coronary artery disease (CAD)- father and paternal uncle both had their first myocardial infarction at ages 55 and 59 respectively.  Presenting Complaints:   Mr. Rivera presents to the clinic with intermittent  constrictive discomfort in the center of his chest which often radiates towards his left arm. Episodes last for 5-10 minutes at a time and have been happening for the past 2 months. They are often induced by exercise and alleviate by rest. He also reports experiencing dyspnea on exertion and has noticed a decrease in exercise tolerance within the past couple of months. These symptoms have worried Mr. Rivera as he knows his father and uncle both had heart disease. He denies other symptoms such as syncope  palpitations  or orthopnea.  Assessment of this case should focus on advanced cardiovascular examination and diagnostic tests for coronary artery disease including ECG  stress test  echocardiography  and angiogram. Students should be instructed to focus on assessment  risk stratification  patient counseling  and treatment considerations for CAD including medical  invasive  and lifestyle modification strategies. They should also be advised to educate patients about the importance of timely evaluation of potential angina symptoms.  Note: This patient's history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia should be highlighted  as these are major risk factors for developing coronary artery disease which proves its epidemiological setting. Other factors including age  gender  race  and positive family history should also be discussed in the context of risk stratification.

Patient Profile: - Age: 55 years old - Gender: Male - Race: African American - Occupation: Office worker - Smoking Status: Former smoker; 1 pack per day for 25 years  quit 10 years ago - Alcohol Use: Rarely - Family history: Father had hypertension  mother had type II diabetes  Past Medical History: - Hypertension for 10 years  controlled with medication - Type II diabetes for 5 years  diet-controlled - Occasional dyslipidemia  Chief Complaints: 1. Progressive chest discomfort over the past 4 months: The patient describes a dull central chest discomfort radiating to the left arm  usually during exertion (climbing stairs  exercising)  lasting 5-10 minutes  and subsiding with rest. Severity of pain has been increasing from 3/10 (4 months ago) to 6/10 (present). It is occasionally associated with shortness of breath. 2. Shortness of breath on exertion: The patient reported increasing difficulty in breathing on performing daily activities like walking or climbing stairs and has had to reduce his physical activity due to this. No associated cough  wheezing  or chest pain. No orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. 3. Fatigue: The patient reported feeling unusually tired  especially over the past month.  Angina symptoms - chest discomfort with exertion and associated shortness of breath and fatigue suggest an underlying coronary artery disease. His old age  gender  race  history of hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  and smoking status further accentuate his risk. Hence  a coronary artery disease should be kept in differential diagnosis  and further diagnostic evaluations  including diagnostic stress testing or perhaps invasive coronary angiography  should be planned.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics: The patient is Robert  a 66-year-old Caucasian American male. He is a retired military officer  lives with his wife of 40 years  and they have four children. He has a past history of smoking for 10 years but quit 30 years ago. His height is about 5 foot 9 inches  and he weighs 200 pounds. He lives in the urban area of Boston  Massachusetts and comes from a middle-income background.   Past Medical History: Robert has a relevant medical history of hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago and controlled medications. He also has a history of hypercholesterolemia which was diagnosed 6 years ago and is under control with statin therapy. There is no reported history of diabetes  and Robert regularly monitors his blood sugar after his meals given an unreliable family history of DM. His father died in his early 70s due to a heart attack  and his mother is living and has a history of ischemic heart disease.   Key Complaints: The patient presented to the Emergency Department complaining of intermittent chest pain that has been ongoing for the last couple of weeks. The pain is usually in the central part of his chest and sometimes radiates to the left side of his jaw. It often comes after exertion  like walking a distance  and relieves upon resting. He rate it as 7/10 in severity. Pain is described as squeezing or like ""chest being in a vice.""  In the last two days  he also noticed that the pain often wakes him up from sleep and does not go away even after resting. Robert also mentions feeling extremely fatigued lately compared to his usual state. Occasionally  he also experiences profuse sweating  despite daily temperatures being in the normal range.   Concluding Remarks:  This case report can form the basis for understanding and diagnosing Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Robert's history  demographics  and symptoms can be analyzed to consider possible medical diagnoses  engage in differential diagnoses as well as plan investigations. His notable risk factors include age  gender  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  ex-smoker status  family history  and symptoms that match the profile for CAD.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Rodriguez  Age: 59 years Gender: Male Race: Hispanic Occupation: Truck driver Smoking Status: Smoker (30 packs/year) Alcohol Consumption: Moderate  BMI: 30 (Obese) Family History: Father suffered from coronary heart disease  Past Medical History: Mr. Rodriguez was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago for which he is on metformin. He was diagnosed with hypertension 7 years ago for which he takes amlodipine. He also suffers from dyslipidemia  currently managed on statin therapy. He has a history of smoking for the past 20 years.    Presenting Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez visits the clinic complaining of recurring chest discomfort that he describes as a heavy feeling rather than a sharp pain  particularly when doing physical activities  which eases upon rest. He also reports shortness of breath  tiredness  and occasional feelings of dizziness. He has also noticed that his episodes of chest discomfort have recently been triggered by lesser levels of exertion than before.   Based on the aforementioned profile  the patient is presenting with stable angina due to coronary artery disease  a clinical diagnosis that should be confirmed with appropriate investigations. Cardiovascular risk factors in this case include the patient's age  gender  heredity  diabetes  hypertension  dyslipidemia  obesity  smoking history  sedentary lifestyle  and possibly stress given his profession.

Case Report:  Demographics - Patient: Mr. Samuel Peterson Age: 65 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Engineer Smoking History: Ex-smoker; stopped 7 years ago.  Past Medical History - 1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 2. Hypertension 3. Dyslipidemia  Key Complaint - Mr. Peterson presented to the clinic with a 6-week history of experiencing tightness in the chest  particularly during his morning walks. The chest discomfort typically lasts 10-15 minutes and usually resolves with rest. He complained that over the last week  the chest pain has started to occur more frequently  at times even while at rest. He has noticed that his exercise tolerance has decreased. He also reported occasional shortness of breath  particularly while climbing stairs  but does not wake him during sleep. He denied any palpitation  dizziness  syncope  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. No prior history of heart disease. He maintains a rather sedentary lifestyle and his diet is high in sodium and saturated fats. His BMI falls into the overweight range. He has a history of 35 years of smoking  but quit 7 years ago.  This case is designed to be indicative of stable angina progressing into unstable angina  which are common presentations in Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). The contributing risk factors are senior age  male gender  history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  sedentary lifestyle  and an unhealthy diet. These are all widely associated with CAD in medical literature.  Note: Adjust demographic characteristics accordingly to reflect the patient population in your geographic location or intended scope of practice.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics: Name: John Doe Age: 52 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Construction laborer Smoking status: Smoked 1 pack/day for 30 years  Past Medical History: 1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (controlled with metformin). 2. Hypertension (controlled with lisinopril). 3. Obesity with Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31. 4. Family history of heart disease (father and elder brother died of heart attacks in their mid-fifties).  Chief Complaints: Patient presents to the clinic complaining of episodes of chest discomfort over the past six weeks  particularly during physical work or walking. He describes the discomfort as a heavy pressure-like sensation  located ""right in the middle of the chest"". The episodes generally resolve with rest within about 10 minutes. The pain does not radiate and is not associated with shortness of breath  nausea or diaphoresis (sweating).  Of note  he states that these episodes are becoming more frequent  and he had one today  which prompted him to seek medical attention. The episode today was similar to previous ones but felt more intense and lasted for about 20 minutes  causing him concern. He denies experiencing any dizziness  palpitations  or loss of consciousness.  The Case:  To provide a better understanding of the case  students will have to start with recognizing that the patient's history is highly suggestive of angina pectoris due to coronary artery disease (CAD). They are requested to outline the associated risk factors from the patient’s history and discuss the significant management strategies  which is basement of the diagnosis suspected. The case is designed in such a way as to prompt the need for urgency and aggressiveness in the management of CAD  given the patient's increasing frequency and intensity of chest pain. This situation could suggest underlying worsening CAD or potentially unstable angina  which can lead to myocardial infarction or heart attack if not addressed urgently.

Case Report   Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Hispanic male named Mr. Lorenzo Garcia. He is a retired postman  lives with his wife  and has 3 grown-up children. His primary language is Spanish but he also speaks fluent English. He is a long-term smoker with a 40 pack-year smoking history and is overweight with a BMI of 28. He lives in an urban population area and has a fixed income with adequate Medicare insurance. He has an average level of education  having finished high school.  Past Medical History: Mr. Garcia has a medical history of hypertension (HTN)  which was diagnosed 10 years ago and is well-controlled with Lisinopril. Five years ago  he was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM type 2) and is on Metformin with inadequate glycemic control. He also has Hyperlipidemia  for which he is prescribed statin therapy. His father had an early myocardial infarction (died at age 56). We could not find any family history of stroke or other peripheral vascular disease.  Key Complaints: Mr. Garcia seeks medical attention due to a two-month history of episodic chest pain. The pain typically arises on brisk walking and is relieved after a few minutes of rest. For the last two weeks  however  he admits that it has been occurring more frequently  especially during minimal activities such as climbing stairs  and sometimes at rest. He describes it as a pressing  substernal pain that sometimes radiates to his left shoulder but never to his jaw or arm. At times  he experiences a few moments of breathlessness with the chest pain. He also reports of feeling increasingly fatigued over the last few weeks. There’s no history of associated diaphoresis  palpitations  syncope  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He denies experiencing any fevers  coughs  swollen legs  or significant weight changes. He also denies any change in his diet or daily activities that might explain his symptoms.  This case is representative of the accurate demographic disposition of coronary artery disease  especially considering the prevalence among Hispanic males  the patient's age  significant family history  and the effect of comorbidities such as diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and smoking habit.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Credentials: - Name: John Doe (Pseudonym used to maintain patient confidentiality) - Age: 68 years - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: African American - Occupation: Retired Bank Manager - Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has been a type II diabetic for the past 20 years with fair glycemic control. He has been hypertensive for the past 15 years for which he takes antihypertensives regularly. He was a heavy smoker until five years ago  when he quit. He also has a familial history of cardiovascular disease – his father suffered from a myocardial infarction at the age of 75.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with a primary complaint of severe chest pain since last evening. He explains the pain as heaviness in his chest and the pain radially spreads to his left arm and jaw. Along with that  he reported episodes of breathlessness on minimal exertion and episodes of unexplained fatigue over the past month. He also mentioned experiencing palpitations and occasional lapses into lightheadedness.  Given the high prevalence of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) in African American males in their late 60s and based on the symptomatic correlation  students are advised to consider a differential diagnosis of CAD. Further evaluations and management strategies should be discussed and decided within the scope of this clinical impression.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Information: Mr. Rodriguez is a 67-year-old Hispanic male retired from manual labor  who currently resides in Albuquerque  New Mexico with his wife.   Past Medical History: Mr. Rodriguez has had borderline hypertension for the last 10 years  controlled with lifestyle modifications along with occasional use of anti-hypertensive medication  namely amlodipine. He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 3 years ago but rarely follows the diet or medication regimen prescribed; his HbA1c levels consistently indicate poor glycaemic control. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history  but reports having quit smoking about 10 years ago. He is overweight with a BMI of 29.5 kg/m2  and has a family history of premature heart disease  with his father dying of myocardial infarction at age of 56. Lastly  he admits to drinking alcohol socially.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez consults at the outpatient department complaining of sudden-onset burning chest pain in the central part of his chest  lasting for over an hour. He describes the pain as ""like a pressure or tightness "" radiating to the left arm  associated with shortness of breath  sweating  and light-headedness. The pain was initially eased by rest when it occurred several weeks ago; however  it has started to become severe and happen even while resting in the past week.  Consideration: Given the patient’s age  sex  race/ethnicity  hypertension  diabetes  obesity  family history of premature heart disease  and former smoking habits  he is at a high risk for coronary artery disease. The chief complaints  especially worsening chest pain triggered by minimal or no physical activity and prolonged chest pain at rest  may suggest unstable angina or an ongoing heart attack.  This case well represents an example of coronary artery disease in older  Hispanic males  which is consistent with published literature reporting a higher incidence of heart disease in this demographic. Moreover  poor control of risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  and obesity  along with lifestyle and genetic factors  can worsen the progression of coronary artery disease. This case underlines the necessity of primary and secondary prevention interventions in such high-risk groups.

Case Report:   Patient Demographics: The patient is a 62-year-old African American male  retired and living with his wife of 40 years. He has a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes every day for the past 25 years  though quit ten years ago. He engages in minimal physical exercise and admits his diet could be better  often choosing fast-food meals due to their convenience. He is of moderate socioeconomic status and lives in an urban setting.   Past Medical History:  He has a documented history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both well-controlled with medication (Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension). Five years ago  he was diagnosed with high cholesterol and has been on Atorvastatin since then. There is a family history of heart disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. His last physical examination was a year ago  where he was noted to be obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 32 kg/m2.   Key Complaints: He has recently started experiencing intermittent chest tightness and shortness of breath that typically occur after eating or exerting himself physically. These episodes last for about 5-10 minutes then resolve by themselves  but they are increasing in both frequency and intensity. He has also noticed that he has been more fatigued than usual over the past couple of weeks.  This case acknowledges the elevated risk of coronary artery disease in African American men  particularly those with a history of hypertension  diabetes  high cholesterol  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of heart disease. The symptoms point towards angina  an indicator of coronary artery disease.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  retired construction worker  residing in an urban area. He is married with 3 kids and 6 grandchildren. Mr. Rodriguez is a non-smoker  but reports a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Past Medical History: Mr. Rodriguez has a history of Type 2 diabetes and hypertension  which are both controlled with medication (metformin and lisinopril  respectively). He also has a family history of heart disease  with his father having had a heart attack in his late 50s. His BMI indicates obesity and he admits infrequent exercise. His diet is rich in saturated fats and he shows initial signs of high cholesterol.  Key Presenting Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez comes in for a routine appointment  during which he reports intermittent episodes of chest discomfort over the past two months. The discomfort is described as a tight feeling located in the center of the chest  which sometimes trends towards the left side. These episodes typically last for about 10-15 minutes and often occur after moderate physical exertion such as playing with his grandchildren or doing yard work. He initially attributed the discomfort to indigestion  but recently  lighter activities such as casual walking seem to trigger these episodes  which is now causing him concern. He also reports occasional episodes of breathlessness.   This case is designed to simulate a real-life presentation of coronary artery disease with typical risk factors such as advanced age  male gender  ethnicity  diabetes  hypertension  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and unhealthy diet. Moreover  it takes into account the higher prevalence of coronary artery disease among Hispanics  related to factors such as diabetes and obesity. This case aims to teach medical students to understand  diagnose  and manage coronary artery disease  taking into account cultural  social  and lifestyle factors.

Case Study: Mr. Johnson  Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics: Name: Samuel Johnson Age: 63 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired  ex-smoker for over 10 years after a 30 year smoking history Demographics Justification: The choice of a 63-year-old Caucasian male patient aligns with the current epidemiological data  which identifies middle-aged to elderly men as a high-risk group for coronary artery disease (CAD). Also  rates of CAD are higher in smokers  even those who quit smoking.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension for over 8 years (on medication) 2. Type II Diabetes mellitus for around 5 years (on oral hypoglycemic agents) 3. High cholesterol levels (on statins) 4. Ex-smoker (quit 10 years ago) 5. Family history of heart disease (Father died at 67 from myocardial infarction) History Justification: The patient's medical history demonstrates the association between CAD and common risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  smoking  and genetic predisposition.  Key Complaints: 1. Reported an increasing intensity of chest pain over the past 2 months  more noticeable during physical activities like walking his dog or climbing stairs. 2. The pain  typically in the center of his chest  often radiates to his left shoulder and arm. 3. He often feels breathless with the onset of the chest pain. 4. He's also observed that he tires more quickly than usual in recent weeks. Complaints Justification: Chest pain or discomfort that worsens with physical activity and resolves with rest is typical of angina pectoris – a key symptom of CAD. The fatigue and dyspnea (shortness of breath) reported by the patient are also common symptoms associated with CAD.   In Conclusion: This scenario creates an inclusive environment for the discussion of key concepts in CAD  such as the relationship between risk factors and disease  the significance of patient medical history and patient symptoms in CAD diagnosis. The primary goal of this case study is to boost the medical student's clinical reasoning skills and their understanding of CAD.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. John Rodriguez  a 60-year-old Hispanic male  a retired factory worker  comes to the office for a routine check-up. He is a resident of Los Angeles  grandmother and grandfather both immigrated from Mexico. Married with 3 kids and 5 grandchildren.   Past Medical History: Mr. John has a history of hypertension (HTN) with sub-optimal control on hydrochlorothiazide (HTZ)  diagnosed seven years back. He also has controlled type II diabetes mellitus (DM) managed on metformin for five years. His lipid profile from last year shows mild hyperlipidemia. For the last 15 years  he's been a consistent smoker  smoking a pack of cigarettes a day. His diet is mainly fast food  and admits to having a 'sweet tooth'  often eating sugar-rich foods. He does a 30-minute walk twice a week  but no other physical activities. Family history is remarkable for his father suffering from a myocardial infarction (MI) at the age of 64.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Rodriguez reports he has been experiencing exertional chest discomfort for the past two months. He describes it as a 'feeling of heaviness' located in the center of his chest. It typically lasts less than 10 minutes and is relieved by taking rest. Last week  he experienced this discomfort after a large meal  which is a new occurrence. He denies taking any over-the-counter medication for this. He also notes increased shortness of breath and fatigue while climbing stairs. No history of syncope  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.

Case Report:  Patient Profile:  - Name: John Doe - Age: 62 years - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Firefighter - Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension for 10 years  controlled with medication - Smoker for 30 years  quit 6 years ago - Occasional alcohol drinker - Family history of coronary artery disease in paternal lineage (Father died of myocardial infarction at age 70)  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department complaining of intermittent chest discomfort over the past six weeks. Recently  he has noticed an increase in the severity and frequency of these episodes  stating they often occur while he's engaged in yard work or climbing stairs. The pain is described as a pressure-like sensation in the center of his chest  occasionally radiating to his left arm. Rest and cessation of activity typically relieve the discomfort within a few minutes.  Additional Complaints:  Over the same period  he has also experienced shortness of breath with increased exertion  mild episodes of restlessness  an unusual feeling of fatigue  and infrequent bouts of nausea and cold sweats. There was no history of palpitations  syncope  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He denied cough  fever  or weight changes.   This hypothetical case presents a high-risk profile for coronary artery disease (CAD) which is common in males over the age of 60  especially those with a history of long-term smoking  hypertension  and family history of CAD. The study of CAD prevalence in these demographics is well documented in medical literature  making this an accurate representation for the students to study.

Patient Case Report:  Demographics: Patient: Mr. Allen Smith Age: 63 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired from a managerial position Residence: Urban Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with hypertension two years ago and was prescribed a daily medication regimen. He had a smoking history of 1 pack/day for 35 years and quit 10 years ago. He has a known family history of heart disease  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. There is no history of diabetes.  Key Complaints: Mr. Smith arrived at the outpatient clinic reporting increased fatigue over the past several weeks. He mentions discomfort and tightness in his chest during his daily morning walks in the last two weeks. The chest discomfort  which he describes as heavy and squeezing sensation  tends to subside after 10-15 minutes of rest. He has also noticed mild episodes of shortness of breath accompanying the chest discomfort.  For the past three days  he has been experiencing similar bouts of chest discomfort while doing minor activities around the house or even while sitting stressfully watching news on TV. He has also noticed an increase in frequency and severity of this discomfort and a decrease in its predictability and the exercise amount causing it. He denied any instances of syncope  palpitation  or lower limb swelling. His appetite and weight have remained stable  and he has not noticed any changes in his bowel movements or urine habits.  Note: This case report is designed based on the fact that coronary artery disease (CAD) predominantly affects men over 55 years of age and is particularly prevalent in the Caucasian population. A significant risk factor for CAD is hypertension  along with a history of smoking and a family history of heart disease. The symptoms described by Allen Figuratively are consistent with chronic stable angina transitioning to unstable angina  a common presentation of CAD.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  64-year-old African American male  Presenting Complaint: The patient was brought to the emergency after experiencing sharp chest pain radiating to his left arm  along with shortness of breath  and cold sweats which started while he was climbing stairs at his home.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has been suffering from hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years. He has been on oral hypoglycemic drugs and antihypertensive treatment. He has a history of smoking – approximately one pack per day for the last 30 years  but he quit smoking a year ago. His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 65  indicating a positive family history of coronary artery disease. Mr. Smith admits to not have been too compliant with his medications and has a relatively sedentary lifestyle with an unhealthy diet consisting mainly of processed and high-fat foods.  Lifestyle and Personal Details: Mr. Smith is a retired high school teacher  is widowed  and lives with his son. His alcohol consumption is limited to social occasions.  Key details from initial examination: On physical examination  the patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic. His BP was noted to be 170/100 mmHg  pulse - 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate - 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation - 94% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) was calculated to be 30 kg/m2  indicating that the patient is classified as obese.   On auscultation  no heart murmurs or abnormal lung sounds were heard. His electrocardiogram showed Q wave and ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  consistent with an inferior wall myocardial infarction.  Given his high-risk profile (age  gender  race  history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  unhealthy diet  non-compliance to medications  and family history)  the students should be guided to understand the cumulative impact of these factors on Mr. Smith's cardiovascular health leading to the presenting symptoms of coronary artery disease. This case should serve as an exemplar for coronary artery disease for educating the students on its risk factors  clinical presentation  and immediate management.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics:  Name: John Doe Age: 59 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Police Officer Marital Status: Married  Domicile: Urban area  Past Medical History:  John has a known history of hypertension for 10 years  hyperlipidemia for 7 years  and type 2 diabetes mellitus for 4 years. His father had a heart attack at the age of 62. John has been a smoker for 35 years and has a sedentary lifestyle. His medications include Metformin 500 mg BD for diabetes  Atorvastatin 40 mg OD for hyperlipidemia  and Lisinopril 10 mg OD for hypertension. John has poor medication adherence.  Key complaints:  John came to the emergency room complaining of central chest pain radiating to the left arm  worsening over the last 3 hours with associated shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. He states that the pain feels like a heavy weight is placed on the chest and it does not alleviate with rest.  As this case represents  men  especially those with familial history of heart disease  have a greater propensity towards coronary artery disease. Increased prevalence of the disease can also be observed in people with sedentary lifestyles  smokers  individuals with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes. Even though coronary artery disease can affect individuals of all races and ethnicities  Caucasian men have been reportedly more prone to it as compared to their racial counterparts. Older age and urban lifestyle due to changes in physical activity and diet also increase the risk. Thus  John's case fairly represents common demographic and risk factors seen in literature.   In your further education lessons  you may want to elaborate on the detailed assessment  investigations  diagnosis  management  and counseling of patients with coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. James Roberts Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired steelworker  Past medical history:   1. Hypertension for 15 years  managed with lisinopril. 2. Type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years  managed with metformin. 3. Dyslipidemia  managed with atorvastatin. 4. Family history of coronary artery disease; father died of a heart attack at the age of 72. 5. Smoking history of 20 pack-years  but sober for 5 years now. 6. Moderate alcohol consumption.  Key Complaints:   Mr. Roberts has visited the Emergency Department with chief complaints of:   1. Chest Pain: He describes it as a heavy crushing pain in the center of the chest that radiates to the left arm and jaw. The pain started approximately one hour ago while he was mowing his lawn. It’s not relieving with rest and graded as 8 on a scale of 10. 2. Shortness of Breath: He reports difficulty breathing along with the onset of chest pain. 3. Diaphoresis: Profuse sweating noticed along with chest pain.  Additional Notes:  This case was designed for medical students to study the correlation between demographic factors and Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Emphasis is placed on the patient's key risk factors including age  race  gender  previous medical history  family history of CAD  and lifestyle factors including smoking and alcohol consumption. The students will also learn to appreciate the nature of chest pain commonly associated with CAD progression.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 64-year-old African American male  retired mechanic  living in an urban setting. He is currently living with his wife. The patient is a former heavy smoker  having quit 8 years ago  but reports a 35 pack-year history. He is known to have a moderate level of physical activity but continues to battle obesity with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32. Patient history shows an unhealthy diet high in saturated fats and trans fats. The patient reports moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both of which have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. There’s also a record of dyslipidemia for which he has been inconsistent with his statin therapy. The patient's father died of myocardial infarction at 56 years old  indicating a family history of cardiovascular disease.   Chief Complaints: The patient presents with a 2-week history of intermittent  troubling chest pain that he describes as 'pressure-like'  frequently occurring during physical exertion like climbing stairs or heavy lifting  often resolving at rest. He additionally reports noticing an increased shortness of breath with minimal exertion that he initially attributed to his weight. He is also experiencing episodes of diaphoresis and mild nausea. He denies any recent trauma  cough  fever  or palpitations.   This case scenario was designed to represent the profile of a typical patient with coronary artery disease risk as per literature demographic  which often involves older age  male gender  African American ethnicity  and a history of risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  family history of heart disease  smoking  unhealthy diet  physical inactivity  and obesity.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Demographics: Mr. Michael Dalton  a 65-year-old African American male  retired banker  non-smoker  resides in urban Houston  Texas. He lives with his wife and has a BMI of 30. His family history is significant for CAD  with his father having suffered a heart attack at the age of 68.   Past Medical History: Mr. Dalton has a known case of Hypertension for the past 15 years for which he takes Amlodipine 5mg daily. He also has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DMT2) diagnosed 10 years back and is on Metformin 1000mg per day. He had attended a health check-up 1 year ago and his blood pressure  blood sugar  and lipid profile were under control.   Key Complaints: Two weeks ago  Michael visited his doctor complaining of recent episodes of mild and diffuse chest discomfort over the past several weeks. He described the pain as a pressure sensation  primarily in the sternal region  rated 6/10  lasting for 10-15 minutes and typically occurring during physical exertion. No radiation of pain was reported. Michael found that rest or cessation of activity typically caused the pain to disappear.  The episodes were becoming more frequent over time  now happening 2-3 times per week  and increasingly interfering with his daily activities. He also mentioned feeling slightly more breathless than usual when climbing stairs  which used to be an easy task. However  he has not noted any palpitations  syncope  sweating  nausea  or vomiting.   This case report represents the typical demographics for Coronary Artery Disease. Coronary artery disease  a leading cause of morbidity and mortality  is more common in adults older than 60 years  males particularly African American and Hispanics due to a higher prevalence of hypertension and diabetes  and individuals with risk factors such as obesity  family history of CAD  smoking  hypertension  and diabetes.

Case Report: Cardiovascular Disease - Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: - 63 years old Male - African American - Occupation: Retired engineer - Smoking status: Ex-smoker (quit at age of 55) - Marital status: Married - Weight: 210lbs; Height: 5’8” - Residence: Urban area  Cleveland  Ohio  Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with hypertension at 50 years old; managed with hydrochlorothiazide - Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus at 58 years old; managed with metformin - No previous surgeries or hospitalizations - Family history of hypertension and coronary artery disease (father died at age 64 due to heart attack)    Presenting Complaints: - Patient has been experiencing intermittent chest discomfort  primarily on exertion over last 4 months. - The patient notices the discomfort particularly when climbing stairs and describes the discomfort as a ""heaviness in the chest"". - Episodes usually last for less than 10 minutes and are relieved by rest. - The patient also reports episodes of shortness of breath  fatigue  and light-headedness for the same duration.  Differential diagnosis: - Coronary artery disease - Stable angina - Gastroesophageal reflux disease - Panic anxiety disorder   Considering the patient's symptoms  age  background including a family history of coronary artery disease  the priority would be to rule out or confirm coronary artery disease. However  a comprehensive approach should be taken also addressing other potential causes of chest pain.   Note: Demographics are representative of many risk factors associated with coronary heart disease. The African American population experiences early onset of hypertension  a well-known risk factor. Moreover  men are more likely to experience coronary artery disease than premenopausal women. The patient is also in a typical age bracket (over 60)  and has multiple risk factors including smoking history and type 2 diabetes mellitus. It is thought that about half of men and a third of women over 40 will develop some form of cardiovascular disease in their lifetime.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 58 years - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian  - Occupation: Corporate Lawyer - Marital Status: Married  with 2 children  Past Medical History:  - Smoking for 30 years  quit at age 53. - Chronic hypertension for the past 10 years  controlled on medication. - Moderate hypercholesterolemia.  - Father passed away from myocardial infarction at age 63. - Maternal uncle diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD).  Key Complaints:  Mr. Doe has presented with the primary complaint of experiencing a heavy  squeezing chest pain for the last three days. The pain seems to radiate towards his left shoulder and it gets worse with exertion and eases with rest. In the last 24 hours  the chest pain has become more frequent  happening at least 3-4 times per day  even at rest. He also mentions slight shortness of breath and feeling unusually fatigued for the past 5 days. He reports feeling nauseous but no vomiting  observations of leg swelling  or weight gain.  This clinical case is fairly typical of the demographics found in coronary artery disease literature. According to the American Heart Association  coronary artery disease  also known as ischemic heart disease  is more commonly found in males over the age of 45 (especially those of Caucasian descent) with a history of smoking  hypertension  and familial cardiac events. Similarly  the complaints presented by Mr. John Doe are very typical of a patient with coronary artery disease  hence the need for further assessment and diagnostic tests.  The purpose of this case study is to enhance recognition of coronary artery disease presenting symptoms  enriched medical history-taking  understanding the significance of familial history  and investigating  diagnosing  and managing appropriately.

Case Report - Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient's information:  Name: Mr. John Williams Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Insurance Agent Residential Area: Suburban  Past Medical History:  Mr. Williams has a documented history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which have been managed with medication for the past ten years. He is also a former smoker  having quit about five years ago but reports a 30-pack year smoking history. He enjoys a diet high in saturated fats and automotive activity is his main form of exercise. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his elder sister has been recently diagnosed with atherosclerosis.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Williams reported an onset of intermittent chest pain that occurs during physical exertion such as walking uphill or climbing stairs but subsides when at rest. The pain is described as heavy and squeezing  located in the center of the chest and sometimes radiating to the left arm. He also mentioned experiencing episodes of shortness of breath and occasional dizziness. Over the past month  he has noticed that these symptoms have increased in frequency and that it takes less exertion to provoke them than before. He also reported that symptoms had started to wake him from his sleep  which is a newer manifestation.    Given the typical findings and his risk factors (hypertension  type-2 diabetes  high cholesterol diet  genetics  age  sex  and smoking history)  a preliminary diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease should be considered. Next steps would be to carry out diagnostic tests  including but not limited to an electrocardiogram  stress tests  and angiogram for confirmation of the diagnosis.  This scenario provides an opportunity for students to critically evaluate a patient's history  risk factors  and symptoms  formulating a likely diagnosis and arranging appropriate investigations. It encourages exploration of the pathophysiological links between risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia and the development of CAD. It is essential for students to recognize these links in order to understand the disease process  provide advice about lifestyle modification  report risks involved  and ensure the prompt diagnosis and treatment of the disease.  Reference:  Benjamin EJ  Muntner P  Alonso A  et al. Heart Disease and Stroke Statistics—2019 Update: A Report From the American Heart Association. Circulation. 2019;139(10):e56-e528.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease   Patient Information:  Mr. Marcus Johnson  a 68-year old African American male  currently residing in a suburban neighborhood in New York City  comes to our attention. He is a retired banker  a non-smoker  but has a 30-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 38  and type 2 diabetes mellitus at the age of 40  both of which are being managed with medication (Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes). He has had no recent hospitalizations. The family history includes a father who died of myocardial infarction at 70 and a mother who had stroke in her late 60s.  Present Complaint:  For the past couple of months  Mr. Johnson has experienced frequent episodes of chest discomfort  especially while walking his dog or climbing stairs. At first  he attributed the discomfort to old age and physical unfitness. However  the discomfort  a gripping sensation that often radiates towards his left shoulder  has become more frequent and recently  it occurred at rest. The pain relieves upon taking rest. However  the growing intensity of the discomfort prompted him to seek medical assistance.   Other symptoms Mr. Johnson has noticed include increased frequency of urination  fatigue  and dizziness. He denies any problems with his vision. He does not report any symptoms of hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia  indicating that his diabetes is possibly under control.   Note: The incidence of coronary artery disease (CAD) is higher among African Americans  with an even higher prevalence among those with comorbid conditions like diabetes and hypertension. The patient's age  gender  race  and comorbid conditions are consistent with the typical risk factors for CAD.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. Thompson Age: 65 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Location: New York  USA  lives alone but has a supportive neighbor. Occupation: Retired school teacher  Past Medical History:  1. Hyperlipidemia diagnosed at the age of 58 years. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus since the age of 60. 3. Ex-smoker (quit 5 years ago  smoked one pack a day for 40 years). 4. No known history of hypertension or any other cardiac diseases. 5. Father passed away from a heart attack at the age 68.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Thompson visits the outpatient department with complaints of recurrent chest pain for the last one month  commonly initiated by physical activity or emotional stress. He describes it as a heaviness in the center of his chest  which radiates towards his left arm and jaw. The pain generally lasts for about 15-20 minutes and has been subsiding with rest  but is noticeably getting more frequent. The pain is never present while at rest. In addition  he mentioned experiencing episodes of excessive sweating and feeling out of breath during these episodes.  Note: This patient case attempts to depict the typical demographic and lifestyle factors associated with coronary artery disease. Epidemiologically  CAD is more common among males  elderly individuals  Caucasians  and those with a history of hyperlipidemia  Type 2 DM  and smoking. Furthermore  the chosen complaints are representative of chronic stable angina  an important manifestation of CAD. However  patient presentations can vary widely  and CAD also occurs in those outside of these demographics.

Case Report:  Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a Middle-Aged Latino Male  Patient Information:  - Name: [Anonymous] - Age: 55 years - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Hispanic/ Latino - Occupation: Construction worker - Location: Urban area  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented with gradually increasing symptoms of chest discomfort radiating to the left arm which worsens on exertion and is relieved by rest. He also reported experiencing shortness of breath  unusual fatigue  lightheadedness  and dizziness over several weeks.  Past Medical History:  The patient has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension over the past 10 years and remains on medication. He admits to a history of smoking  consuming about 15 cigarettes per day for the last 20 years. There is no history of any other major surgery or significant medical conditions in the past. Family history reveals that his father had a heart attack at the age of 59.  Social History:  The patient lives with his wife and three children. He has limited recreational physical activity and admits to an imbalanced diet rich in fats and processed foods. He has not had any regular health check-ups  mentioning limited health literacy as a factor. He does not consume alcohol.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient was conscious  oriented  and mildly dyspneic. His vitals include heart rate - 92 beats per minute  blood pressure -154/96 mmHg  respiratory rate - 18 breaths per minute  and BMI of 29 Kg/m². Cardiovascular examination revealed a soft systolic murmur. The rest of the medical examination was unremarkable.   This case is designed for medical students to focus on recognizing  diagnosing  and managing coronary artery disease  given a set of common clinical symptoms  significant past medical history  lifestyle factors  and risk factors. It also emphasizes the importance of preventive measures  continuous monitoring  and management of comorbidities such as hypertension and diabetes  given their prevalence in patients with coronary artery disease  leading to poor outcomes.
